headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everybody, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com.We will now turn the ca
componenttext:
Good day, everybody, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com.
We will now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Company, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Taylor, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Chairman and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations.Before we begin, I'll co
componenttext:
Thank you, Taylor, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Chairman and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations.
Before we begin, I'll cover 2 items. First, during this presentation, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations. Actual events or results could differ materially.
Certain factors related to future expectations are or will be detailed in the company's fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results news release and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Form 10-Q filed for third quarter 2015 and the Form 10-K to be filed for 2015. 
Second, earnings per share, operating earnings and EBITDA referenced in this presentation exclude certain noncore costs, charges and gains.
A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and other associated disclosures, including a description of the excluded items, are available on the fourth quarter and full year 2015 financial results news release and in the appendix to the slides that accompany our remarks this morning. Both of these can be found in our website, www.eastman.com, in the Investors section.
Projections of future earnings in the presentation also exclude such items as described in the news release.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. 2015 was another outstanding year for Eastman as we continue to make excellent progress in our strategy to transform towards a specialty portfolio. We delivered our sixth consecutive year of solid EPS growth
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. 2015 was another outstanding year for Eastman as we continue to make excellent progress in our strategy to transform towards a specialty portfolio. We delivered our sixth consecutive year of solid EPS growth despite a very challenging global business environment and generated record free cash flow of $960 million, reflecting strong earnings as well as the benefit of recent acquisitions, which generated outstanding free cash flow. 
A strong contributor to earnings growth in our specialty businesses in 2015 was the progress we made on organic growth initiatives. I'll highlight just a couple of examples. In Advanced Materials segment, our window interlayers, particularly our acoustic and heads-up display products, delivered solid double-digit volume growth for the year. Also in AM, we delivered very strong growth from our new optical film solutions for mobile devices. And in Additives & Functional Products, tackifying resins into tires was a strong contributor to overall growth in 2015. 
These are just a few examples of how innovation and market development and supporting growth in overall difficult environment. We also did a great job in 2015 to successfully integrating our recently acquired businesses. Each of these acquisitions were completed and aligns well with our strategy of delivering consistent superior value and combined, delivered over $0.50 a share in accretion for the year as expected. 
In the cost management, we did an outstanding job in 2015, reflecting very strong productivity gains. Overall, we were able to more than offset inflation by about $25 million. 
We also made substantial progress on reducing our net debt. Finally, during the year, we remain committed to returning cash to our stockholders. We increased our dividend by 15%, the sixth straight year of increases, and over at that time, we have more than doubled the dividend, and we repurchased more than $100 million of stock. This strong performance in so many fronts is a great testament strength of Eastman's portfolio and integration and scale that has been built over decades. More importantly, I am very fortunate to work with such a strong team of employees, who consistently overcome challenges and find ways to deliver results for our stakeholders. 
Now I hand the call over to Curt to cover the financial details for 2015, and then I'll come back to talk about 2016.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Since we have a lot to cover today, I'll be brief with my comments. I'll start with our fourth quarter corporate results on Slide 4. We delivered solid earnings despite the many increasing challenges we faced during t
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Since we have a lot to cover today, I'll be brief with my comments. I'll start with our fourth quarter corporate results on Slide 4. We delivered solid earnings despite the many increasing challenges we faced during the quarter. The decline in revenue largely reflected lower selling prices due to lower raw material and energy costs. 
Operating earnings were down somewhat. Positives include strong volume growth in Advanced Materials and strong operating margins in Adhesives & Plasticizers. Headwinds were lower oil prices and the associated propane hedges, which largely impacted Specialty Fluids & Intermediates and lower volumes in Fibers. 
Earnings per share were solid and included a lower tax rate year-over-year, which reflected the full year impact of the tax extenders enacted in December. 
Next on Slide 5, looking at the full year, we delivered outstanding results, reflecting the strength and robustness of our strategy to transform to a specialty portfolio. Sales revenue increased slightly as sales from recently acquired businesses more than offset lower selling prices, which largely reflected lower raw material costs. Operating earnings increased in 3 of our segments with particularly strong earnings growth in Advanced Materials. Our operating margin for the year was 18%, an increase of nearly 100 basis points compared to 2014. Overall, we're very pleased with our results in a challenging business climate. 
Moving next to the segment results beginning on Slide 6, the Advanced Materials had an exceptional year as they continue to deliver on the elements of their strategy. Sales revenue increased due to higher sales volume and sales of products of the acquired performance films business. Offsets were currency and lower selling prices, which reflected lower raw material costs, particularly paraxylene for copolyesters. 
Operating earnings increased more than $100 million or about 40% due to a number of factors: volume growth and mix improvement, volume from the acquisition, operational improvements and improved spread. The improved product mix was driven by increased sales of optical film solutions and premium interlayers. 
The operating margin increased to roughly 17% from just over 12% in 2014. These results reflect execution of a strategy over a number of years to improve the operating margin in this business and to achieve an appropriate return given the investments made. We expect to build on this success going forward. 
Moving next to Additives & Functional Products on Slide 7, which had a solid year. The revenue increase was due to the impact of the Taminco acquisition. This was partially offset by lower coatings and other formulated products, selling prices, which reflected lower raw material and energy costs as well as the impact of currency. Operating earnings were up year-over-year, reflecting both improved spread and the impact of the Taminco acquisition. The business did a great job managing value in the face of a slower growth environment, increased competitive rivalry and narrowing olefin spreads. 
Moving next to additives -- I'm sorry, Adhesives & Plasticizers on Slide 8. For 2015, sales revenue declined, primarily due to lower prices reflecting lower raw material costs and currency. Volume was about flat as growth in nonphthalate plasticizers, particularly in North America, was offset by lower adhesives resins volume due to the lack of availability of raw materials earlier in the year as well as operational constraints. Operating earnings increased as improved spread was partially offset by propane hedges and currency. The operating margin increased to just under 20% as we did a good job of holding onto val through the year. 
Now to Fibers on Slide 9. Revenue declined mainly due to lower acetate tow and acetyl chemicals sales volume. The decline in tow volume was mainly attributed to consumer destocking especially in China. And the decline in acetyl chemicals volume was due to increased sales to the cellulose acetate flake joint venture in Kingsport. Operating earnings were down year-over-year due to lower tow and acetyl chemicals volume despite. The challenge for lower volume, the operating margin for the segment was 32%. 
I'll finish the segment review with Specialty Fluids & Intermediates on Slide 10. Sales revenue decreased as lower selling prices and lower chemical and other intermediate sales volumes more than offset the impact of acquisitions. For operating earnings, we had a number of significant headwinds impacting results. The significant decline in oil prices reduced the North American shale gas advantage. And as the market became long in ethylene and propylene, the drop in olefin prices outpaced the decline in oil, further impacting margins. Also slower-than-expected economic growth in Asia led to an increased level of competitive of import threats to the U.S. and Europe, and the impact of propane hedges was significant for this segment. These headwinds more than offset earnings from acquired businesses and commercial productivity actions we took through the year. While operating earnings declined for the year, we did a good job managing through a challenging environment. 
On Slide 11, I'll transition to the overview of cash flow and other financial highlights for 2015. We did an excellent job of generating cash in 2015 with operating cash flow over $1.6 billion. This is a new record for cash from operations as is our free cash flow of $960 million for the year. Capital expenditures totaled $652 million, below our previous expectations as we managed the pace of spend with the current economic environment while maintaining our growth investments. We expect to be at a similar level in 2016. 
Looking at the balance sheet. Net debt stands at $6.7 billion as of year-end, reflecting almost $600 million in debt reduction for the year. Our cash flows from balance sheet and liquidity keep Eastman in a position of strength in uncertain economy. 
Our full year dividend was $238 million, and this included a 15% increase in the fourth quarter. In addition, we had $103 million in share repurchases through the year, including $55 million in the fourth quarter. 
The combination of regular increases in our dividend and share repurchases reflected our continued confidence in future earnings and cash flows. And finally, our effective tax rate for the year was approximately 25%, which again includes the enactment of tax extenders for the fourth quarter as well as favorable geographic mix of earnings. We expect the effective tax rate for 2016 will be at a similar level, if not better as we continue to pursue opportunities to reduce this rate further. Overall, a strong year results given the challenging conditions. 
And with that, I'll turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Slide 13, I'd like to transition to 2016 and share our key objectives for this year. We're obviously, in a challenging macro environment and are using every lever to create value for our shareholders. In the next few slides, I'll discuss some of thes
componenttext:
On Slide 13, I'd like to transition to 2016 and share our key objectives for this year. We're obviously, in a challenging macro environment and are using every lever to create value for our shareholders. 
In the next few slides, I'll discuss some of these levers. First, our priority will be continued volume growth and mix upgrade in our specialties. We're aggressively increasing our cost-reduction activities, and we're also taking our next steps in portfolio management and organizational design, and we will return our strong free cash flow to shareholders. 
On Slide 14, I want to provide you a quick view on our historical volume growth as a basis for our forward look. Over the last 5 years, we delivered 10% compounded volume growth. Let's start with the foundation before our acquisitions. The yellow line reflects volume growth from our heritage specialty businesses, which you roughly see a 3% compounded growth. And then we levered our strong free cash flow and very strong balance sheet to expand our connection to attractive end markets with high-quality specialty products through several attractive specialty acquisitions. 
This organic growth both in heritage Eastman and within our acquisitions, is a tribute to our management team on 2 fronts: one, we are driving high-growth and innovation platforms that is well above end market growth rates; and second, we are doing an excellent job of balancing price-volume trade-offs in our core businesses. 
It's a great story of organic growth and disciplined capital deployment. We're also not waiting around for market growth. We are focused on creating our own growth. 
On Slide 15 you can see a depiction of how we execute our innovation and market development efforts. On the vertical axis are our key world-class technology platforms, and this is a combination of platforms that Eastman has had for decades: cellulose esters, polyesters, OXOs and hydrocarbon resins, and some that we recently acquired, PVBs and alkyl amines. 
Across the horizontal axis are 4 key end markets where we are concentrating our growth efforts. What you see is that we have a fairly concentrated set of initiatives that take advantage of our expertise in these platforms to help us further penetrate these attractive markets, some we've already mentioned this morning such as tire resins, acoustic and heads-up inter displays -- interlayers and new mobile device displays, others we have discussed in the past, including Tritan, our next-generation copolyester coatings and microfibers. 
We're making great progress with the innovation and market development portfolio, and I'm committed to accelerating investment in and emphasis on these efforts because I believe it is the key to Eastman's long-term success. We expect over the next 3 years that innovation and market development initiatives will add between 1% to 2% to overall Eastman revenue growth on a competitive basis, and that operating earnings for these revenues will be well above corporate average. 
Moving next to Slide 16. We also recognize that we're in a tough economic environment that will require aggressive cost management. Over the last couple of years, we've been able to offset inflation with productivity and cost-reduction initiatives. And in 2015, we were able to do a little bit more with over $25 million falling to the bottom line. 
This year, we know that in this very challenging environment, we need to do much more. We expect to double our productivity and cost-reduction efforts so that they're in the range of $200 million. After offsetting inflation, we project these combined efforts contribute about $0.50 per share to EPS this year, and I want to emphasize that as we achieve these cost reductions, we will continue to invest in our innovation and market development initiatives. We have a great track record of cost management, and I'm highly confident we will manage and achieve these cost-reduction targets for '16. 
That brings me to our outlook on Slide 17, and it starts with growth drivers that have been constant for us over the last 6 years. We have a strong performance specialty businesses that are well positioned for growth. They have delivered over the last 6 years. We expect that to continue into '16 and beyond. In addition, we expect that our innovative specialty products will continue to grow strongly, improving product mix and accelerating overall earnings growth. As I mentioned on the previous slide, we are today aggressive cost actions to add $0.50 a share. 
In addition, we will achieve further cost synergies from the acquisitions as we have guided in the past. We're also looking at every other lever. We see further improvement in tax, as Curt mentioned, and pension costs. We also will repurchase shares with our industry leading free cash flow after delevering in the back half of the year. 
All that said, we face remaining -- we face some increasing near-term challenges. The further collapse in the price of oil recently has increased price pressure, especially in our olefin and acetyl products. Stagnant global economic growth combined with weakening Asian European currencies are increasing some competitive activity in some products. We further expect to see inventory destocking in Fibers in China. 
In this challenging environment, we will drive hard to deliver EPS in 2016 that approaches our 2015 EPS, and we expect our EBITDA margins to be similar to 2015. Finally, we expect to deliver another strong year of free cash flow above $900 million. 
Next on Slide 18. As our announcement that we are improving our business structure, which results in changes to the segments, in which we report our financial results. Principally, we are making changes that better align our business model to drive long-term growth and support our continued transformation to a specialty portfolio, and part of this is enabled by the completion of the Taminco integration. This new structure should result in acceleration of growth opportunities and attractive markets. This also enables us to reduce cost in a more streamlined structure. And finally, this improved reporting structural will result in less complexity and enhanced visibility for those tracking our performance. 
On Slide 19, you can see this new structure. The biggest changes that we have moved from 5 segments to 4 with the Adhesives business moving to Additives & Functional Products and the Plasticizer business moving to the new Chemical Intermediates segment. Adhesives and AFP will enable us to better manage our businesses in combination with our great success of our tackifying resins going into tires. We also see more opportunities in application development adhesives, and we can leverage our world-class market development, application development capability in AFP. Plasticizers and distribution solvents from AFP will be better managed in chemical intermediates, where we have commercial excellence in managing pricing and asset utilization at a highly competitive environment. 
In addition, there are various product line moves to enhance market connect. This reporting structure's effective here in the first quarter, and we provide -- we plan to provide historical segment results on the new segment basis prior to releasing first quarter earnings. 
With these moves, the more specialty businesses are now in Additives & Functional Products and Advanced Materials, and the significant majority of our oil exposure, olefins, will now be in chemical intermediates. 
Our 2016 earnings expectations for these segments are as follows: we expect another year of strong growth in Advanced Materials, driven by volume and mix upgrade. Additives & Functional Products is expected to remain stable despite a tough market with volume growth offsetting price pressures, including adhesives being modestly lower. For Fibers, we are expecting declining prices due to lower pulp prices and weakening currencies, which will be offset by cost actions we have taken. 
Therefore, the key variable is volume. We expect continued destocking China, but we don't know yet how far it'll go, and we expect to know more in the coming months. For Chemical Intermediates, we expect earnings to be lower, given the collapse in the oil and the pressure on spreads in that business with the same trends impacting plasticizers. And once again, we believe this new business structure supports our strategy to transform towards a specialty portfolio. 
As you know, we have been on a long and committed journey to divest commodity businesses and add specialties. On Slide 20, I'll provide an update on our portfolio management efforts. Having successfully integrated our attractive acquisitions in 2015, we're shifting our focus in 2016 towards portfolio optimization consistent with our long-term strategy. Over the last few years, we've been looking to divest our excess ethylene position that continues to be a source of earnings volatility. These efforts have been constrained due to pipeline dispute with Westlake, which we have discussed previously. With favorable rulings from the Texas commission and the appeals court, we believe we can now move forward with our efforts to divest the excess ethylene. We are also pursuing strategic options for both excess ethylene and commodity olefin intermediates that are not essential to our specialty strategy and can be operationally segregated at the site. 
Of course, the specific scope may vary depending on buyer interest and valuation. I also want to be clear that our integrated Texas site produces advantaged ethylene and propylene, much of which we translate into our specialty derivatives and as such, will remain a critical integrated stream within our portfolio. We've hired an investment bank to restart the process to monetize our excess ethylene position and the other commodity olefin-related product lines that are not essential to our long-term strategy. This effort will be one of our top priorities in 2016, and we'll provide more details later in the year as it progresses. 
On Slide 21, our expectations for cash generation. As you can see on the bar chart, we have a history of generating strong free cash flow, particularly over the last 5 years. This reflects the strength of our solid core businesses as well as the transformation of our portfolio. 
Looking at 2016, we expect free cash flow to be greater than $900 million. With this free cash flow, we expect to continue deleveraging, having reduced the debt by over $600 million in 2015, and we expect to complete our delevering in 2016 to get to approximately $1 billion of debt reduction. As a result, we've also committed to our investors in past calls that we expect to fully utilize our free cash to pay an increasing dividend, continue delevering and repurchase shares. 
So in summary, on Slide 22, we have a strong portfolio specialty businesses that we are confident in, and we know that are going to drive volume growth this year and continue to drive on growth into the future. This organic set of initiatives our innovation our product improvement are essential our strategy, and they were essential in how we grew value last year, this year, in the future. We are committed to using every lever we have in this challenging environment, including increasing our cost-reduction efforts, and we will return our strong free cash to stockholders. Despite our short-term challenges this year, I'm confident we'll continue to deliver solid earnings growth for the long term and looking forward to the questions on this call. Thank you.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: Mark, on SFI, it was a challenging Q4. How should we think about the earnings progression into Q1 and for the full year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Curt, David. I'll take that. It's fair to say first half will be our toughest comp year-over-year especially the first quarter, given the strong performance especially fluids and intermediates had last year. It also if you think about earnings tra
componenttext: This is Curt, David. I'll take that. It's fair to say first half will be our toughest comp year-over-year especially the first quarter, given the strong performance especially fluids and intermediates had last year. It also if you think about earnings trajectory general, our cost-reduction efforts will help in first quarter but will be mostly in the subsequent quarters, plus the deleverage and some other share repurchases second half of '16 will help kind of overall shaping next year and specifically SFI when I got of look at their run rate last year versus this year, I would say right now the way things are shaping up, what you saw in the third quarter is more representative of what you might expect for the year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good, and just Curt and Mark, just on Slide 16 on the cost actions, can anybody give more concrete example besides working reduction, what also cost actions coming from, plants being closed, more concrete you can add?
componenttext: Very good, and just Curt and Mark, just on Slide 16 on the cost actions, can anybody give more concrete example besides working reduction, what also cost actions coming from, plants being closed, more concrete you can add?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So we saw things development we need to take action on cost like most people in this industry. And so we've done our restructuring program, where we're going to reduce nonoperating labor by about 7%, David. In addition, there's a bunch of other
componenttext: Yes, sure. So we saw things development we need to take action on cost like most people in this industry. And so we've done our restructuring program, where we're going to reduce nonoperating labor by about 7%, David. In addition, there's a bunch of other nonlabor spent items in SG&A and R&D that we have that we're going to be able to reduce some spent on and then there is a wide range of manufacturing cost improvements around our plants that we're pursuing in addition, of course, the other things like the plant closure in Workington, but that will be additive to the $0.50 a share. That working closure was not included in that $100 million. So that's an additional plus. I'd also emphasize that you've got quite a bit of cost synergies continued to flow in from the acquisitions on top of that $0.50 a share. So in collection that adds up to a pretty significant number.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Frank Mitsch with Wells Fargo.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When Curt was talking about the various segments, he did talk a fair amount about the interplay of pricing dropping due to the raw materials coming down, and that always is kind of a signal of more commodity type behavior rather than specialty type behavi
componenttext: When Curt was talking about the various segments, he did talk a fair amount about the interplay of pricing dropping due to the raw materials coming down, and that always is kind of a signal of more commodity type behavior rather than specialty type behavior. So Mark, as you think about your portfolio, and you went through this exercise to resegment into 4, what percent do you see it being commodity versus specialty in your mind? And I know you mentioned that you're going to restart the ethylene sale process. Are there other parts of the portfolio that you see as perhaps not fitting longer-term into EMN?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. The first on the specialties part with the resegmentation you should think about the parts of the products that we have that are commodity oriented that have been concentrated Chemical Intermediates. So the other segments really don't have an
componenttext: Sure, Frank. The first on the specialties part with the resegmentation you should think about the parts of the products that we have that are commodity oriented that have been concentrated Chemical Intermediates. So the other segments really don't have anything we consider to be commodities, and the reality is that even in specialty businesses when you have oil prices drop from $100 to $30, and you're oil-based, your customers sort of noticed and expect that some of that raw material benefit is going to be shared with them. So throughout last year, we realize obviously significant raw material benefits in our specialties and our commodities and the pace at which the price is shared within is very different. So in the commodities, it happens quickly. In the specialties, you still give back value to your customers. If you don't do that and if you hold onto price very aggressively, which you can certainly do a specialty, you set yourself up for volume within the future because even if your proprietary product, and we have a number of ones where we're the only a manufacturer in the world if you don't share some of that at an appropriate level, you put your customers on to find new suppliers, whether it's an alternative material or a smaller competitor you might have or you're a very strong leader in a Specialty business. So we do that. We are probably the most sophisticated commercial excellent pricing systems. I think in the industry, where we make these price volume all year long to make sure that we are sharing value but maintaining the ability to grow volume in the long term. Over the year, that plays out and prices come down and, to some degree, and you take that into this year, and that's a bit of a headwind versus how you started last year. But no, I don't think our specialties are commoditizing at all, and what I love about most of our technology platforms is we have next-generation products building up of the same assets, whether it's the next generation of acoustics and heads-up display product replacing copolyesters any series of opportunities going on to improve Crystex with our next-generation Crystex technology, et cetera. So we never sit around waiting for people to try and replicate as we always moving the ball down the field and advancing what we offer to our customers. So overall, I'd say the performance feels great on that front. What I did say, though, in my prepared remarks is we are expanding the scope of what we're considering selling be on excess ethylene. So we are looking at what other olefins that have commodity behavior in Chemical Intermediates, a lot of volatility, a lot of distraction for investors that is not essential to our long-term strategies are there not critical intermediates for our specialties. And so we're going to a look at how much of that we can package with excess ethylene and find a buyer who values that olefin portfolio in their strategy.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then following up on this theme, I really appreciate the Slide 14 with a volume growth of 3% in your AAA businesses, and then on top of that, I believe you're expecting 1% to 2% innovation market development as well. So that would
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then following up on this theme, I really appreciate the Slide 14 with a volume growth of 3% in your AAA businesses, and then on top of that, I believe you're expecting 1% to 2% innovation market development as well. So that would almost imply kind of a 4-plus percent improvement in that area. My sense is that given the economic backdrop in 2016, that would not be the case. How are you thinking about the potential volumes in AAA side in 2016?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Frank, I think when we look at AA, I guess, we're moving up in the ranks, those 2 segments, we still expect solid volume growth. Obviously, the economy's going to do what it does, and we'll track with it especially in the end markets we serve from
componenttext: Yes. So Frank, I think when we look at AA, I guess, we're moving up in the ranks, those 2 segments, we still expect solid volume growth. Obviously, the economy's going to do what it does, and we'll track with it especially in the end markets we serve from transportation to B&C and consumables being our 3 largest end markets, and I think those have attractive growth trends this year from what we can see. So I think we'll go with those markets. So I think we'll have volume growth that will be like history and within that, I think they'll get the mix uplift that will be these high-growth specialty products that aren't necessarily huge volumes, but they're very attractive earnings, and they provide nice leverage to earnings, but we don't see a volume problem in this year. We think it continues to be solid. We think will have good volume growth. We think volume growth will be better this year than last year when we look at because last year wasn't as much as we wanted, of course. So we do see some places and specific areas, where we are improving our market share position, where we'll get better volume growth there, too.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to get a sense on the earnings bridge. You did 7 28 in '15, $0.50 of cost savings. In your segment breakdown, you basically told us AM is going to be up. AFP is going to be stable. Fibers, the present Mark around volume and then you've got oil
componenttext: Just trying to get a sense on the earnings bridge. You did 7 28 in '15, $0.50 of cost savings. In your segment breakdown, you basically told us AM is going to be up. AFP is going to be stable. Fibers, the present Mark around volume and then you've got oil spread issue. So can you just help us what you think the FX headwind is in '16, and then when you say you're going to approach last year, does that mean you're going to be north of 7? Or do think you're actually get close to 7 28? I guess, what I'm really asking is how much risk do you think there is on the side of things? And is that really the true wildcard for you guys next year or this year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Vincent, thanks for the question. It's obviously a very important one. As we look at it, we do see a lot of tailwinds as you noted, good volume growth, mix upgrade, the cost-reduction actions, the acquisition synergies, improvements in tax, pension cos
componenttext: So Vincent, thanks for the question. It's obviously a very important one. As we look at it, we do see a lot of tailwinds as you noted, good volume growth, mix upgrade, the cost-reduction actions, the acquisition synergies, improvements in tax, pension costs as well as share account. So there are a  number very attractive tailwinds for us and really 2 principal issues as you've identified that are headwinds. So how much spread compression do we take this year versus last year and this volume on Fibers. When it comes to the spread issued, I think that there's predominantly that spread person is going to be and chemical intermediates feel a little bit of that AFP would still will have some olefins in that segment, and we expect prices to come off a bit in the adhesive, where things have been relatively tight last year. And so we'll have a little bit price get back and better volume growth this year netting each other but somewhat down. With the majority of the issues really a spread issue. And then, of course, we put in an expectation of some additional destocking in Fibers. There's a lot of moving parts when it comes to oil, the economy, the uncertainty and destocking that can combine those in a variety of different scenarios. The way of would suggest you all think about it is we're somewhere between stable to 2015 EPS and down 5% when I combine all of those different factors together in those I think give us that sort of range. Specific to FX, I'll let Curt answer that question.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vince. Just the way to think about currency itself right now, the currencies we've seen, particularly our exposures euro, is slightly down compared to what we saw on average for '15. Maybe the best way to look at it is if you think about just the net
componenttext: Yes, Vince. Just the way to think about currency itself right now, the currencies we've seen, particularly our exposures euro, is slightly down compared to what we saw on average for '15. Maybe the best way to look at it is if you think about just the net impact of hedges whether that was the cost of the propane hedges or the benefit of the currency hedges, net-net, that was probably a $0.60 headwind for us for the year. For '16, we think the net impact of these changes in hedges, net-net, is going to be about flat. This is was a little lower than we were thinking before, primarily due to the collapse of oil and the underlying impact on our propane hedges, but then that $0.60 impact really rolls off in '17 and '18.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just building on that comment, I think it's important for investors to understand a lot of what we're seeing right now we view as pressure or not launch of pressure we don't think there's anything undermining our long-term growth strategy of deliverin
componenttext: And just building on that comment, I think it's important for investors to understand a lot of what we're seeing right now we view as pressure or not launch of pressure we don't think there's anything undermining our long-term growth strategy of delivering attractive earnings growth in '17 and beyond. To Curt's point if oil and currency stay where they at, we'll just get natural $0.60 lift in '17 and '18, $0.60 a share lift as those roll off. Oil prices go up, our earnings will improve just as they've pressured it down. So either way, you look at you got earnings growth coming in '17 and '18 depending on your view about oil prices because I think is likely they'll be better than where they are today. In addition to that, you've got continued volume growth next year. You've got this transition of spread expansion in '15, normalizing a bit of those spreads in '16. That is a 2-year event when you're adjusting from $100 to $30 oil, but you don't have that in '16 anymore. That'll be behind us and then on top of that, we've got continued ways to improve costs and importantly, we have a very strong free cash flow, and we'll be repurchasing shares started in the back half of this year and strongly in '17. So while we're certainly disappointed about some of the challenges right now, we are focused on driving long-term growth and taking actions that makes sense to maintain volume growth long term and deliver strong earnings growth beyond this year and '17, '18 and beyond.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: No, I think if you look at the bridge, only thing I probably is going to be a little different, 2 aspects. One is we're not anticipate the release of working capital as great as we experienced in 2015 as we go into 2016 just because of just way have fallen on a relative basis plus there's always some difference in years between when you make your tax payments, et cetera, but I'm very confident in our ability to generate meaningful cash flow in 2016, and I think it's just a matter of how much higher over $900 million it's going to be.

componenttext: Okay. And then in Q4, AFP also saw price down about 10%, which was probably their price movement that surprised me the most. Is that still just the olefins effect in that segment or were there some other spreads in there that got compressed as well?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was principally just the olefins. We've been doing a great job of holding onto value all year long, but we came to the point where at some places we needed to reduce prices to remain competitive. It's a tough comp versus where prices were at $100 oil i
componenttext: It was principally just the olefins. We've been doing a great job of holding onto value all year long, but we came to the point where at some places we needed to reduce prices to remain competitive. It's a tough comp versus where prices were at $100 oil in the fourth quarter of '14. So it was just that.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from P.J. Juvekar with Citi.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It just seems that you were hurt more by the ethylene chain than the propylene chain, given your exposure. Would you agree with that? And on the propylene side, sort of how much impacts do you have in the area?
componenttext: Yes. It just seems that you were hurt more by the ethylene chain than the propylene chain, given your exposure. Would you agree with that? And on the propylene side, sort of how much impacts do you have in the area?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the propylene side, propylene prices also came off through the year, and we look at cracking spreads. They obviously came in on the propylene side if you look at the first half versus the second half of the year, and our prices tracked with it, and
componenttext: So on the propylene side, propylene prices also came off through the year, and we look at cracking spreads. They obviously came in on the propylene side if you look at the first half versus the second half of the year, and our prices tracked with it, and we're taking that lower probably pricing to this year. So certainly there's a first half headwind this year versus last year when it comes to propylene. The ethylene is sort of the opposite story. Ethylene prices were relatively good in first half of last year and then obviously, came off pretty significantly in the back half of last year. So it sort of the flip story there on sort of where it goes, but we expect ethylene prices to improve into the second quarter this year as is very large cracking maintenance schedule takes place this year. That should certainly move ethylene prices back up a bit. We're not expecting it to go back to last year, but we certainly expect improvement versus right now. So moving parts there. On the coating side, the -- our customers there -- sorry? I thought you had said something. On the coating side, we certainly saw our customers do a very good job of working with us in getting their presence down on the propylene-related derivatives and getting a benefit from that.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question on tow. You took a step down in 4Q in terms of year-over-year comparison. Can you discuss some of the declines? You said declines in China. Can you discuss tow declines in China and outside of China?
componenttext: A quick question on tow. You took a step down in 4Q in terms of year-over-year comparison. Can you discuss some of the declines? You said declines in China. Can you discuss tow declines in China and outside of China?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with the tow business, first I'll take outside of China, which is the more straightforward story. What we see there is that destocking come to an end, and we expect times to be relatively stable into this year. Outside of China, we have seen pric
componenttext: Sure. So with the tow business, first I'll take outside of China, which is the more straightforward story. What we see there is that destocking come to an end, and we expect times to be relatively stable into this year. Outside of China, we have seen prices come off some with the reduction in pulp prices and our competitors in Europe and Asia Pacific using their weakening currency as a way to attempt to chase volume. We, of course, defended our market position, but the crisis did come down a bit. With all the cost actions we're taking in that business, we've been able to offset that pricing decline that we're seeing outside of China. So really it is about a pure question around what does a volume do in China at this point. And what I'd say is well, from what we can see the chinese national tobacco company made progress in their destocking company in 2015, but not achieved their objectives in going as far as they are wanted to. They have to walk a tight balance in delivering their tax revenue increase for the year, which they did do, which limits how far they can go and producing production and achieving their inventory management goals, and so they're going to do another round of that this year and trying to work that inventory down. It's important to keep in mind as well that when you see this sort of volume issue in '15 and '16, a good portion of it is also CNTC backward integrating with tow suppliers. So we did JV in the end of '14 with CNTC, and that is what led to a certain amount of volume decline in '15. And Daicel did a JV, which is going to be part of why volume goes down this year. So you shouldn't misinterpret that as a decline in primary demand. We don't see any issues with primary demand. Our consumption going to decline. This is all about inventory management and some backward integration. The good news on the backward integration front is that we don't expect any other tow backward integration by CNTC until the 2019, '20 time frame. So that won't be an issue as we go into '17 and '18 and other upside for sort of '17, '18 versus what we're seeing this year. So overall, I'd say it's we expect some decline, and we just have to wait and see how it goes with a final conversations and content negotiation.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, could you give us a outlook in 2016 on the Crystex business?
componenttext: Mark, could you give us a outlook in 2016 on the Crystex business?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Crystex has been a great, great business for us. Obviously, it's a challenging market condition with primary demand not being robust, but we saw volume growth last year, and in particular, we saw that volume growth really pick up in the second half
componenttext: Sure. Crystex has been a great, great business for us. Obviously, it's a challenging market condition with primary demand not being robust, but we saw volume growth last year, and in particular, we saw that volume growth really pick up in the second half of last year relative to the first half, and we expect that volume growth will continue into this year. So from a demand point of view, everything seems to be on track. On the pricing side, it's competitive business. We have a lot bunch of little small competitors in Asia, and we've been dealing with since 2012, and we're seeing some price pressure there. I'd say in one place our Japanese competitors using their weakening yen to sort of chase volume, where we're once again defending our market positions. They're just giving a potential earnings growth by and improving margins, but I think it's all playing out sort of as we plan. We feel very good about our new technology. We're bringing on our process technology and our retrofit in Germany this quarter, and we're on track to develop the no plans and build the new platinum and have it online at the end of -- not in the end, in the beginning of 2017, and that will significantly improve our cost structure for competing in this business. So feel good about this.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fantastic, and then you made some comments on ethylene divestitures and how the pipeline dispute was holding that process up. It looks like you feel more confident that this process is moving forward in 2016. Could you just evaluate the pipeline dispute a
componenttext: Fantastic, and then you made some comments on ethylene divestitures and how the pipeline dispute was holding that process up. It looks like you feel more confident that this process is moving forward in 2016. Could you just evaluate the pipeline dispute and where it stands and how quickly you think you could wrap that up?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, this is Curt. Eastman, as Mark mentioned, Eastman has won every case to date on this dispute whether those it's those Texas Railroad Commission rulings, favorable opinion from the appeals court, so that really speaks to the strength of our position.
componenttext: Jim, this is Curt. Eastman, as Mark mentioned, Eastman has won every case to date on this dispute whether those it's those Texas Railroad Commission rulings, favorable opinion from the appeals court, so that really speaks to the strength of our position. So we recognize there may be a few more steps to completely resolve this dispute, but we're confident that we can move forward with these efforts to divest the excess ethylene at this time, and the timing of resolving these disputes is very similar to the time line we think it's going to take to complete a divestiture.

componenttext: On that want to be clear because I'm sure this question will come up a lot. The reality is we want to maintain some flexibility because in the olefins world, each the potential buyer actually has a slightly different interest in what they might want in our portfolio, and so we maximize shareholder value in what we sell we're going to keep that flexibility in there and be able to sort of address what the interest might be.

Pricing, we're going to see where oil goes.

componenttext: All right, and then maybe you can help me understand the ethylene issue a little bit better. My understanding you're running about 70% propane feed to your crackers and you also have what one of your crackers that shutdown. So when you think about divestitures, would you be, I mean, could help me understand what you be moving away the asset you closed down? Or would you be would potentially putting any capital to work towards  a heavier even propane feed in order to get propylene you need? I guess, I'm just trying to understand how you get rid of that ethylene without also losing some of the propylene that you need.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good news our solutions there and as we talked about in the press as we try to monetize our excess ethylene we indicated we do not necessarily need to be the owner smaller crackers, many times we call the type 3 crackers. Nothing has changed in that r
componenttext: The good news our solutions there and as we talked about in the press as we try to monetize our excess ethylene we indicated we do not necessarily need to be the owner smaller crackers, many times we call the type 3 crackers. Nothing has changed in that regards. Our larger cracker is really heavily integrated into our overall site operations and is really critical to our specialty derivative production. So as we go through the strategic evaluation, we will ensure that reliability integrity safety of this crackers reserve to support our specialty derivative product lines, and this is consistent with our strategy again to reduce volatility but not compromising our specialty growth. On the propylene, I also remind you yes, we're net buyer today but as we look forward to the start-up of the PDH unit with enterprise, we'll be kind of fully integrated with our propylene, but as we move down the road, we can think about different options on all these crackers may play out in our strategic options, and we'll be able to adjust appropriately.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one. On your transportation and construction breakouts for the specialty businesses, can you breakout your current thinking about how much is maintenance versus first fit for OEM and what you're seeing on the OEM trends in the very near-term
componenttext: Just a quick one. On your transportation and construction breakouts for the specialty businesses, can you breakout your current thinking about how much is maintenance versus first fit for OEM and what you're seeing on the OEM trends in the very near-term like next 3, 6 months.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Our customers are probably more qualified to comment. On the tire side, 75% of that business is roughly replacement, and it's important to remember we're leveraging commercial tires much more so than passenger tires when it comes to the amount of Cr
componenttext: Sure. Our customers are probably more qualified to comment. On the tire side, 75% of that business is roughly replacement, and it's important to remember we're leveraging commercial tires much more so than passenger tires when it comes to the amount of Crystex per tires, 10x in a commercial tire versus passengers. So what we see there is like there will be economy getting better in the U.S. improving in Europe, and it's still growing in China, by the way, just not as fast as we'd all like, and so that's all sort of driving the need for replacement tires especially increased construction activity in North America and even some increased construction activity in Europe that we're seeing. So that's sort of how we talk about the tire side of it. On coatings, when you look at transportation and building construction, we expect a good year in North America, which is where we have our largest market share with the increasing construction rate of housing coming for us in '16. And we also saw decent growth rates in Europe. So that's all feeling relatively good. China's a bit of a wildcard but still some growth. When it comes to interlayers they had a phenomenal year last year and automotive as well as a good architectural year in Europe. And on the automotive side, we've significantly faster than the market for a couple of reasons. One is we're seeing good the addressable market grow because a lot of the company OEMs are moving to putting laminated glass on the side windows and even the sunroofs. So the market's just getting bigger relative to OEM build rate. In addition, a lot more use of acoustics, both for quieting the cabin as well as lightweight in the windows, and heads-up displays been growing very strongly with a home mobility trend. It's now to figure out an extra as you've got to go to the Consumer Electronics Show for cars, and the heads-up displays a critical part of all those technology trends. So all of that allowing grow much faster than the OEM build rate, which is about 60%, 70% of the total for interlayers. So each business is a different story, but all of them are good ones.

componenttext: And then if we roll over [indiscernible] for the 2 As [ph] over the next, what, 3, 4 years what do you see as you're mixed tailwind for margins you a lot of moving parts in terms of the hedges and market trends but what do you see these tailwind just for margin uplift if any or for mix shift.

componenttext: I'm not sure I've done all math that you're doing we are compare notes like we always do over time, but I would say yes, we're facing significant headwinds, and so we're offsetting that with again growth in Advanced Materials, stability in AFP. We're also than see the cost-reduction actions. I'd also remind that we're also going to finish deleveraging during the course of '16 as well as look at repurchasing shares mostly weighted toward the second half of the year. So those will also help overcome some of that headwind.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one quick one, Mark. Eastman's done a nice job of kind of locking away from more commodity businesses and adding specialty businesses. Unfortunately, the commodity business seems to continue to weigh on your earnings results probably more t
componenttext: Okay. And then one quick one, Mark. Eastman's done a nice job of kind of locking away from more commodity businesses and adding specialty businesses. Unfortunately, the commodity business seems to continue to weigh on your earnings results probably more than you might have thought. What are your thoughts and what do you think you need to do with the portfolio now to maybe reposition it to continue to lessen those exposures? I know you want to pay down debt, but that acquisition something that you would consider to continue to improve the portfolio?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what you want to do is what we just announced, which is get the volatile bit out of the portfolio, right? So go into 4 segments, concentrating the olefins in one segment, where we can better manage that business and the volatility in it day
componenttext: Well, I think what you want to do is what we just announced, which is get the volatile bit out of the portfolio, right? So go into 4 segments, concentrating the olefins in one segment, where we can better manage that business and the volatility in it day to day, make sure we capture the best value of the current market situation. That's why we pull the distribution solvents out of AFP and put plasticizers in there. It also allows us to look at all options for what is best divested from this portfolio that certainly is a distraction for investors having a disproportionate impact on our evaluation and allow us to focus on our specialty strategy because you're right. Last year, we did a great job of growing our specialties. It was why we delivered earnings growth. We're going to do it again next year and beyond, and that's where we should be spending our time and focusing our efforts when it comes to acquisitions as I said the second quarter call and the third quarter call last year, we're not looking for a large M&A. We're looking to focus and growing our platform we have. We have a lot of great organic growth initiatives kicking into gear already and ones that are about to come especially in AFP. Those were a little bit behind in cycle relative to Advanced Materials. So you're going to hear a lot more stories about that as we go forward, but we're not looking for any large M&A. It's always possible to find on M&A that might be attractive that dramatically improves the business we're in like we did last year in Advanced Materials with our Commonwealth acquisition, but our focus right now is generating cash flow and repurchasing shares.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Taminco had a great year and a good quarter. So overall, they did as we expected. Volumes held together nicely. You saw strength in things like crop protection for the year as well as personal care doing well. Usually there's some pressure in soybean and
componenttext: Taminco had a great year and a good quarter. So overall, they did as we expected. Volumes held together nicely. You saw strength in things like crop protection for the year as well as personal care doing well. Usually there's some pressure in soybean and corn-related functional amines demand with all the drama in the ag industry. That's small percentage of their total revenue, and we took some hits, of course, and some products going into downhole applications on the energy side, but a lot of that was offset by gas cleanup sales doing quite well on the downstream part of that business for us. So volumes held in well and came out as we expected. Margins also are fine. The only 2 hits we've had in that business is currency obviously, like every thing else and then some of the methanol that we produced from our advantage contract obviously is feeling spread pressure relative to how methanol prices have come down.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2016

componenttext: And if I could add, Mark, what I like about Taminco we have completed integration. We achieved about $25 million of cost synergies in 2015. We expect that to be about $50 million of cost synergies as well as me now believe we'll have some good tech synergies that will have our effective tax rate in 2016. So again only is that a good collection of good integration by both teams. It's also the business that seems are responding to of business climates to help our businesses trend meant at Eastman.
