componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company First Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com. We will now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Company, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you, Taylor, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Chairman and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations.Before we begin, I
componenttext:
Okay, thank you, Taylor, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Chairman and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations.
Before we begin, I'll cover 2 items. First, during this presentation, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations. Actual events or results could differ materially.
Certain factors related to future expectations are or will be detailed in the company's first quarter 2016 financial results news release and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Form 10-K filed for 2015 and the Form 10-Q to be filed for first quarter 2016. 
Second, earnings per share and operating earnings referenced in this presentation exclude certain noncore costs, charges and gains.
A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and other associated disclosures, including a description of the excluded items, are available on the first quarter 2016 financial results news release, which can be found on our website, www.eastman.com, in the Investors section.
Projections of future earnings also exclude any noncore, unusual or nonrecurring items. With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. We had a solid start of the year with the first quarter results, which were slightly better than our expectations. Overall, our strategy is working. We did a great job of holding onto value through the quarte
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. We had a solid start of the year with the first quarter results, which were slightly better than our expectations. Overall, our strategy is working. We did a great job of holding onto value through the quarter as we increased our operating margin by 40 basis points or over 18%. We continue to upgrade the quality of our product mix by growing high-margin specialty product lines, a key component of our winning strategy. 
To see more of our strategy in action, I recently traveled to visit customers in Asia, and I'm really excited about all the innovation and customer engagement that's gaining traction across the region from India to China to Japan. In India, we secured our first commercial success on our next-generation polyester coatings platform with a leading manufacturer of SUVs and tractors. As I met with them, I was excited to see their engagement and enthusiasm for our solution and how it could significantly improve their ability to maintain their leadership cost effectively. 
With increasing expectations from the emerging middle class in India and new western competitors, this customer faced a challenge. Upgrade the durability and glass retention of their mono coat coating were spent significant money to build a more expensive 2-coat systems. Our revolutionary next-gen polyester coating enabled them to achieve best-in-class performance with a mono coat instead of moving to a much more expensive 2-coat solution. We were there last September when the first SUVs rolled off the assembly line, a short 15 months after the project started in, and now there are more than 30,000 SUVs on the road. 
Key to this success was a tremendous partnership built between this auto OEM, their exceptional coatings formulator and Eastman. We started with auto coatings, and we're making tremendous progress in industrial and package coatings as well. 
In China, we recently partnered with a leading local housewares brand to launch a product line that utilizes their tracking copolyester, and we're seeing increased local need for greater product safety and durability. Similar to success in India, this customer's looking for a way to differentiate themselves from other local competitors, and I'm very bullish on this market expansion into China for a product that is predominantly been sold to North America and European consumers. 
As part of our success, we are providing training to the company's 20,000-person sales force that works throughout department stores in China, who were pitching our Tritan value proposition for us everyday. These are just 2 of many examples where we're succeeding by helping our customers through innovation. 
On the cost management front, we are well on track with our corporate cost-reduction efforts without sacrificing our long-term growth initiatives. Our SG&A and R&D as a percentage of sales remains in the low -- lowest quartile of our peers, which is a function of our scale and integration and the great discipline of our employees. We've also made excellent progress in reducing manufacturing costs. Productivity is in the DNA of Eastman, and we continue to succeed. 
Cash flow is consistent with our expectations, and we are on track to deliver another strong year of free cash flow, enabling our increasing dividend, deleveraging and repurchasing shares in the back half of the year. 
Beyond these great results, we've also been the recipient of numerous awards over the past several months, which highlight many of the qualities our stakeholders have come to expect from Eastman. We received the Glassdoor Employees Choice Award honoring the best places to work. What I valued most of this -- about this award is it's based solely on the input of employees. We're the only chemical company to be in the top 50 best place to work ever, and this is our third year in a row we've been honored. The award speaks to our winning culture, which enable us to innovate with our customers and integrate our acquisition so successfully. 
We're also named one of the world's most ethical companies for the third consecutive year by Ethisphere for outstanding corporate ethics and corporate responsibility, characteristics highly valued by our employees, our communities and our customers. 
Finally, we were recognized by the EPAs and Energy Star Partner of the Year award, becoming the only chemical company to ever receive this recognition consecutively for 5 years in a row, and only 2 other chemical companies have received it once. This is a great win for both the environment and our cost structure. 
Our solid first quarter results and the continued recognition we're receiving are direct result of the great work being done by Eastman employees around the world, and I want to thank them for their outstanding contributions. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Curt.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Mark, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. I know it's been a busy week for you. I want to go off script for a second here just to pile on a little to Mark's comments. I'm now coming on -- the CFO now coming on 8 years, and I just w
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Mark, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. I know it's been a busy week for you. 
I want to go off script for a second here just to pile on a little to Mark's comments. I'm now coming on -- the CFO now coming on 8 years, and I just wanted to express the excitement we have with our various growth programs. When I look through my finance lens, I'm convinced that these growth programs will lead to meaningful revenue growth and strong returns for the coming years, and it's a real pleasure to watch a winning strategy get executed by Mark and our business technology and strategy teams despite this business climate that we're facing and to be a part about high-performing, winning culture that Mark talked about. 
So many of you know this already. Good things are happening at Eastman that will benefit both 2016 and beyond. 
So with that, let me get back to my prepared remarks. I'll start on our first quarter corporate results on Slide 4. Overall, we delivered a solid quarter in a challenging business climate. Sales revenue declined as sales -- solid sales line growth was more than offset by lower selling prices. As we expected, the largest decline was in the Chemical Intermediates segment, where low oil has its greatest impact. 
Our operating earnings decreased as strong performance in Advanced Materials was more than offset by a decline in Chemical Intermediates. Overall, earnings per share was solid, reflecting good quality earnings and a lower tax rate, and I'm proud of how our commercial teams are finding the right balance of retaining appropriate value given the attributes and value proposition of our specialties and sharing some that benefit of lower raws with our customers. 
On Slide 5, I'll transition to an overview of our cash flow and other financial highlights for the year -- or for the quarter, sorry. We continue to do an excellent job of generating cash with first quarter operating cash flow of $47 million in what is typically our lowest quarter. These results reflect our normal beginning of the year working capital build. 
Capital expenditures totaled $110 million. We continue to manage the pace of capital spending with the current economic environment while maintaining growth investments. We expect full year capital expenditures to be approximately $650 million, maybe a little less as the year unfolds. 
Free cash flow was a negative $63 million for the quarter, consistent with our expectations. Our first quarter dividend was $68 million. Our effective tax rate for the first quarter improved to approximately 24%. We continue to expect our full year tax rate will be between 24% and 25%, reflecting the continued benefits of our improved business operations, and we'll continue doing what we can to be at the lower end of that range. 
For free cash flow, we remain on track to be above $900 million. As a whole, I'm pleased with our earnings and cash flow per to start the year. 
On Slides 6 and 7, I'll provide an overview of the 2 segments most affected by our business restructuring. This is the first quarter we're reporting under the new business structure. So we thought these would be helpful. 
First under our new structure, Additives & Functional Products is well positioned for GDP-plus growth with an attractive market footprint and diverse geographic profile. Our transportation exposure is about 75% replacement, 25% OEM. This split is similar for building and construction. 
Performance drivers for the segment include increasing demand for quality vehicles, the improvement in housing market and increasing use of consumables by growing middle class, and we remain focused on attractive secular growth end markets, where innovation and deep customer connect offer a clear competitive advantage. 
As we look forward, I'm excited about the growth we expect from our innovation projects. Mark already shared an exceptional story of rapid innovation in India. We are continuing to see strong growth in our tire resins as a performance additive and strong growth in our low VLC, low order for architectural paints, and we're just getting started with integration efforts in alkylamine specialties. 
Next on Slide 7, the new Chemical Intermediates segment, which now comprises the majority of our olefins exposure. We'll benefit from advantaged market positions in key intermediates, particularly in North America. Performance drivers for this segment include growing middle class, continued adoption of nonphthalate plasticizers and North American shale gas advantage. In addition, flexible market outlets will drive our asset utilization and support growth for our strategic specialty product lines. Overall, the segment has a set of good value-adding businesses, which benefit from scale, integration and reliability and are essential to supporting the growth in our specialty businesses. 
Moving next to the segment results and starting with Advanced Materials on Slide 8, which delivered a strong quarter. Sales revenue increased due to higher sales volume of premium products, including Eastman Tritan copolyester and Saflex acoustic interlayers. This was partially offset by lower selling prices, primarily for copolyesters, attributed to lower raw material costs. Earnings increased, primarily due to higher sales volume and improved product mix of premium products and lower unit cost due to higher capacity utilization. 
Looking at the full year, we continue to expect strong results for Advanced Materials as they progress on our strategy for this business of volume growth, mix improvement and fixed cost leverage. Sequentially, we expect volume will increase due to normal seasonality for our copolyester customers. We had strong sales in March that has continued into mid-April. 
Interlayer volumes remains strong as OEM auto builds remain solid, acoustic growth continues, and overall building construction market in Europe is improving. As a result, for the year, we expect greater-than-GDP volume growth for this business. 
In addition to the strong volume growth, we expect further robust mix improvements with continued growth in high-margin products such as Trident copolyester and acoustic interlayers. As we continue to fill out our existing capacity, we benefit from fixed cost leverage. We expect all of these factors will result in strong earnings growth for Advanced Materials. 
Now it's Additives & Functional Products on Slide 9. Overall, a solid quarter despite the short-term challenges. Revenue declined, primarily due to lower selling prices, attributed into lower raw material energy costs and competitive pressure for certain products, particularly in Asia Pacific. Operating earnings decreased, primarily due to an unfavorable shift in foreign currency rates. 
Looking at the full year 2016, we expect solid volume growth for AFP, in line with the end market growth. In particular, we expect volume growth in the transportation, building and construction and consumables end markets. We also expect lower selling prices, reflecting both lower raw material costs, and as we discussed in January, we did an excellent job holding onto value last year while we also started to share this value with our customers towards the end of 2015 and through the first quarter this year. 
Overall, we expect Additives & Functional Products to be stable to slightly down, which would be a solid result in the current business climate. 
Now to Fibers on Slide 10. Results for this segment were as expected. Sales revenue declined, primarily due to lower acetyl chemical sales volume and lower acetate tow selling prices, mostly offset by higher acetate tow sales volume. The higher acetate tow sales volume was attributed to customer buying patterns. The decline in acetyl chemicals was due to lower cost internal sourcing of cellulose acetate flake raw materials rather than obtaining these raw materials from our joint venture in Kingsport. 
Earnings for the quarter declined moderately as lower selling prices were partially offset by higher acetate tow sales volume, lower raw material energy costs and reduced operating cost resulting from recent actions. Looking at the full year 2016, our current expectations are in line with the guidance I provided at an investor conference in March. We expect acetate tow sales volume to be down about 10% for the year, mainly reflecting customer backward integration and destocking in China. We also expect selling prices to decline but to be mostly offset by lower raw material costs as well as the benefit of cost actions we have taken. As a result, we are expecting earnings to be down close to 15% for the year. 
I'll finish up the segment review with Chemicals Intermediates on Slide 11. Chemicals Intermediates delivered a solid quarter despite significantly volatility -- significant volatility impacting their business. Sales revenues in the first quarter declined, primarily reflecting lower selling prices attributed to lower raw material costs. Chemical Intermediates is also impacted by continued competitive pressure resulting from weak demand in Asia Pacific. Operating earnings declined, in part due to a difficult comparison. In the first half of 2015, we did a great job of holding onto value during a period of significant raw material cost decline. In the first quarter 2016, selling prices were down, reflecting the lower raw material costs and therefore, margins declined. 
Looking at the full year 2016, we expect a number of factors to impact results. We expect solid volume growth due to continued plasticizers growth, particularly in the building and construction market as well as overall modest growth in North America, which is almost 70% of the overall segment revenue. We also expect olefin margins to remain under pressure as the recent increase in oil price has not yet translated to improving olefin prices, particularly ethylene, and we expect lower methanol prices to enable lower pricing by competitors in some of our acetyl and amines product lines. Therefore, for 2016, we expect earnings to be meaningfully lower, given the low oil environment and the pressure on spreads, and I'd add that when you think about how the year will unfold, we expect second quarter operating earnings will be lower than first quarter due to both significantly higher maintenance shutdown costs and how our propane hedge flows through cost. 
Lastly, I'll give you a quick update on our process for divesting our merchant ethylene position and potentially other commodity olefin product lines. As we mentioned in January, we're moving forward with this process and having engaged bankers. The books are now out, and we're talking with potential buyers and are pleased with the initial interest. We will be disciplined, patient sellers as we move through this process, and we will update you further as the process continues to progress. 
With that, I'll turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Curt. I'll transition to our outlook on Slide 12. We have a strong portfolio specialty businesses. They've delivered over the last 6 years, and we expect that to continue in 2016. We expect our innovative specialty products will continue to grow s
componenttext:
Thanks, Curt. I'll transition to our outlook on Slide 12. We have a strong portfolio specialty businesses. They've delivered over the last 6 years, and we expect that to continue in 2016. We expect our innovative specialty products will continue to grow strongly, improving product mix and accelerating overall earnings growth. And we are levered to grow in attractive end markets as specialty transportation, building construction and consumables. 
We're equally committed to meet our aggressive cost-reduction targets. In addition, we expect to achieve further cost synergies from our acquisitions. And after delevering, we also expect to repurchase shares in the back half of the year. 
In the near term, however, slow global economic growth combined with low oil and weak Asian and European currencies are increasing competitive pressure in some products. And as we guided earlier in the year, we expect some inventory destocking in China to impact Fibers results. 
Net, we'll continue to drive hard to deliver EPS that approaches our 2015 EPS, and we are maintaining our guidance for EPS to be flat to down 5%. And given where olefins are today, we are likely to be more towards the lower end of that range. 
I'd also note that the first half of the year will be a tougher comp than the back half. As I look beyond 2016, we are well positioned for growth as these short-term challenges recede and our strong growth drivers continue. Altogether, I'm confident we'll continue to deliver attractive earnings growth in the long term as we transform towards a specialty portfolio. 
Thanks for joining us this morning, and I look forward to your questions.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Mark. We've got a lot of people on the line this morning, and we like to get to as many questions as possible. [Operator Instructions] With that, Taylor, we are ready for questions.
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Mark. We've got a lot of people on the line this morning, and we like to get to as many questions as possible. [Operator Instructions] With that, Taylor, we are ready for questions.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from David Begleiter with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the guidance, you had strong Q1 beat. The world's gotten probably a little bit better since late January. FX a little bit better as well yet you're now guiding towards a lower half of that, down flat to down 5% range. So it seems awfully conservative.
componenttext: On the guidance, you had strong Q1 beat. The world's gotten probably a little bit better since late January. FX a little bit better as well yet you're now guiding towards a lower half of that, down flat to down 5% range. So it seems awfully conservative. Help me with that if you can.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. So obviously it's pretty dynamic environment out there with oil and currency, and it's difficult to predict the next month, let alone the remainder of the year. What I love about our portfolio right now is we're growing the way we should in o
componenttext: Sure, David. So obviously it's pretty dynamic environment out there with oil and currency, and it's difficult to predict the next month, let alone the remainder of the year. What I love about our portfolio right now is we're growing the way we should in our specialties. We drive a lot of strong volume growth, a lot of mix improvements through innovation in Advanced Materials. We did a great job of holding onto value and as in functional products. So we feel good about that, and we feel great about the cost reductions coming through as we expected. But what we're not seeing right now, as we expected in January, is the improvement in olefin spreads. Oil certainly gone up, as we all know, to $45, but we're not seeing sort of the olefin prices recover in the way we would have expected especially on the ethylene side. So it should have been more in the low 30% -- $0.30 range, and we'll get spot down to $0.25. So that's really the main issue, Dave. There's some increasing activity with currencies. Currencies and just about FX translation, it includes how people use that improved cost structure to pursue volume unsuccessfully I might add, but they give it a good shot, and that put some price pressure in the marketplace that you have to respond. So we're seeing a little bit out here and there, but principally, it's an olefins issue. Overall, though, I feel very much on track with our strategy and how we're going to create earnings growth especially as I look at it from '16 through '17 and beyond. And the one interesting upside that's coming out of all this is we're finding customers highly motivated to find innovation these days because we're all living in a tough world, and so we're seeing tremendous engagement even from Asian customers looking on how to innovate value add their product portfolio. So we're really starting to see some acceleration on that front, which is great to see.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, and just on Fibers, Mark, destocking, when do you think we'll end? We'll go into '17? And post destocking ending, what's your net view of long-term secular volume trends in this business?
componenttext: Understood, and just on Fibers, Mark, destocking, when do you think we'll end? We'll go into '17? And post destocking ending, what's your net view of long-term secular volume trends in this business?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I'll break it down both from a cigarette demand point of view and a tow point of view. So on the cigarette side, we see primary demand being very consistent with our views we've shared in all the previous calls. Outside of China sort of down 1% t
componenttext: Sure. So I'll break it down both from a cigarette demand point of view and a tow point of view. So on the cigarette side, we see primary demand being very consistent with our views we've shared in all the previous calls. Outside of China sort of down 1% to 2% like it's been for years. Inside China, we're still not seeing any signs that there's some significant change in primary consumption of cigarettes I call it sort of flat, maybe up 1%,but there's some uncertainty here in the short term is the economic pressure in China could affect people's rate of purchasing cigarettes. But overall, I would say it's very stable, especially when you think inside China that the Chinese National Tobacco Company principal goal is to grow tax revenue. They are assigned a target to grow at stated China GDP around 6.5%, 7%. They've never missed their target ever from what I know. So I think we should expect stability there when it comes to primary demand. So then you get back to what's going on in destocking and what we see is at the tow level, the Chinese National Tobacco Company has set a pretty aggressive destocking target for tow this year, and you have to remember that demand dropped last year, and this year is a function of 2 things. The first driver is CNTC backward integrating with us in '14, with Daicel in '15, and so certain amount of import demand was just replaced by internal production inside China. That's actually a little bit bigger driver than the stocking relative to primary demand, and so you've got that happening plus they've built up too much tow inventory in their imports as they did this backward integration, and so now they're pulling the inventory down. Their target puts it to a very low level. So I think that destocking will be complete. So now we're really looking at what other decisions do they make around cigarette inventory in the marketplace in between tow and primary demand. That's very opaque. We think they're making good progress on that, and they've got this mandate to keep on growing. So I think the vast majority of the destocking should be behind us, but I'm not going to forecast inventory of cigarettes in China.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more about last quarter, you mentioned that on specialty side of the house, you're worried about sort of the spread opened up and you're actively sort of stepping out and trying to partner with your customers in trying to find a
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about last quarter, you mentioned that on specialty side of the house, you're worried about sort of the spread opened up and you're actively sort of stepping out and trying to partner with your customers in trying to find a spread that would be conducive to both of you being happy and sort of remove the risk that the customers were kind of come in and try to reformulate -- a competitor reformulate away from you. Can you talk a little bit about where you are in that process? And do we know how to layout over the balance of the year or not?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you described the situation pretty well. I'm not sure I need to say anything else, but that's exactly what we've been doing to get. In Advanced Materials, we've been growing through volume and mix, and spreads have been relatively stable whe
componenttext: Well, I think you described the situation pretty well. I'm not sure I need to say anything else, but that's exactly what we've been doing to get. In Advanced Materials, we've been growing through volume and mix, and spreads have been relatively stable when it comes to raw materials, and so that is a volume mix story and how we're improving the margins there and how we're growing deliver results. So I would take that off the table, and we feel very, very stable about how we're going to grow there. AFP, as you saw prices came off a bit in the first quarter, and what we did last year and on a restated basis if you look at Additives & Functional Products last year from '14 to '15, prices were only down about 3%. So we had a great success last year in holding onto value through the beginning half of last year really through the third quarter, expanding our margins and tremendous growth earnings as you can now see in Additives & Functional Products and our specialty businesses from '14 to '15. So we started giving some of that value back and sharing the value of raw materials with our customer in the fourth quarter last year through the first quarter this year, which is the right thing to do. It's the way you create value because in the end of the day what you all want is as to grow long term not just short-term earnings, and you've got to have market share and more importantly, you've got have customers that are motivated and engaged with you to work on innovation for the next generation of products. And I think we're walking that balance as carefully as we can. And margins, I would expect, will normalize around sort of what you're seeing in the first quarter, and I think that's what we'll see for the rest of the year. So I think that business is doing well, and there's always the choice to hold prices high, be aggressive and deliver greater earnings relative to raws in the short term, but sooner or later, you're setting yourself up for volume fall and certainly lack of innovation in that portfolio if you do that because customers are very motivated when they can see how much your raw materials have improved to work with you. So we're not going to make that choice. I think that's in the stake, and I'm proud of how the team's walking that balance. It's not easy in a tough environment. We're pushing hard for earnings growth everyday, but I think that's going to work out well for us long term.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just quickly I heard your comments in your prepared remarks about still expecting to repurchase shares in the back half of the year. You didn't mention M&A at all. Landscape out there is changing a little bit with different companies splitting of
componenttext: And then just quickly I heard your comments in your prepared remarks about still expecting to repurchase shares in the back half of the year. You didn't mention M&A at all. Landscape out there is changing a little bit with different companies splitting off and spinning off and things like that the valuations are still high, but any change in your view on M&A?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the M&A front, we're certainly not looking at any large M&A. I view the valuations of assets trading lately as very high, and we struggle to see how I'd be delivering a good return on invested capital to our investors. So I think we're staying away fro
componenttext: On the M&A front, we're certainly not looking at any large M&A. I view the valuations of assets trading lately as very high, and we struggle to see how I'd be delivering a good return on invested capital to our investors. So I think we're staying away from that. Bolt-on M&A is always something that you'll consider when it's reinforcing an existing business to improve its competitive position it relevance to consumers, customers. But right now, even there, we're not really looking at anything in the short term. So I think that as you think about our very strong free cash flow that's outstanding for this industry, you should think about it we're supporting increasing dividends and repurchasing shares after we finished the delevering.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: This is Ryan Berney on for Bob Koort. Back to cash flow question. Would you say M&A kind of large-scale M&A kind of off the table is an investment-grade credit rating still a high priority for you? And is that going to be a significant use of your cash flow proceeds? Or has your kind of thinking shifting more towards returning cash to shareholders?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what you've seen from us and continue to see from us is disciplined and balanced across all the buckets of where we can deploy our cash. So Mark already addressed M&A as well as the share repurchases. From an investment-grade standpoint, yes, we are
componenttext: Well, what you've seen from us and continue to see from us is disciplined and balanced across all the buckets of where we can deploy our cash. So Mark already addressed M&A as well as the share repurchases. From an investment-grade standpoint, yes, we are committed to our investment-grade credit rating, and we'll continue to take actions necessary to maintain that credit rating, but I think you will see balanced use of our cash flow going into 2017.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Well, if you look at synergies, in 2015, we achieved roughly $25 million. For 2016, we expect that to be roughly $50 million of cost and operational synergies as well as some additional tax synergies, and you're seeing this tax synergy showing up in our effective tax rate.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: This is Jagan sitting in for Aleksey. So question in Advanced Materials, could you provide a little more color your comments between volume and mix? What products are you or maybe even regions do you see mix upgrade versus volume?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question, let me answer that one. Advanced Materials rocking it again this year, building on a great year last year, incredibly proud of that team driving innovation across the portfolio. So we're seeing strong growth in Tritan as we've seen for sev
componenttext: Great question, let me answer that one. Advanced Materials rocking it again this year, building on a great year last year, incredibly proud of that team driving innovation across the portfolio. So we're seeing strong growth in Tritan as we've seen for several years now growing in housewares, seeing some early and very encouraging wins around medical, and that's going to continue. Also, continued great success in our new displays products growing with mobile devices delivering very attractive margins as well as growth. Interlayers is just having another phenomenal year building on top of last year in addition to OEM growth rate, which has clearly been pretty good around the world especially in North America and Europe. We're seeing a significant increase in our real estate of the cars moving from the windshields to the sidelines to the sunroofs as they're adding more not just laminated glass but particularly acoustic laminated glass to quiet the cabin for better rider experience, and so we're seeing great engagement there. In fact, when I was with a key customer glass customer in Japan last week, it was very exciting to hear about how much they're looking forward to our next-gen acoustics and heads-up display products. We added a lot of value to this industry already. We've got a new acoustic product that's going to allow them to lightweight the glass, maybe take as much as 25% of the weight of the glass out, which is a big deal, and we've got a far superior heads-up display product coming out as well that's going to dramatically increase size and clarity, allowing a lot of mobility to be added of information to the car for the whole new Internet of Things trend in the car. So a lot of engagement, a lot of innovation there, so great success. And then even in performance films, we've rolled out a very successful new channel strategy in performance films, where we're growing especially in North America, bringing a lot more people into the category, seeing the value proposition of greater solar ejections, skin protection from skin cancer as well as aesthetics and securities. So just all fronts are doing really well right now really excited about what those teams are getting done.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: We do. We see -- we always can be tight OEM growth rate, to some extent, that business is about 75% OEM, 25% replacement, where offered transportation, by the way, that is functional products in the reverse, 25% OEM, 75% replacement. So we're going to be tight OEM growth rate, to some degree, but I think that the ability to go into real estate and most overtly a value of mix, where we are selling much higher margin acoustic and heads-up display products at a much higher rate than the OEM growth rate allows us to continue to grow earnings.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A question on your Additives & Functional Products. Your prices dropped 8%. Now some of these products like coatings additives, I know you're at low prices to your customers. So what is the range of price declines in this segment? Is Crystex flat? An
componenttext: Yes. A question on your Additives & Functional Products. Your prices dropped 8%. Now some of these products like coatings additives, I know you're at low prices to your customers. So what is the range of price declines in this segment? Is Crystex flat? And some products down double digits? Can you just help us sort through the pricing?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as I said, this is a place where we've had a lot of margin expansion last year relative to raw materials dropping in particular the place where we saw the tightest conditions last year was in adhesives, where we're able to maintain very good plac
componenttext: Sure. So as I said, this is a place where we've had a lot of margin expansion last year relative to raw materials dropping in particular the place where we saw the tightest conditions last year was in adhesives, where we're able to maintain very good place discipline via raws improved, and there's that place where we're giving back some price as the market for some of the products we are moving toward balance versus tight position, and we knew that was coming we told the investors about that for several quarters now and that sort of playing out as expected but that some of the price decline. The other places in the olefin related products the specialty products like our, where we're seeing some prices being shared with our customers as raw materials improved last year, we hold prices fairly well and now we are reducing from prices to share the value with our customers. We are seeing prices come off a bit in the Crystex product as we are growing in that business and defending our share again very much as we expected, but some of the prices coming off there especially in Asia what I would say is quite encouraging about the tires market as we are seeing nice recovery in demand in tires especially in the first quarter here relative to last year, and that market getting back on stable footing and well positioned to deliver some nice volume growth this year. So overall, I'd say price is more or less playing out the way we would expect. It's important that we defend our markets and keep these customers engaged as we work on this next generation of product introductions. Really excited about the Crystex process that we're launching. We've got the retrofit line in Germany up and running that'll improve our cost and enable us to have much superior product and the quantum project's going well. So it's all coming together.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: The way we are seeing hedges as we talked about started the year we did expect some of the propane hedges are rolling off yet the out of conditions got it was all worse, but still when I look across hedging portfolio both currency and propane hedges, the impact of roughly $0.60 a share next year -- last year net is still roughly the same amount of impact that we's are expecting this year.

componenttext: Well, I think what that reflects is the relationship between pricing, raw materials and the value that Mark talked about as well as what you're continuing to see is improved mix. componenttext: The other factor fourth quarter has quite a bit of propane hedge in it, Jeff, first quarter restart. So hedge starts falling into inventory and COGS doesn't come out of inventory until the second quarter. So the biggest delta that you're seeing on the cost side is going from quite a bit of the propane hedge to basically none in the first quarter.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: I'm sorry to focus on commodities, but -- so for the propane hedge this year, is it the case that the first quarter has the smallest amount and the fourth quarter will have the largest amount? componenttext: Well, I'll talk about the hedge. You're right, the hedge impact is the lowest in the first quarter. I'm not sure I'd characterize it as the heaviest in the fourth quarter. It's pretty well weighted across the rest of the quarters as inventory turns, but it's definitely lower in the first quarter.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm almost thinking about asking a question for about Patel [ph] since we're talking about ethylene so much, but with that said, if Mark, if I gave you an Eastman Chemical without exposure to ethylene, how would you change the phrase looking at 2016 versu
componenttext: I'm almost thinking about asking a question for about Patel [ph] since we're talking about ethylene so much, but with that said, if Mark, if I gave you an Eastman Chemical without exposure to ethylene, how would you change the phrase looking at 2016 versus 2015, how would you change the phrase, "driving hard to deliver 2016 EPS approaching 2015?" Would you be confident in saying you'd meet and exceed or exceed? How would you -- how would that change the dynamic of your guidance?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob -- Frank, if you didn't have the sort of olefins dynamic going on that we are going through right now we have earnings growth this year over last year and be locking in our seventh consecutive year of earnings growth. Take it another step further, if
componenttext: Bob -- Frank, if you didn't have the sort of olefins dynamic going on that we are going through right now we have earnings growth this year over last year and be locking in our seventh consecutive year of earnings growth. Take it another step further, if you look at the quality of our properties in our company right now, it's substantially better, right? It's about $0.60 share better if you strip out both the propane hedge and the currency hedge, which I think it is financial activity. So we'd have had, and that will be the same number roughly applied to last year. So we would have very strong earnings last year and very strong earnings this year relative to sort of what you're seeing because of this financial hedging. So that's why we're divesting the bulk ethylene and some of these other associated Chemical Intermediates is to get this while noise of our story because the real story for Eastman's tremendous growth in specialties, tremendous innovation across a wide range of very attractive markets, a very consistent strategy and driving that. And we fundamentally believe in innovation the value it's created for us and are very happy to have our largest integrated asset supporting our specialty, but for these intermediates in the bulk ethylene that we don't need for the specialty strategy, our objective as it has been since 2013 is to get it out of our portfolio. So we can focus on the great successes we're having in our specialties.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I could add. Another way to look at it, Frank, if you look at it a couple of years ago, our excess ethylene contributed about 5% of our overall EBIT as a percentage of revenue. If you look at this year, it's probably going to contribute 11% [ph], so
componenttext: Mark, I could add. Another way to look at it, Frank, if you look at it a couple of years ago, our excess ethylene contributed about 5% of our overall EBIT as a percentage of revenue. If you look at this year, it's probably going to contribute 11% [ph], so that gives you order of magnitude.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. That's very helpful, and in terms of the disposals, the asset disposals you talked about, I love to ask about the potential timing but having Curt being CFO role for 8 years, coming up in 8 years, I know there 0% chance you'd answer that
componenttext: Okay, all right. That's very helpful, and in terms of the disposals, the asset disposals you talked about, I love to ask about the potential timing but having Curt being CFO role for 8 years, coming up in 8 years, I know there 0% chance you'd answer that was something that could actually use. So I'll ask another question. You talked about significantly increasing your our cost-reduction efforts. Can you give us some color there or some quantification as to what's going on there, what are the mile post, what did you achieve in Q1 and beyond besides of the acquisition synergies?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. I'll answer that. I'll answer both your questions. The timing of this effort is we're going to be a disciplined seller, and this is -- but this is a priority for us, but I think it's going to take a greater part of this year to execute that t
componenttext: Sure, Frank. I'll answer that. I'll answer both your questions. The timing of this effort is we're going to be a disciplined seller, and this is -- but this is a priority for us, but I think it's going to take a greater part of this year to execute that transaction. As it relates to cost reductions, know we're continuing the cost-reduction program we discussed last quarter. It's a continued strong drive bar organization to see where we can eliminate waste, take out cost and drive our productivity. So we're making great progress towards our goal of $200 million of productivity gains, and we're going to remain confident that about $100 million of that will drop to the bottom line after we all set back growth spend and related projects in that normal inflation. So we're very much on track with what we started this year with.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we're trying to say is the benefits of it are going to start showing up more the second, third and fourth quarter relative to the first because headcount reductions didn't really complete into the end of February, so that's still flowing
componenttext: Yes, I think what we're trying to say is the benefits of it are going to start showing up more the second, third and fourth quarter relative to the first because headcount reductions didn't really complete into the end of February, so that's still flowing into COGS to flow out of inventory on the manufacturing side, and obviously, the SG&A will show up a little bit faster, but that's what we trying to get at.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Duffy Fischer with Barclays.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your outlook statement, you guys added the phrase kind of increasing competitive pressures. Can you walk through the 3 or 4 SVUs that are most impacted by that? And in your mind, is that a structural change? Or is it just kind of a cyclical change mayb
componenttext: In your outlook statement, you guys added the phrase kind of increasing competitive pressures. Can you walk through the 3 or 4 SVUs that are most impacted by that? And in your mind, is that a structural change? Or is it just kind of a cyclical change maybe around raw materials and some activity there?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of those factors. So we're seeing this in Chemical Intermediates, and it's not surprising that you see those kind of products, and it's really a combination of the world's growing slowly, in particular China is growing slowly and not co
componenttext: It's a combination of those factors. So we're seeing this in Chemical Intermediates, and it's not surprising that you see those kind of products, and it's really a combination of the world's growing slowly, in particular China is growing slowly and not consuming a lot of capacity that they've added for a variety of products that sit in Chemical Intermediates. And so when you combine that excess capacity with low oil environment and some other places, some weakening currencies, you can get competitors chasing volume with their improved cost structure and basically that's what you're seeing. So you see some pressure in olefin-related products in Chemical Intermediates. You see some pressure in asset. So as methanol price gets low, that allows the Asians, particularly the Chinese, to drop their so you can prices, and you have to respond to that as it works its way across the world and even in alkyl amines, we have contracts that track methanol. We have very advantage methanol contract that goes into our cost structure. So it's just like our coal gasification or shale gas position if our competitors have lower methanol price, some of that price come down you're going to get a bit of compression. So that's what you're seeing. I'd say added to that, some pressure in plasticizers. We've been talking about that since 2013, where the Koreans have been dumping their product all over the world since they cannot get it into China anymore. So you see some pressure in a few products like that. There's a few products that I already discussed in the prior question around functional products like adhesives. So we've already addressed that in AFP.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then in tow, pretty divergent numbers between you and your biggest competitors. Now sometimes tow can be lumpy any given quarter should we talk about talk up to that? Or is again there's something special going on there or maybe we'll see
componenttext: Okay, great. And then in tow, pretty divergent numbers between you and your biggest competitors. Now sometimes tow can be lumpy any given quarter should we talk about talk up to that? Or is again there's something special going on there or maybe we'll see continued large variances in the volume and pricing numbers between the 2 of you?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think the answers 2 things. One is it is lumpy. So there are lumpy buying patterns. Careful about trying over interpret any quarter when you're comparing us to our tow peers, but there is also a difference that we've discussed in the past, which is
componenttext: No, I think the answers 2 things. One is it is lumpy. So there are lumpy buying patterns. Careful about trying over interpret any quarter when you're comparing us to our tow peers, but there is also a difference that we've discussed in the past, which is we've been incredibly successful in having a very large share of imports into China that's allowed us to grow our generate cash for shareholders in the past 10 years. Of course, there's the flip side of that now when imports are dropping, we're going to feel the pressure of that more is in our peers with the drop in imports in China. So I'd say you're right there that's sort of a key difference. On a global basis, I think our market shares are very stable, and we certainly have every intention of maintaining our position on a global basis from a share point of view. What I like about Eastman and our long-term future here is we have the lowest cost, largest scale, fully integrated back to coal flake and tow position for the world, and we've got great asset here in flake that allows us to support all of our assets both here, Korea and China and because the integration because of the great value creation we get from our other silos of products and additives products Advanced Materials you also have more capability than anyone else and sort of taking that integrated asset base running. So I'm very confident about long-term position, and we're committed to doing it. So we'll see how it plays out, but I think we're the winner end of this game.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Nils Wallin from CLSA.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Nils Wallin from CLSA.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: With respect to the sale of the olefins business, I'm curious as to how you're thinking about that in terms of potential tax leakage. I would assume that the olefins as it is pretty well depreciated and what your thoughts are would be in terms of doing a
componenttext: With respect to the sale of the olefins business, I'm curious as to how you're thinking about that in terms of potential tax leakage. I would assume that the olefins as it is pretty well depreciated and what your thoughts are would be in terms of doing a spin as opposed to the sale.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we're doing is while it's not only a tax leakage, a lot of broad factors you looking at that we recognize the current market conditions with oil and olefins, but our belief is that any potential strategic buyer will understand the long-term val
componenttext: Well, what we're doing is while it's not only a tax leakage, a lot of broad factors you looking at that we recognize the current market conditions with oil and olefins, but our belief is that any potential strategic buyer will understand the long-term value of olefins produced with these good quality assets, and we look at that way and you know us. We have a talented team at easement knows how to buy and sell businesses. So we'll be disciplined with valuation and patient on time. And if need be, I already mentioned as a priority. As it relates to spin, that's a little tougher one we are not quite sure this would be the scale of an asset that we really would result in value-creating spin, but we're close to -- we're not we are open to all options we are pretty flexible of the other assets in our product is also we do see how this all plays out, and that's why said earlier this will probably take greater part of this year to run this process.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just kind of a follow-up on in terms of the pricing obviously, there's been a lot of discussion around getting some price back to customers to ensure that value to just thinking over the long term over 3 to 5 years, what type of underlying
componenttext: Great. And then just kind of a follow-up on in terms of the pricing obviously, there's been a lot of discussion around getting some price back to customers to ensure that value to just thinking over the long term over 3 to 5 years, what type of underlying price increase do you think you should be able to get for the innovation in your -- of your products in your portfolio?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I think that the innovation always commands nice premium especially if proprietary products like Tritan like our next-gen acoustics and heads-up display products that are going to come out a variety of our cellulosics and other display products. So t
componenttext: Well I think that the innovation always commands nice premium especially if proprietary products like Tritan like our next-gen acoustics and heads-up display products that are going to come out a variety of our cellulosics and other display products. So those are great, but it's even in the places, where you do have some competitors, but we still a dominant strong leader of that space, you've got to have some discipline about how you price relative to your competitors. I feel very confident about our ability to grow value of mix, command very attractive margins. I think we have one of the strongest EBITDA margins industry and have every intention taking them stable as we go forward leveraging our fixed cost as well as mix improvement. So the overall I think we're on the right strategy. As I look beyond this year, doing a lot of adjustments. You have such significant changes in margin, not margin but in oil prices and currency, you're going to get margins flying up and down as you sort of normalizer a stable levels and are going to see that stabilized that's not unique to us. It's going to be true for any company connected to petrochemicals or a global distress, but what I like is as you look beyond this year, we've got a lot of great drivers to deliver growth going forward. So we've got a strong product mix and innovation we've got a cost management that is going to continue to deliver great results. We'll continue being very disciplined in the cost. We've got the hedges rolling off, so that $0.60 a share I mentioned earlier will come back to earnings over the next 2 years, and then you've got a very strong free cash flow that will continue to get better as we go from this year forward, and that was the delevering is completed, you've got repurchasing shares in increasing the dividend. So it all adds up by mean obviously, there's a lot we can control around the economy when it comes to how it's going to play out over long and currency but I like the fact that we have a lot in our control, companies very focused on innovation. Focused on customer engagement, which is the only way you get the to innovate, and that's how we're going to deliver results for our owners.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Jim Sheehan with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

componenttext: When we look at the currency, it's a small percentage of that piece. I would guess -- well, currency's actually normalize if you think about this year versus last year. So I don't see currency as a major driver. You see some of it in the other income line item. So, for example, you see a good variation between this quarter versus last year, but as it relates to our gross margins, currency will not have a dramatic impact this year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and your comments earlier on the tire market picking up. You've got more exposure to commercial vehicles there. Could you just give a little more color? Are you seeing this only in commercial tires? Or is it across the passenger tire space as well?
componenttext: Great, and your comments earlier on the tire market picking up. You've got more exposure to commercial vehicles there. Could you just give a little more color? Are you seeing this only in commercial tires? Or is it across the passenger tire space as well?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's across the market. We're seeing good recovery. Obviously, OEM growth rates are good on the auto side. The replacement business has been solid. The TDR business, the truck business is where we really felt some significant destocking out in China l
componenttext: No, it's across the market. We're seeing good recovery. Obviously, OEM growth rates are good on the auto side. The replacement business has been solid. The TDR business, the truck business is where we really felt some significant destocking out in China last year, which seems to be going behind us now. So you're seeing particularly stronger improvement in demand in the first quarter in Asia for TDR, consistent what I think you're seeing from some of the tire companies. So overall, I'd say it feels really good. I wouldn't say it's going to be strong all year. I think some of this is a restocking event, but we certainly expect solid growth out of the tire industry this year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Laurence Alexander with Jefferies.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. You indicated that innovative new products and that a large part of growth strategy. Just in terms of like, how many new products are we talking about aside from Tritan and acoustic interlayers? Just in terms of scale, w
componenttext: This is Dan Rizzo on for Laurence. You indicated that innovative new products and that a large part of growth strategy. Just in terms of like, how many new products are we talking about aside from Tritan and acoustic interlayers? Just in terms of scale, what's the number?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that raises that interesting question about product numbers. There's a lot of people talk about product introductions, and you have to be very careful in how you compare it relative to our peers because you can count it in very different ways. I thi
componenttext: Well, that raises that interesting question about product numbers. There's a lot of people talk about product introductions, and you have to be very careful in how you compare it relative to our peers because you can count it in very different ways. I think about technology platforms that lead to many customer wins and many applications as opposed to talking about every individual customer application I win. And so we've got great platforms across Advanced Materials. We've got Tritan as you said. We've got a wide range of both cellulosic and some other technology products in the displays industry. As I mentioned, whole portfolio of acoustic and heads-up display products and next generation of performance film product. So basically, where we are, we're introducing new products in Advanced Materials. Functional products, same thing. We are now starting to see in our new polyester coating platform, which is taking the Tritan chemistry on into polyester coatings. That's a huge market when you look at market from auto to industrial to packaging. So tremendous amount of opportunities and wins we expect there. Nice set of portfolios for next-gen on products. The tire resins, next-gen acoustic -- next-gen Crystex products rolling out. So everywhere you go where we're a leader in specialty product, we have multigeneration product plans delivering sustainable growth and sustainable margins into the future, but we're not going to start firming out individual product wins because I find those numbers not to make a lot of sense that I've seen in some other places.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could add, Mark. I appreciate people patience let me go off script earlier because what I like about it is there are multiple innovation programs, and we mentioned in our last call in January provided that slide, where we would provide 1% to 2% of re
componenttext: If I could add, Mark. I appreciate people patience let me go off script earlier because what I like about it is there are multiple innovation programs, and we mentioned in our last call in January provided that slide, where we would provide 1% to 2% of revenue growth above our normal revenue growth in GDP because of just the different programs we have, the progress we're making and as we the discipline that we go through stage gaining, I'm convinced that we going to see above-company average margins come off those that 1% to 2% revenue growth.

componenttext: I can tell you we have 1,500 wins, but what does that mean? What it means tangible results in earnings coming from programs that you can see as we move forward.

componenttext: Mark, I wanted to gauge your sentiment into -- from your guidance from the last quarter into this quarter, the specialty chemical side as your Specialty business seen to become a little bit better. So I mean, are you effectively saying that your specialty businesses are doing better in terms of your part of your guidance for this year? And then you're tougher business is like Fibers in Chemical Intermediates doing worse?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I think that's directionally correct. So certainly Advanced Materials doing better than we expected, delivering great growth the way you want to do it through volume and mix. I would say Additives & Functional Products is coming in as expected. So n
componenttext: Mike, I think that's directionally correct. So certainly Advanced Materials doing better than we expected, delivering great growth the way you want to do it through volume and mix. I would say Additives & Functional Products is coming in as expected. So no surprises there. Sort of solid volume growth prices coming off a bit from last year as we knew that would occur. Fibers coming in as we expected, maybe slightly lower than where I thought in January but not materially. And then yes, the challenge's in Chemicals Intermediates with all the dynamics we discussed.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't sort of take the first quarter year-over-year improvement and apply it to the rest of the year. That would be impressive but too much. Basically, it's sort of the opposite of last year. So last year, we have a lot of the destocking going on in
componenttext: I wouldn't sort of take the first quarter year-over-year improvement and apply it to the rest of the year. That would be impressive but too much. Basically, it's sort of the opposite of last year. So last year, we have a lot of the destocking going on in the first quarter as people were trying to hold out for better prices. So volume wasn't that strong, and then we had both the cost finally started flowing through the reduced oil benefits last year into the second quarter as well as very strong volumes second quarter. When you look at this second quarter, it's still going to be a strong sequential improvement versus first quarter but not quite as strong on a year-over-year basis for the reasons I just said. And so overall, I think you should expect a very good year for Advanced Materials delivering a lot of strong earnings growth, probably not quite as strong as last year on a 14 to 15 basis, but still a very, very good year.
