componenttext: We will take our next question from Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Chemical Intermediates, you referenced a few products that you said sort of had come into oversupply and sort of exacerbating the pricing issue with the energy costs. I'm just curious, when you look at those supply-and-demand balances, as we get into '
componenttext: In Chemical Intermediates, you referenced a few products that you said sort of had come into oversupply and sort of exacerbating the pricing issue with the energy costs. I'm just curious, when you look at those supply-and-demand balances, as we get into '17 and into '18, is there incremental capacity coming in those products? Or are we going to see the worst of that S&D balance this year, and as demand grows over the next couple of years, things should tighten up a bit? How is that going to play out?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. From what we see right now, we think the price pressure is upon us based on those capacities. I don't think we see any increase in those pressures in any significant way. There is incremental capacity being brought on always in these kind
componenttext: Great question. From what we see right now, we think the price pressure is upon us based on those capacities. I don't think we see any increase in those pressures in any significant way. There is incremental capacity being brought on always in these kind of products, but unfortunately, the prices are now down to what I think is cash cost for the different relevant Asian players that we face. So we've sort of reached the bottom as long as oil stays in the sort of $40 range. Obviously, if oil drops to into the $20s, you're going to see additional pressure.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if oil goes up, we'll get benefits as well.
componenttext: And if oil goes up, we'll get benefits as well.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if oil goes up, as many expect, that would be a tailwind for us next year.
componenttext: Yes. And if oil goes up, as many expect, that would be a tailwind for us next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in general, in terms of where your pricing is now relative to the raws, it was something you brought up at 4Q and obviously has been playing out through the year, do you think your -- the pricing conversations that you've had with cust
componenttext: Okay. And then just in general, in terms of where your pricing is now relative to the raws, it was something you brought up at 4Q and obviously has been playing out through the year, do you think your -- the pricing conversations that you've had with customers in terms of where spreads have gone, I mean, do you think things are also balanced now as we head into the second half?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. From what we can see, pricing has stabilized, and that's our view right now in the back half of the year. The big question's going to be, how do all the moving parts on olefins change? They're bouncing around a lot even in July. You've seen pr
componenttext: I think so. From what we can see, pricing has stabilized, and that's our view right now in the back half of the year. The big question's going to be, how do all the moving parts on olefins change? They're bouncing around a lot even in July. You've seen propane costs be anywhere from $0.52 to $0.43 depending on the day. So there's just a lot of volatility there. But right now, as Frank asked earlier, we're assuming conditions stay pretty challenging like they were in the second quarter and continue that way for the rest of the year. If it gets better, we'll do better, but it's really hard to predict right now.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Aleksey Yefremov from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Aleksey Yefremov from Nomura Securities.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your Advanced Materials, you averaged about 5.5% volume growth in the first half. Is this about the level that we can expect from the second half? And also, what is sort of organic growth going forward in the segment?
componenttext: In your Advanced Materials, you averaged about 5.5% volume growth in the first half. Is this about the level that we can expect from the second half? And also, what is sort of organic growth going forward in the segment?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Advanced Materials is just a phenomenal success story for us last year and this year, and what I love about it is what you just highlighted. It's a volume and mix-driven story. It's not some temporary expansion on price relative to raws. So we feel g
componenttext: Yes. Advanced Materials is just a phenomenal success story for us last year and this year, and what I love about it is what you just highlighted. It's a volume and mix-driven story. It's not some temporary expansion on price relative to raws. So we feel great about how we're building on last year's tremendous growth this year. And we do expect volume growth to continue in a similar level in the second half of this year, and we'd expect volume growth to continue into next year. But it's really important to highlight, it's not about the absolute volume growth; it's all about the mix. So while we're having double-digit growth in really high-margin, great, innovative products like acoustic interlayers, heads-up display, Tritan, our whole performance films business, our core copolyesters are growing slower than that average that have lower margins. And so you're really getting a great mix improvement every quarter on top of just good overall solid volume growth.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could, Alex, the margins you're seeing from the businesses are the kind of margins you would expect given the investments we made with this business.
componenttext: And if I could, Alex, the margins you're seeing from the businesses are the kind of margins you would expect given the investments we made with this business.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe back to Fibers. How far down this road of price cuts is the industry for committing 2017 contracts? Is there still time you think to sort of -- for the industry to pull up and be more rational? Or I guess, in other words, has there been signific
componenttext: And maybe back to Fibers. How far down this road of price cuts is the industry for committing 2017 contracts? Is there still time you think to sort of -- for the industry to pull up and be more rational? Or I guess, in other words, has there been significant volume committed at lower prices for 2017?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say where we are, the customers were quite smart in sensing that the industry had excess capacity. It's been a great industry for 10 years of consistent earnings growth for us and incremental improvements in margins. Over the last 5 years, we've been
componenttext: I'd say where we are, the customers were quite smart in sensing that the industry had excess capacity. It's been a great industry for 10 years of consistent earnings growth for us and incremental improvements in margins. Over the last 5 years, we've been increasing price. And with the excess capacity, I think customers are smart, and they sensed an opportunity, and they started contract discussions early to see what kind of price improvements they could get. And some people responded, and we're defending. And so I think that that's -- that horse has left the barn as far as 2017 goes. We're going to see prices come down at our large customers. But I do think that the positive side of this story is they also put a high value on stability and security of supply and are looking for long-term commitments in contracts with suppliers that are committed to being in the industry for the long term. And we stand out as the most committed given our integration and scale, so that, I think, will work well for us as we try to maintain our market share position. But -- and so these long-term contracts, if this is the way it continues to play out, will also provide needed stability for our customers on price and supply, and of course, it also helps us provide stability to us, too.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question comes from Jim Sheehan from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.
componenttext: Our last question comes from Jim Sheehan from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the tow business, do you see any opportunities for strategic combinations or joint ventures? Or would antitrust issues preclude anything like that as being a possibility?
componenttext: In the tow business, do you see any opportunities for strategic combinations or joint ventures? Or would antitrust issues preclude anything like that as being a possibility?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've looked at it for ourself, of course. And given we're the largest merchant tow supplier in the industry, it's unlikely we could do anything. I think in a flat to declining industry, you can make a case for consolidation and get it approved wh
componenttext: I think we've looked at it for ourself, of course. And given we're the largest merchant tow supplier in the industry, it's unlikely we could do anything. I think in a flat to declining industry, you can make a case for consolidation and get it approved when a couple other competitors want to come together in theory. Any combination of the other 3 competitors is possible based on our look at it, but it would obviously be a comprehensive process with the antitrust agencies to make sure that there be no harm to customers, but I think it's possible. Whether or not it happens is obviously out of our control, and we'll have to see what our competitors choose to do.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you comment on how your propane hedges roll off next year and how you see propane supply-demand and, just generally, how you see propane factoring into your earnings for 2017?
componenttext: Great. And could you comment on how your propane hedges roll off next year and how you see propane supply-demand and, just generally, how you see propane factoring into your earnings for 2017?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll answer the hedge first. On the hedge, nothing has dramatically changed in our outlook of -- the impact of the hedge is net of the currency. We said that impact's around $0.60 a share, and we think about half of that will still roll off next year.
componenttext: So I'll answer the hedge first. On the hedge, nothing has dramatically changed in our outlook of -- the impact of the hedge is net of the currency. We said that impact's around $0.60 a share, and we think about half of that will still roll off next year. But we'll have to see how propane moves around a little bit, but no, generally speaking, we still expect that benefit next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would note that, that hedge is in that comment, so that's both the propane hedge headwind being rolled off as well as the currency hedge benefits coming on. On the outlook for propane and propylene, because you really -- what really matters is the crack
componenttext: I would note that, that hedge is in that comment, so that's both the propane hedge headwind being rolled off as well as the currency hedge benefits coming on. On the outlook for propane and propylene, because you really -- what really matters is the cracking spread relative to propylene and ethylene, our view is the market is already reconnecting propane to global values with all the export capacity that's readily available in the U.S. So I think you're seeing that now with how propane prices improved through second quarter. And even as oil has come off recently, you've seen propane prices follow it down. So it just depends on your view on oil, and you can get a view of what you think propane's going to do next year. The bigger question is what I already discussed, which is what are ethylene and propylene prices going to do, especially ethylene as they've been stranded and disconnected? I mean, it's really significant when you think about ethylene in Asia in the mid-$0.40 range, and we're in the mid- to high $0.20 range in ethylene times 700 million pounds of ethylene that we sell. And this is our product line. You do the math on whatever you think that delta should be, and you can get to some very large earning numbers that have been a headwind for us relative to what we expected at the beginning of the year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when you think about your portfolio, I think you've done a nice job moving in the right direction, but you still have about 1/3 of it struggling quite a bit here. Does it make sense to look at more acquisitions? And what percent of your portfolio do
componenttext: Mark, when you think about your portfolio, I think you've done a nice job moving in the right direction, but you still have about 1/3 of it struggling quite a bit here. Does it make sense to look at more acquisitions? And what percent of your portfolio do you think you need to be able to offset these headwinds over time? I mean, is it more like an 80%, 90% of your portfolio's specialty? Or what do you think you need to do to get more stable?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Certainly, we're committed to driving our portfolio towards specialty as hard as we possibly can, and you do that through multiple things. We've done, I think, some excellent acquisitions, large ones like Solutia and Taminco and some bolt-on
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. Certainly, we're committed to driving our portfolio towards specialty as hard as we possibly can, and you do that through multiple things. We've done, I think, some excellent acquisitions, large ones like Solutia and Taminco and some bolt-ons as well. And we paid reasonable prices for them and are going to get attractive ROICs relative to where the average cost of capital. So -- and frankly, those acquisitions were intentional. We always knew we had challenges in fibers and olefins at some point in the future. We intentionally chose not to build crackers and PDH units because we were convinced 5 years ago that, that industry would overbuild. And we were intentionally diversifying our portfolio with the strength of the cash that we had at the time in olefins and fibers into more attractive long-term markets where we can innovate. So I think that part of the strategy is great and on track. And of course, we've always been a disciplined seller of underperforming businesses. We've sold off $3.5 billion of revenue from PET to polyolefins, et cetera, in the past, and we're trying to get rid of more of it now in this current process on the bulk ethylene and some other products. So we're doing everything within our control. Unfortunately, I've said this before, we're out of the M&A market as a tool to sort of further diversify our portfolio at this moment in time. I think the valuations are way too high in the market that are being paid right now, 15x anything, it seems. It's hard to get an ROIC at an acceptable level, and we still -- we're old-fashioned that way. We still believe in an unlevered return on capital even if that is close to free. And so we don't think that's value creating for our shareholders. We're not going to do that. What we are going to do is focus on innovation and driving innovative growth across our portfolio. We've been doing it for a long time as heritage Eastman, and we're showing you excellent proof points about how we're doing it in the acquisitions, from interlayers to Crystex to performance films, and/or starting to accelerate somewhat great opportunities in Taminco now that we've got under the hood there. So we're going to do that. We're going to take out cost as much as we possibly can but not cut our innovation programs. That's a core choice for us. And as Curt mentioned, we've got one of the best free cash flows in the industry, and we'll be repurchasing shares as aggressively as we can but also maintaining our credit rating.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then Advanced Materials has been a bright spot this year. Operating income's up 14% in the first half. You mentioned that should grow double digits in '16. Will you have double-digit growth in the second half of '16? And if so, what do you thin
componenttext: Great. And then Advanced Materials has been a bright spot this year. Operating income's up 14% in the first half. You mentioned that should grow double digits in '16. Will you have double-digit growth in the second half of '16? And if so, what do you think will drive that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're going to continue that rate of growth through the rest of the year. And it's volume and mix. It's just the continuation of the story we've been delivering for a long time.
componenttext: Yes, I think we're going to continue that rate of growth through the rest of the year. And it's volume and mix. It's just the continuation of the story we've been delivering for a long time.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you remind me how much is your pension funding this year? And I would imagine your pension liabilities will grow given the interest rates -- interest rate environment that we're in. And so do you have any sort of guesstimate for how your pension fundi
componenttext: Can you remind me how much is your pension funding this year? And I would imagine your pension liabilities will grow given the interest rates -- interest rate environment that we're in. And so do you have any sort of guesstimate for how your pension funding might change next year or in future years?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll -- Jeff, I'll answer those in reverse order if you don't mind. First of all, we do anticipate lower discount rates. And so if you just give $0.01 for every 25 bps that the discount rate lowers in 2016, that's roughly a $50 million increase in our
componenttext: So I'll -- Jeff, I'll answer those in reverse order if you don't mind. First of all, we do anticipate lower discount rates. And so if you just give $0.01 for every 25 bps that the discount rate lowers in 2016, that's roughly a $50 million increase in our liability for our pensions; if you expand that globally, about $90 million. And so if you take current discount rates, that's probably about a 75, 80 bps decline. So you're looking at maybe a couple hundred million increase in your pension liability. But it's only July, so we'll see what the next 5 months hold. As it relates to pension funding, we contributed about $100 million last year. I suspect it'll between $50 million to $75 million this year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then for my follow-up, in the additives and functional area, can you remind me which product lines are growing in volume and which ones are shrinking?
componenttext: Great. And then for my follow-up, in the additives and functional area, can you remind me which product lines are growing in volume and which ones are shrinking?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. So overall, the segment net had a 2% volume growth for the second quarter. And what we're seeing is very strong growth in tire additives, especially Crystex, great recovery there, and we're doing really well in -- with our customers across the
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. So overall, the segment net had a 2% volume growth for the second quarter. And what we're seeing is very strong growth in tire additives, especially Crystex, great recovery there, and we're doing really well in -- with our customers across the globe there. And then antidumping tariffs on tires is really helping us out as we have a stronger position outside of China, and we're benefiting from that shift to the U.S. Coatings are growing with the market, consistent with our customers. And as you think about adhesives, it's also -- has modest growth. All of that success is being offset, to some degree, by decline in energy markets, which has been double digit. We have some products that go downhaul into that space and industrial construction, which is where our fluids go. And so we're obviously seeing a pretty drop in the construction cycle in China when it comes to chemical plants, and demand is off there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, just want to connect 2 of the responses earlier. The comments around 8% to 10% growth next year, do you need the areas in the more -- in your intermediates business to stabilize for that to happen or you see enough levers that you ca
componenttext: Two questions. First, just want to connect 2 of the responses earlier. The comments around 8% to 10% growth next year, do you need the areas in the more -- in your intermediates business to stabilize for that to happen or you see enough levers that you can get to 8% even if the current pressures spill over into next year and the bottoming-out process is pushed out?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're assuming that the world stays similar to the way it is today. So oil stays in the $40s, economy continues to grow slowly, and there's a modest improvement in oil prices next year relative to this year but not anything material. And with those c
componenttext: Yes. We're assuming that the world stays similar to the way it is today. So oil stays in the $40s, economy continues to grow slowly, and there's a modest improvement in oil prices next year relative to this year but not anything material. And with those conditions, we believe Chemical Intermediates can grow earnings over this year. You have to remember that you got a net $0.30 a share tailwind with the hedge; when we back out currency, that's $0.40 of propane hedges coming off and a $0.10 headwind in currency, net $0.30. And a lot of that tailwind flows into Chemical Intermediates, 80% roughly. So you've got that tailwind, and you've got what we think is a bottoming-out situation right now in pricing and behavior by our competitors. And so we're not assuming some dramatic recovery next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could add, that's -- don't forget, we've also announced the additional cost actions because given the challenges of Fibers potentially being down 10% to 20% next year, we didn't want to sit idle. And so have taken the additional cost actions, plu
componenttext: And if I could add, that's -- don't forget, we've also announced the additional cost actions because given the challenges of Fibers potentially being down 10% to 20% next year, we didn't want to sit idle. And so have taken the additional cost actions, plus we expect good, strong free cash flow next year and the ability to deploy that in a balanced way across debt and share repurchases.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And secondly, if and when energy markets recover, what do you see as the lag effect for your business to recover? And is your operating leverage in any way diminished by the cost-out actions you've taken?
componenttext: And secondly, if and when energy markets recover, what do you see as the lag effect for your business to recover? And is your operating leverage in any way diminished by the cost-out actions you've taken?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The cost actions certainly don't diminish anything. We are very committed to innovation. The only way we actually deliver long-term growth, long-term margins for our shareholders is innovate. That's true, I think, of any company in this industry. If you d
componenttext: The cost actions certainly don't diminish anything. We are very committed to innovation. The only way we actually deliver long-term growth, long-term margins for our shareholders is innovate. That's true, I think, of any company in this industry. If you don't innovate, your products get commoditized. That's just a fact of life. So our cost reductions are not -- we have a very bright line where we're not going to cross that, but we are going to put our -- push our cost reductions to the limit. And I'd also note, we are already very low-cost, and we already stretched our functional scale capability tremendously with the large number of acquisitions we've done. So we feel good about where we are, but you can always push for more, and that's what we're going to do. When it comes to the overall market dynamics, as we go into next year, I think we're set up well to grow our businesses through volume and mix in the specialties and hold our margins. And I think in Chemical Intermediates, the situation, we hope, is stabilizing as long as oil doesn't take another big step down.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from P.J. Juvekar of Citigroup.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, you talked about C2 chain being weak. I have a question on C3 chain. Propylene prices are generally stable in second quarter, around $0.30. Are the propylene derivatives still falling? Or have you seen some stabilization? And can you just talk gener
componenttext: Mark, you talked about C2 chain being weak. I have a question on C3 chain. Propylene prices are generally stable in second quarter, around $0.30. Are the propylene derivatives still falling? Or have you seen some stabilization? And can you just talk generally about the C3 chain?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the C3 chain -- I think we've talked about it to some degree already, which is propylene prices seem to have stabilized right now, but they're not improving as oil improved as much as propane did. So you've seen some compression in that sprea
componenttext: Yes. I think the C3 chain -- I think we've talked about it to some degree already, which is propylene prices seem to have stabilized right now, but they're not improving as oil improved as much as propane did. So you've seen some compression in that spread. And if you look at it, year-over-year, obviously, there's tremendous compression in propylene-to-propane spread versus a year ago in the second quarter as well as how we view the next couple of quarters. But I think that, over time, it will go back to a more normal relationship. Propylene is a little bit artificially depressed by all the excess supply of PDH out there. But end of the day, propylene price is going to get set out of Asia, particularly probably China, and it's going to either be PDH, methanol or olefins or naphtha. All of them are connected to oil. So once we get enough derivative capacity out there to turn all this propylene into something, I think you start getting back to some more normal relationships of propylene to propane with where oil turns out to be.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about your portfolio transformation. A lot of investors are saying the portfolio is a bit too complicated for them to understand. I know you're divesting ethylene, but the longer this transformation takes, your multiple is getting impacted in t
componenttext: You talked about your portfolio transformation. A lot of investors are saying the portfolio is a bit too complicated for them to understand. I know you're divesting ethylene, but the longer this transformation takes, your multiple is getting impacted in the meantime. So can you give us a sense of timing on what you're thinking about this transformation? And when do you think you can sort of say that you've done it?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So roughly this year, 2/3 of earnings will come from AM and AFP, which is a dramatic change if you look at who we are today versus 5 years ago. So I think we've made huge progress on altering our portfolio, and it was intentional, as I said. Obvious
componenttext: Sure. So roughly this year, 2/3 of earnings will come from AM and AFP, which is a dramatic change if you look at who we are today versus 5 years ago. So I think we've made huge progress on altering our portfolio, and it was intentional, as I said. Obviously, we didn't expect the accelerated pressure in Fibers and Chemical Intermediates we're experiencing at the moment. So I thought I'll have a lot more time to sort of grow the specialties relative to those 2 segments. But I do think we're doing everything we can, and we're cutting costs aggressively to offset the margin compression we're facing in Fibers and CI as much as we can. And I think oil will recover to some degree at some point, and that'll give us a big tailwind relative to some of these businesses. So I think this is a really tough year for us obviously, not happy about it. We're doing everything we can on every front to make it as good as possible. But right now, we got to organically grow. We got to divest what we can and return share to -- returning cash to shareholders. And I think that is going to be a compelling story if you look at how we can perform in that context relative to this year going forward and relative to, I think, many of our peers. So we're on the right track. We just got to keep driving it.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Duffy Fischer from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Duffy Fischer from Barclays.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Three questions on tow if I could. First is, you talk about being low cost, which I think everybody would grant you, but bigger question is, how steep do you think the cost curve is? So you guys versus, say, the plant that sits at the 90th percentile of t
componenttext: Three questions on tow if I could. First is, you talk about being low cost, which I think everybody would grant you, but bigger question is, how steep do you think the cost curve is? So you guys versus, say, the plant that sits at the 90th percentile of the cost curve, how big is that delta? Second question would be, how much has the low methanol prices changed the cost dynamic for your competitors and therefore the dynamics in tow? And then the last one is, selling half of your JV back to Solvay, on the surface of it, giving a smaller competitor more capacity doesn't seem logical. So could you walk through the logic of doing that deal?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first 2. Curt will take the last one. So in regards to the shape of the curve, we are definitely the lowest-cost player. And to answer your question, the curve has flattened out a bit because while we're based on coal, our competitors are
componenttext: So I'll take the first 2. Curt will take the last one. So in regards to the shape of the curve, we are definitely the lowest-cost player. And to answer your question, the curve has flattened out a bit because while we're based on coal, our competitors are based on natural gas and methanol, that drives our cost structure. And certainly, those prices have come down. So in this year, it's feeling a little bit sort of flattened out relative to the past. As you look forward, coal's going to probably stay pretty low in the U.S., and natural gas prices are already moving up, and methanol prices will certainly move up with oil as well. So I think the curve is actually going to steepen relative to us from this year going forward is our view of sort of how that cost curve's changed and is going to go back to being steeper as we move forward. I'm not going to get into details of the steepness of the curve. What I can tell you, though, is there's plenty of high-cost assets out there that are discrete stand-alone assets. And if someone wanted to improve their earnings and their cost position to serve their customers, that's a choice that they have to work through.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the flake joint venture, as you know, we enjoyed the benefits of that flake joint venture for a number of years. A good partner, a good asset, but given our debottlenecking of our own low-cost flake assets and the shutdown of Workington, we're not bala
componenttext: On the flake joint venture, as you know, we enjoyed the benefits of that flake joint venture for a number of years. A good partner, a good asset, but given our debottlenecking of our own low-cost flake assets and the shutdown of Workington, we're not balanced. So we didn't need that capacity out of that joint venture. So really, we agreed to sell our share to that joint venture. I think it's a good outcome for both parties because we'd be able to match our flake to what our tow demand -- tow capacity is around the world. It gives them a low-cost tow -- sorry, flake asset. I assume that gives them some options to think about, but you need to ask them about that.

componenttext: Guys, in the Chemical Intermediates, I mean, pretty, pretty jarring result to nearly make no money. I'm just curious, if you look across that portfolio, it seems like there's several businesses that should be reasonably good. So are there some reasonable lossmakers in there at the moment?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bob, I mean, I think we've called out ethylene enough. And obviously, that one's pretty challenged in the current economic situation. It's also important to keep in mind that, while we're certainly not happy about the hedge with low oil, that the margi
componenttext: So Bob, I mean, I think we've called out ethylene enough. And obviously, that one's pretty challenged in the current economic situation. It's also important to keep in mind that, while we're certainly not happy about the hedge with low oil, that the margins in this business will probably be double if you extract the hedge out of this segment. So it's certainly not good, and we're not happy about it, but if you look at operating earnings before financing activity, it's quite a bit better and will, by that reason, get better as the hedge rolls off over the next 2 years. But certainly, we're under pressure in bulk ethylene. That's only the sort of one that is sort of in a challenged situation. The others are just much lower margins than what we'd like it to be. And as I said, plasticizers is an example of the place that's under a lot of pressure, hence, our antidumping case.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. I mean, again, we have no unique -- we're just a buyer of propane in the marketplace, same with ethylene. We have a certain slate products mix in the crackers. There's some flexibility, but you have some limitations there. Longer term, if
componenttext: No, not really. I mean, again, we have no unique -- we're just a buyer of propane in the marketplace, same with ethylene. We have a certain slate products mix in the crackers. There's some flexibility, but you have some limitations there. Longer term, if there's a party interested in our crackers, there is amount of capital you could deploy to make that more ethylene based. And that's the kind of conversations we're having with people interested in our excess ethylene position today.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm just going to make one final comment and let Greg wrap up. While we're certainly not happy with our performance in the second quarter and revising guidance down for this year, I think that we are extremely happy with our strategy and what we're try
componenttext: So I'm just going to make one final comment and let Greg wrap up. While we're certainly not happy with our performance in the second quarter and revising guidance down for this year, I think that we are extremely happy with our strategy and what we're trying to do. For a long time, we've known that we should be growing our specialties, both innovative ways as well as acquisitions. And we're doing that, and it's improved the quality of our portfolio and the strength of this company dramatically from where we were 5 years ago. And we're going to continue doing that. We're also going to do everything we can to reduce costs to offset these short-term challenges, being responsible for delivering value for our shareholders, both in the short and the long term at the same time. So you're going to see us drive the execution as hard as we can. You're going to see us push results as hard as we can in this very tough environment. And we feel good about our way to fight our way through this and deliver growth next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com. We'll now turn the call over to Mr. Gr

Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com. 
We'll now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Company Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ron. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Board Chair and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations. Before we begin, I'll c
componenttext:
Thank you, Ron. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Board Chair and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations. 
Before we begin, I'll cover 2 items. First, during this presentation, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations. Actual events or results could differ materially. Certain factors related to future expectations are or will be detailed in the company's third quarter 2016 financial results news release and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Form 10-Q filed for second quarter 2016 and the Form 10-Q to be filed for third quarter 2016. 
Second, earnings per share and operating earnings referenced in this presentation excludes certain noncore costs, charges and gains. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and other associated disclosures, including a description of the excluded items, are available in the third quarter 2016 financial results news release. You could find this on our website at www.eastman.com in the Investors section. Projection of future earnings also exclude any noncore, unusual or nonrecurring items. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. I'll begin my comments by reviewing our strategic highlights for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016. We continue to upgrade the quality of our product mix by growing high-margin specialty produc
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. I'll begin my comments by reviewing our strategic highlights for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016. We continue to upgrade the quality of our product mix by growing high-margin specialty product lines, the key component of our winning strategy. And I have increasing confidence about the breadth and depth of our innovation portfolio, which is significantly more compelling today than it was 3 years ago. 
One of our recent innovation successes is within our tire resins platform in the Additives & Functional Products segment. Tire manufacturers face a significant challenge in improving fuel efficiency while maintaining traction safety. Eastman is quickly -- uniquely qualified to meet this challenge. We are the world leader in resin technology chemistry, and I'm pleased to report that we have gained commercial approval with a major tire producer for 2 new proprietary products and are in the process of sampling a full range of resins with selected innovation partners. 
So far this year, the tire resins platform has delivered approximately 20% volume growth over 2015, with margins above the corporate average. This is a great example of revenue synergy from Solutia acquisition, combining a strong market-connected application development capability with our resin technology platform. 
Moving next to our capital projects to support our specialty growth. We are leveraging our unique innovation capabilities and investing for long-term growth where it counts. From Tritan to interlayers to Crystex, we're the world leader in both process technology and product offerings and are winning through our innovation platforms. We're walking the talk with our investments in growth in  specialty products and seeing the results. 
We are, therefore, driving hard to complete these capital projects to support our growth. All 3 of these projects are on target to finish on or well below budget, which demonstrates our competitive advantage through best-in-class engineering, construction and operational capabilities. In a slow-growth world, we are creating our own growth and investing capital smartly. 
We also proved we can drive innovation while managing costs aggressively. We remain well on track with our cost-reduction efforts to deliver $100 million to the bottom line in 2016 without sacrificing our investment in long-term growth initiatives. These efforts include implementation of hundreds of projects across our global footprint. 
One example is the successful initiative recently completed by our process control team. We were able to utilize a plant loader program associated with our larger -- largest cracker in Longview, Texas. The initiative increased feed efficiency, saving almost $2 million in costs. This is a great example of how our significant scale and integration in our 2 largest sites provide us a unique competitive advantage, where we have dedicated experts in a wide range of specialized operational disciplines. 
We also leverage these experts across the globe to optimize performance in the smaller manufacturing sites from our acquisitions to our sites we've had for a long time. In addition, we remain on track to execute our second cost-reduction initiative this quarter, which we expect will deliver an additional $100 million to the bottom line in 2017. 
Productivity is a core capability to Eastman. Over the past 5 years, we removed almost $700 million in costs to offset inflation and deliver results to the bottom line while maintaining our commitment to quality, reliability and safety. We are continuing to innovate throughout our enterprise, on product development and how we think about manufacturing and our approach to productivity across all our functions. All of these areas will contribute to our strong growth going forward. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Curt to discuss corporate and segment results.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with our third quarter results on Slide 4. Overall sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower selling prices and lower Fibers sales volumes more than offsetting higher sales volume in all othe
componenttext:
Good. Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with our third quarter results on Slide 4. Overall sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower selling prices and lower Fibers sales volumes more than offsetting higher sales volume in all other segments. 
Our operating earnings declined as an increase in Advanced Materials was more than offset by declines in the other segments. Despite the business -- challenging business environment, our operating margin was above 18%. Adjusted earnings per share was $1.86 for the quarter as actions we took led to both operating earnings and taxes coming in better than expected. 
Moving next to the segment results and starting with Advanced Materials on Slide 5, which delivered another quarter of impressive growth driven by our innovation platforms. Third quarter sales revenue increased due to double-digit volume growth of premium products. Eastman Tritan copolyester once again had a record volume quarter as we continue to lead in consumer durables and housewares. 
Saflex acoustic interlayers continued their strong growth this year as applications have expanded to more windows -- from the windows to the side windows and the sunroof as well as expanded to more models. And performance films volumes were strong this quarter due to an excellent new channel strategy in North America and China. The volume and mix improvement was partially offset by lower selling prices, primarily for core copolyesters attributed to lower raw material costs. 
Operating earnings were up 22% or $25 million, primarily driven by higher sales volume and improved product mix of premium products as well as lower unit costs due to higher capacity utilization. Operating margins for the quarter increased by approximately 350 basis points to over 22%. 
As we look ahead to the fourth quarter, we are expecting normal seasonal decline in volume. With that said, we expect Advanced Materials will deliver low double-digit earnings growth for the full year of 2016 and anticipate this business can deliver -- continue to deliver strong growth again in 2017. We are delivering compelling proof of our ability to drive growth through innovation even in a difficult macro environment. 
Now to Additives & Functional Products on Slide 6. Sales revenue declined primarily due to lower selling prices attributed to lower raw material costs, partially offset by higher sales volume. Operating earnings decreased primarily due to lower selling prices more than offsetting lower raw material costs and higher sales volume. And the operating margin remained solid at over 21%. For full year 2016, we continue to expect higher volumes and expect prices to have mostly stabilized. 
One other item that I thought would be useful as you analyze this segment this year. We have been operating under a new organizational structure for a couple of quarters now, which, if you recall, was some major product moves between Additives & Functional Products and Chemical Intermediates. As we analyze how resources and costs are flowing, that's coming out a little different than expected in our historical recast. 
As you consider year-over-year comps, about $20 million more costs are flowing through Additives & Functional Products in 2016 than what was reflected in the $660 million recasted view for them in 2015 while approximately $20 million less is flowing to Chemical Intermediates. Putting it all together, Additives & Functional Products remains on track with our previous expectations for full year earnings to be somewhat down, which would be a solid result in the current business climate. And as pricing stabilizes, we expect solid earnings growth next year through market volume growth and our innovation effort. 
Now to Fibers on Slide 7. Third quarter revenue, volume and earnings were in line with our expectations. Sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower sales volume and lower selling prices particularly for acetate tow. Lower acetate tow sales volume was primarily due to reduced sales into China. Operating earnings declined due to lower sales volume. The lower selling prices were offset by recent actions we took to reduce raw material costs and actions to reduce operating costs. As a result, operating margins held at approximately 32%. 
Our full year outlook has not changed as we continue to expect second half earnings to be similar to first half, which includes tow volumes being down approximately 10% for the year. I'll also mention that we continued contract negotiations for 2017 and anticipate earnings for the segment to be down roughly 20% next year. We remain confident in our long-term position and strongly believe that Fibers will continue to be a valuable business for Eastman going forward. 
I'll finish up the segment review with Chemical Intermediates on Slide 8. Sales revenue decreased due to lower selling prices. We attributed these lower selling prices to continued competitive pressures due to lower oil prices and weak demand in Asia Pacific. Operating earnings declined primarily due to lower selling prices more than offsetting lower raw material and energy costs and lower hedge costs. During the quarter, we saw some modest improvement in the overall business environment impacting Chemical Intermediates and now expecting earnings in the back half of the year to be slightly higher than the first half, and we expect this improvement to continue into next year. 
Lastly, I'll give you a quick update on our process for divesting our excess ethylene capacity and potentially certain commodity olefin product lines. We continue our discussions with potential partners or parties and now anticipate this process will carry into next year, though I'll add that executing a transaction in this current environment remains challenging. 
On Slide 9, I'll transition to an overview of our cash flows or other financial highlights for the second quarter (sic) [ third quarter ]. We continue to do an excellent job of generating cash with third quarter operating cash flow of $450 million. We contributed $50 million to our U.S. pension plans in the quarter. Capital expenditures totaled $141 million. We continue to manage the pace of capital spending with the current economic environment while maintaining growth investments and continue to expect full year capital expenditures to be between $600 million and $625 million. 
Free cash flow for the quarter was a strong $309 million. And during the quarter, we reduced net debt by over $160 million, paid our second quarter dividend of $68 million and repurchased $75 million of our shares. Through 9 months of 2016, we have reduced debt by $400 million and returned almost $325 million to our stockholders. 
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was just over 21% as we are benefiting from foreign tax credits and other positive tax attributes. We expect our full year tax rate will be between 22% and 23%, which is better than previous expectations, reflecting the continued benefits of our improved -- improvement in business operations. We continue to look for every opportunity to reduce costs, including taxes, from both an earnings and cash flow standpoint. This quarter was another great example of our tax team finding such opportunities, including amending previously filed tax returns.  And lastly, we remain on track to generate more than $900 million of free cash flow for this year, which is a very strong performance in the current environment. 
With that, I'll turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Curt. On Page 10, we've talked a lot about the benefits of our portfolio transformation and how that contributes to more consistent earnings growth and strong free cash flow generation. You can see that our portfolio transformation has been a key
componenttext:
Thanks, Curt. On Page 10, we've talked a lot about the benefits of our portfolio transformation and how that contributes to more consistent earnings growth and strong free cash flow generation. You can see that our portfolio transformation has been a key element to delivering strong earnings for quite some time. 
Over the last 6 years, we have taken decisive actions to improve our portfolio through acquiring attractive specialty businesses and divesting underperforming businesses. And we acquired these specialty companies at reasonable valuations with very attractive synergies that we've delivered. Organically, we have grown our volume and, more importantly, upgraded our mix. This is both within our heritage businesses and within the acquired businesses through great efforts in our innovation programs and through our commercial excellence. 
As a result of these efforts, you can see a very different story from who we were before versus today. We have improved the earnings mix across segments significantly. In 2010, Fibers and Chemical Intermediates were roughly 60% of the corporate earnings. Today, that percentage is closer to 30%. For 2016, we expect that the combination of Advanced Materials and Additives & Functional Products will represent approximately 70% of our earnings. And even in this environment, our EPS CAGR will still be roughly 11% from 2010 to '16. 
We also dramatically improved our free cash flow, almost tripling it from 2010 to 2016. Both improvements in our core businesses and adding the strong free cash flow generation from our acquisitions have substantially upgraded the quality of our portfolio. And we are still investing capital to deliver long-term growth in our specialty businesses while we generate one of the strongest free cash flows in this industry. 
On Slide 11, I'll discuss our 2016 outlook. We're doing a great job of executing our strategy in a challenging global business environment. Strong growth of high-value, innovative products continue as we benefit from leading positions in our attractive niche markets. We're seeing the benefits of scale and integration translating to growth in earnings, and we continue to invest in innovation and product development so that we can sustain our momentum into the coming years. We're also seeing the benefit of acquisition synergies in both costs and revenue. 
At the same time, we're achieving our cost-reduction goals. I can't say enough about how -- our Eastman employees globally who made this possible. As I mentioned earlier, productivity is in the DNA of Eastman, and I remain very confident we will achieve our cost-reduction targets for 2017. In addition, we are using all lines of the income statement to support our performance this year, including lower tax rates. All these actions are helping to offset the challenges from low oil, sluggish global GDP growth and the challenges we face in Fibers. 
Putting all this together, our outlook for adjusted full year 2016 earnings per share has improved to between $6.70 and $6.80, which I consider to be a solid result given our challenges. We also continue to expect strong free cash flow this year above $900 million. And we are creating value for our stakeholders with our balanced and disciplined allocation of this cash, increasing our dividend, increasing share repurchases and continued delevering. 
With this momentum in mind, I'll make a few comments about 2017. On the last call, I indicated we have confidence that we can get back on track for EPS growth in the 8% to 12% range in 2017, and we continue to be confident. As we look at it, we expect growth and innovation-driven mix improvement in Advanced Materials and Functional Products cost-reduction actions to contribute about $0.50 per share, the net of propane and currency hedges continued roll off in 2017 to contribute about $0.30 per share, an increase in the level of share repurchases while maintaining a balanced approach with deleveraging and continuing to use all of the lines of the income statement to contribute to EPS growth. These would more than offset the roughly $0.30 per share headwind from Fibers and the preproduction expenses from our new specialty plants. The combination of these factors will get us to EPS growth in the 8% to 12% range. 
I would also note that we don't need the world to get much better to achieve this growth. And if things get better, there is upside. We'll talk to more -- more to you about the outlook for 2017 in our fourth quarter call in January, but I believe it's important now for you to understand why we are confident about delivering strong earnings growth and strong free cash flow in 2017. 
This has been a tough year, and I'm proud of our employees around the world who have maintained focus and positioned us for growth going forward. I'm confident that 2017 will be a better year for Eastman. Most importantly, I believe that we are building one of the world's leading specialty companies to deliver long-term sustainable growth in a world where we -- where you need to create your own growth. 
With that, I'll turn it back over to Greg.

componenttext: Thanks. We'll let Curt handle that question. I just want to add before he does that we're really excited about getting back to this path of earnings growth. We feel great about all the levers in front of us to get there and certainly expect it to improve our cash.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Mark mentioned [ph] earlier, and if I could -- Eastman has one of the best portfolios, I think, that can generate cash in the industry. And you're seeing that in our results, and also, you'll see that next year. We do expect higher free cash flows
componenttext: Yes. As Mark mentioned [ph] earlier, and if I could -- Eastman has one of the best portfolios, I think, that can generate cash in the industry. And you're seeing that in our results, and also, you'll see that next year. We do expect higher free cash flows next year as we see operating earnings growth as well as we'll see a modest decline in our CapEx. A couple of factors to think about when you -- when I'm  looking at 2017 cash flows is we'll be watching what kind of raw material environment we're facing. If we expect higher raws, as you know, that's going to give us some challenges in working capital that we'll try to offset. I also am expecting some higher cash taxes next year as we have now fully utilized the NOLs as part of the Solutia transaction as well as there's a phaseout of bonus depreciation for manufacturers like Eastman. So putting it all together though, we're going to generate over free -- free cash flow over $900 million. With the earnings outlook that Mark talked about, I won't be surprised if we see free cash flow approaching $1 billion. The allocation, what you'll see is still a balance across the different buckets that we have. You know our disciplined and balanced approach to capital allocation. But what you'll see is some more balanced approach to deleveraging and share repurchases with that free cash flow. So if you think about deleveraging, it was the predominant use of cash flow these last couple of years. That will moderate to be more balanced. And so you'll see share repurchase probably in excess of $300 million.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And Mark, just on -- you've seen some price increase announcements in oxos and plasticizers. Can you comment on the cadence of those price increases and how they could contribute to 2017 earnings growth?
componenttext: Excellent. And Mark, just on -- you've seen some price increase announcements in oxos and plasticizers. Can you comment on the cadence of those price increases and how they could contribute to 2017 earnings growth?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. We are seeing a traction in getting price increases in September and into October as the propylene and ethylene markets have strengthened. That put pressure across the globe and played out as we expected in our second quarter call. We saw tha
componenttext: Sure, David. We are seeing a traction in getting price increases in September and into October as the propylene and ethylene markets have strengthened. That put pressure across the globe and played out as we expected in our second quarter call. We saw that our competitors, especially Asians, setting price on a lot of these products on a global basis. We're starting to hit their cost positions. And as oil strengthened and their raw material costs, who are often -- I mean, purchased propylene and ethylene was going up, they would face pressure to increase prices, and that's what we're seeing. So it's very encouraging to actually see prices go up for once. It's been a long time. We do expect that momentum to continue as we go through the fourth quarter and carry into next year. But obviously, that will depend a bit on the raw material environment, so we'll have to see where oil and olefin prices go. But we're happy to see the change in direction and some traction right now.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question, Robert Koort from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question, Robert Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk -- 2 items real quick, an update on how the Kuantan plants are progressing and when you might see some commissioning of those. And then secondly, can you speak a little bit about the volatility you've seen in Advanced Mat
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk -- 2 items real quick, an update on how the Kuantan plants are progressing and when you might see some commissioning of those. And then secondly, can you speak a little bit about the volatility you've seen in Advanced Materials? Obviously, you had a very nice showing again this quarter after a bit of a dip the prior. But what's sort of the path forward and the level of consistency or reduced volatility you might be able to deliver out of that business?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're making great progress on both our Crystex and our PVB plants in Kuantan and driving hard to get those up in the back half of next year. And as I said, they're on track and we're excited. The customers around our new Crystex product that we're p
componenttext: Yes. We're making great progress on both our Crystex and our PVB plants in Kuantan and driving hard to get those up in the back half of next year. And as I said, they're on track and we're excited. The customers around our new Crystex product that we're producing off of this new process technology are very excited, and we're feeling pressure to get that plant up as quickly as we can to serve this new interest in the better-performing product. So -- and the growth rates in there largely has just been fantastic, so we need to get that plant up to keep our growth. In regards to Advanced Materials, they're just having a phenomenal year like they had a phenomenal year last year, and it's really proof of our strategy we have been talking about for the last 5 years. We said we're going to drive growth through innovation, and that's what we're doing. And Tritan and heads-up display and acoustic interlayers and our performance films business, all delivering double-digit growth and driving not just the sort of overall volume growth but the mix upgrade with all those products growing at such high rates with above-segment and above-company average margins. So it's just a good story. It's really -- very little of it is a raw material tailwind in what's driving the results, which gives us confidence that it will sustain going forward. And obviously, third quarter was a quarter where everything just ran pretty well. We've had good volume, good mix, the plants ran incredibly well. One of the challenges in this kind of businesses where making such a physical product is you have yield and quality issues, and we just had clean quarter in how we ran the plants.

componenttext: And we'll go to our next question from Mike Sison from KeyBanc.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, could you help us out a little bit in terms of looking at Additives & Functional Products it's sort of sitting in the specialty area in your bar chart. So earnings are going to be slightly down. Can you kind of parse out, there's a lot of business i
componenttext: Mark, could you help us out a little bit in terms of looking at Additives & Functional Products it's sort of sitting in the specialty area in your bar chart. So earnings are going to be slightly down. Can you kind of parse out, there's a lot of business in there what's growing and may be just kind of highlight the areas that on the specialty business that are showing earnings growth and maybe some of the headwinds, the hedges and stuff kind of impacting that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, this portfolio is a great set of portfolio of specialty businesses, tremendous additives that add a lot of functionality across our customers in coatings, tires, adhesives and crop, et cetera. This is a great business of unique addi
componenttext: Sure. So first of all, this portfolio is a great set of portfolio of specialty businesses, tremendous additives that add a lot of functionality across our customers in coatings, tires, adhesives and crop, et cetera. This is a great business of unique additives. So we view it as a business that will continue to grow. As you look at the pricing, which I think is the key question and how it's come off, prices have really stabilized since the second quarter. So we did a great job of holding onto raw material value in the beginning of last year starting to giving some back in third quarter but really started giving it back in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of this year as we decided to share value with our customers. But those prices have stabilized. We really didn't have much sequential decline in prices at all from second quarter into the third quarter this year, and we expect the same stability as we go into the fourth you. And you'll see that even on the year-over-year basis, January as you see the trends in the fourth quarter. So that feels very stable to us and appropriate, and we expect prices probably to start moving up in the coatings area especially on the olefin-related products. Specialties are a little slower prices on the way down. They're also slower on the way up. So Chemical Intermediates is starting to move on the pricing front, and we expect as we go into next year those prices on the specialty related products also start to move up with these current market conditions. So that all feels directionally correct to me. I think the important point is how you sustain these margins and continue to deliver growth over the long term. It's easy to hold onto prices when raw has dropped, but if you do that too aggressively and not share some of your customers, you really create problem with those customers being engaged in working with you on any future innovation. And I think we've struck the right balance here, and we're seeing that in the proof of our innovation successes. We're just having tremendous success throughout the AFB portfolio with innovation. Our polyester coatings is doing extremely well. We talked to you about that in the first quarter call. We've gone from 3 to 10 customers aggressively working with us on how to commercialize that product and take it to market. We're seeing success with tire resin I just told you about. We're seeing success in Aerafin olefins products I talked about in the second quarter call that go with adhesive resins. We continue to see great traction on our load coalescence. So across the portfolio, you're seeing a lot of innovation, a lot of traction. And as I said before, this is a little bit slower in getting started than Advanced Materials, but as you look at the next 3 years, you'll see all these innovation programs driving growth and mix improvements here just like we're doing in Advanced Materials. We're improving across the board we can deliver growth and innovation. We can create own growth, not waiting for the economy to get better and that's story you're going to see us deliver over the next 3 years.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I know you don't want to be too specific on '17 yet per segment but Additives & Functional Products gross margins next year had just come off, is there any reason why this segment wouldn't participate in showing some good earnings growth n
componenttext: Great. And then I know you don't want to be too specific on '17 yet per segment but Additives & Functional Products gross margins next year had just come off, is there any reason why this segment wouldn't participate in showing some good earnings growth next year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect AFP to show good earnings growth next year is a combination of modest market volume growth. We're not assuming an improving economy next year just to be clear, but we do assume there is an economy growing somewhat. So we'll get some volume growt
componenttext: We expect AFP to show good earnings growth next year is a combination of modest market volume growth. We're not assuming an improving economy next year just to be clear, but we do assume there is an economy growing somewhat. So we'll get some volume growth. We'll get some mix improvements through innovation. We'll certainly see some benefits hedge. Remember 80% of hedge benefits flow to Chemical Intermediates. So it's modest here, and of course, through broader cost management program. Certain amount of that benefit is going to flow into the segment.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, Curt. I have to ask a question, Mark, with respect of fibers and the positioning of the portfolio. 2015, very difficult year. '16, very difficult year. '17, you just changed guidance from 10% to 20% down to now down 20%. As I think about some of
componenttext: Got you, Curt. I have to ask a question, Mark, with respect of fibers and the positioning of the portfolio. 2015, very difficult year. '16, very difficult year. '17, you just changed guidance from 10% to 20% down to now down 20%. As I think about some of the shifting going on there, we used to kind of count on annual sort of contracts with your customers there, but now we're hearing of multiyear contracts. So if you guys are structuring multiyear contracts, are we setting the stage where '18 and '19 are also going to be more difficult years? Can you talk a little bit about the prospects for that business post another difficult year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. We've, obviously, spent time talking about what's going on in the Fibers business from demand trends to competitive behavior, and I think I provide quite long soliloquy on this one in the second quarter call. So I'll try and be sort of brief
componenttext: Sure, Frank. We've, obviously, spent time talking about what's going on in the Fibers business from demand trends to competitive behavior, and I think I provide quite long soliloquy on this one in the second quarter call. So I'll try and be sort of brief on it now. Bottom line is we had a situation where demand situation weakened across the globe specifically the imports in China and that's created pressure on pricing. And what we see right now is that pricing pressure play out into the 2017 timeframe. Our objective is [indiscernible] sort of keep the business stable. That's been our objective from the beginning. We took capacity out in the U.K. as adding capacity in China, and we also exit some capacity as well. On the pricing front, we've attempted to be as stable as it can be on the pricing. Unfortunately, we got pushed aggressively on some of our competitors trying to take share from us outside of China, and all we're trying to do is defend share and keep it stable outside of China. We're not trying to recover lost imports in China by taking share outside of China. And we think the best way to do that is to get multiyear contracts in volume and pricing place with many of our large customers, which will provide stability actually from '17 into '18 and '19 as we provide security of supply to our customers but also provide security of demand to us. I think those actions actually going to put us in the right direction as far as the things that we can do to control the outcome in this industry and our performance, and we'll just have to see how the rest of it plays out.

componenttextpreview: All right. We'll talk about the taxes again. As you know, Jeff, you'll see a lot of what's going on with cash tax rate versus current as what goes through our deferred on the cash flow statement and so you'll see that has improved this year, and again tha
componenttext: All right. We'll talk about the taxes again. As you know, Jeff, you'll see a lot of what's going on with cash tax rate versus current as what goes through our deferred on the cash flow statement and so you'll see that has improved this year, and again that's again a lot of great work that occurs with our tax, finance and legal teams who are looking for ways to really how do we help reduce costs and how do we help cash flows within this company. And so when I look at that going into next year, I do believe that again we won't have the benefits of those NOLs that we enjoyed and mentioned earlier we've utilized all the NOLs since the acquisition in 2012 and so that was at an accelerated pace because of that great work and again the phase out the bonus depreciation. So there's a pretty good opportunity for us to continue to look at our cash tax rate, but it will be more challenging as we go through the next several years.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Fiber demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends where the markets continued to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and
componenttext: On the Fiber demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends where the markets continued to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and opaque question. Right now, we have seen some changes in production rate, where taken it down 6% to 7%, which is great because I think they're destocking primarily with those actions. You have to remember that production rates are not equal to primary consumption rates. We do expect that they had trouble destocking cigarettes in '15 and '16 -- I'm sorry, '15 and '14. So I think encouraged to see them taking actions to finally address that issue like they're already addressing in the tow inventory level as well. So in some ways, I think there's progress to put this behind us. Primary demand...

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So roughly minus 10?
componenttext: So roughly minus 10?

componenttext: Sorry?

componenttext: So roughly your volume growth is minus 10 next year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. That's not what I said. I said this year, we seen cigarette production being reduced in China, and I think that's destocking. As we look at next year, what we hope is they complete their destocking this year and demand at the production level
componenttext: No, no, no. That's not what I said. I said this year, we seen cigarette production being reduced in China, and I think that's destocking. As we look at next year, what we hope is they complete their destocking this year and demand at the production level is stable next year versus this year. And that's sort of our assumption at this point. So when you look at next year, I think imports are going to be somewhat stable, can be a bit off as they finish out some destocking at the cigarette level, and we'll just have to see how it plays out.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
