componenttext: Okay. And in terms of taxes, are your cash taxes and book -- how different are your cash taxes and book taxes this year and your expectation for next year? And what do you think your Fibers volume growth rate is in 2017?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, I'll talk about the taxes. Again, as you know, Jeff -- and you can see a lot of what's going on with our cash tax rate versus current as what goes through in our deferred tax line item in the cash flow statement. And so you see that has i
componenttext: All right. Well, I'll talk about the taxes. Again, as you know, Jeff -- and you can see a lot of what's going on with our cash tax rate versus current as what goes through in our deferred tax line item in the cash flow statement. And so you see that has improved this year, and again -- that's, again, a lot of great work that occurs with our tax, finance and legal teams, who are looking for ways to just -- as to really how do we help reduce costs and how do we help cash flows within this company. And so when I look at that going into next year, I do believe -- again, we won't have the benefits of those NOLs from Solutia that we've enjoyed. And in fact, if I didn't mention earlier, we've utilized all the NOLs since the acquisition in 2012, and so that was at an accelerated pace because of that great work. And again, the phaseout of bonus depreciation. So there's a pretty good opportunity for us to continue to look at our cash tax rate, but it will be more challenging as we go over the next several years. On the Fibers...

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Fibers demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends, where the markets continue to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and
componenttext: On the Fibers demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends, where the markets continue to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and opaque question. Right now, we have seen some changes in production rate, cigarette production, where they've taken it down 6% to 7%, which is great because, I think, they're just destocking primarily with those actions. You have to remember that production rates are not equal to primary consumption rates. We do expect  -- they had trouble destocking cigarettes in '15 and '16 -- I'm sorry, '15 and '14. So I think that we're actually encouraged to see them taking actions to finally address that issue like they're already addressing at the tow inventory level as well. So in some ways, I think there's progress to put this behind us. Primary demand in China...

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So roughly minus 10%?
componenttext: So roughly minus 10%?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry?
componenttext: I'm sorry?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So roughly, your volume growth is minus 10% next year?
componenttext: So roughly, your volume growth is minus 10% next year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. It's not what I said. I said that this year, we're seeing cigarette production to be -- being reduced in China, and I think that's destocking. As we look at next year -- what we hope is they complete their destocking this year and demand at th
componenttext: No, no, no. It's not what I said. I said that this year, we're seeing cigarette production to be -- being reduced in China, and I think that's destocking. As we look at next year -- what we hope is they complete their destocking this year and demand at the production level is stable next year versus this year. And that's sort of our assumption at this point. So when you look at next year, I think imports are going to be somewhat stable, that could be a bit off as they finish out some destocking at the cigarette level, and we'll just have to see how it plays out.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from P.J. Juvekar from Citi.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from P.J. Juvekar from Citi.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on Crystex. You seem to be doing a good job on innovation. But the OEM market -- the auto OEM market is slowing. The Class 8 truck market seem to be slowing as well. So can you talk about demand there? And is there any generic competition from
componenttext: A question on Crystex. You seem to be doing a good job on innovation. But the OEM market -- the auto OEM market is slowing. The Class 8 truck market seem to be slowing as well. So can you talk about demand there? And is there any generic competition from China coming in?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in auto demand, it sort of impacts us in multiple places. So in Advanced Materials, which is very OEM-driven, we are looking at that. What's been great about our success to date is we're creating a lot of our own earnings growth through mix upgrade and
componenttext: So in auto demand, it sort of impacts us in multiple places. So in Advanced Materials, which is very OEM-driven, we are looking at that. What's been great about our success to date is we're creating a lot of our own earnings growth through mix upgrade and double-digit growth in things like acoustics and heads-up displays as well as a new channel strategy in performance films, where we're growing the whole size of the market and our share of it. So even in a slow automotive growth world, we can still deliver growth. It may not be as high as this year but still deliver growth. So I feel good about where we are there. And we see tremendous innovation opportunities continuing out there to add more functionality to the windows as we work with our customers in the next generation of acoustics and heads-up displays as well as other functionalities. So it's just a very robust opportunity for growth. On the Additives & Functional Products side, when it comes to coatings and tires, we're more balanced there. That's more of a balanced market from refinish or replacement tires than OEM. And so there, we're less exposed to sort of OEM trend rates as we are in Advanced Materials. So I think that, again, we'll have some solid growth there, and I'm not really worried about the OEM trend rates being a material issue.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly, I think, Curt, you mentioned that selling the ethylene business is being difficult in this environment. I would imagine that as we get into second half of '17 and '18  when the new ethylene capacity starts up, that it will be
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly, I think, Curt, you mentioned that selling the ethylene business is being difficult in this environment. I would imagine that as we get into second half of '17 and '18  when the new ethylene capacity starts up, that it will be even more difficult. So can you give us your thoughts about timing of the sale?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The timing of the sale? Sorry, you just were breaking up there.
componenttext: The timing of the sale? Sorry, you just were breaking up there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you're talking about the excess ethylene and the commodity olefins, we continue to have a number of parties actively engaged in the process. As I mentioned, it's been -- continue to be a challenging environment right now to ensure we get fair value
componenttext: So if you're talking about the excess ethylene and the commodity olefins, we continue to have a number of parties actively engaged in the process. As I mentioned, it's been -- continue to be a challenging environment right now to ensure we get fair value for those kind of assets. And what I'll say, it's been further compounded by having a competing asset coming into the marketplace. So we'll just be disciplined with valuation and patient on timing as needed. And so I could have mentioned, this is -- going to next year, I can't give you a good sense of next year other than I would suspect first half of the year feels about right, that we'll have better progress on the different options that we have. And again, we're not just sitting idle. We'll look and see if an outright sale is possible, but we'll continue to evaluate other options or structures and pursue them as appropriate as well.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the one thing you should take from us is we're committed to improving the quality of our portfolio and the stability of our earnings. We -- before it became a trend, we were already divesting a lot of underperforming volatile businesses and have d
componenttext: I mean, the one thing you should take from us is we're committed to improving the quality of our portfolio and the stability of our earnings. We -- before it became a trend, we were already divesting a lot of underperforming volatile businesses and have done a lot of portfolio transformation, as we noted earlier. And we'll continue to look at every way we can do it as practical. But at the end of the day, we're going to focus on shareholder value creation and make sure what we do creates value.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, your Advanced Materials operating margins were up 350 basis points year-over-year. It looks like they were up actually a little bit more than that versus the first quarter. How sustainable is the current level?
componenttext: Mark, your Advanced Materials operating margins were up 350 basis points year-over-year. It looks like they were up actually a little bit more than that versus the first quarter. How sustainable is the current level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, we feel good about the margins we have in this business. As I said, we are running incredibly well through the third quarter and did this through volume and mix, which we generally view as a very sustainable way to grow earnings over the long term.
componenttext: Kevin, we feel good about the margins we have in this business. As I said, we are running incredibly well through the third quarter and did this through volume and mix, which we generally view as a very sustainable way to grow earnings over the long term. It was a clean quarter. So there's always some quarters where you're going to have some quality issues and things like that, but I think the margins are sustainable. I would note that the fourth quarter always does have a seasonal decline in volumes, and so those margins are always going to be a little bit lower on a fourth quarter basis versus the third.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a follow-up. I think in your prepared remarks, you mentioned performance films had a new channel strategy. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.
componenttext: And a follow-up. I think in your prepared remarks, you mentioned performance films had a new channel strategy. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. One of the great things about this business is it's a consumer products business, where we have direct access to consumers and deliver a wide range of products and we have the best products in the industry. But when we picked up Solutia, their strat
componenttext: Sure. One of the great things about this business is it's a consumer products business, where we have direct access to consumers and deliver a wide range of products and we have the best products in the industry. But when we picked up Solutia, their strategy of how to go to market and how to even expand the market was not that sophisticated. And so we spent a lot of time rethinking our channel strategies and figuring out how to not just go through aftermarket retail shops but develop much more compelling programs through auto dealers in the U.S., which allows us to access an entirely new set of customers that don't show up in an aftermarket tin shop, and have been incredibly successful in expanding the market and also improving the quality of how we go to market. Same thing true in China. We were doing quite well aftermarket, not as successful in the auto dealerships and had significantly improved our channel strategy to go through the auto dealerships, which is a very important channel in China, and we're seeing great success. And it's not just going to those channels but how we take the products to market, how we're positioning our value proposition versus our competitors in a more compelling way. It's just been a great story of determined improvement of our go-to-market strategy over the last 3 years.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions, one on the Fibers market. Can you give a sense for how steep you think the underlying cost curve is? I'm thinking particularly where -- like where you see sort of the marginal -- the smallest, most marginal producers. And secondly, as yo
componenttext: Just 2 questions, one on the Fibers market. Can you give a sense for how steep you think the underlying cost curve is? I'm thinking particularly where -- like where you see sort of the marginal -- the smallest, most marginal producers. And secondly, as you look out over, say, the next 3 to 5 years, are there any large chunks that would -- of nonoperating expense that would affect the free cash flow bridge, either maintenance turnarounds or facilities where you need to do another CapEx cycle or pension contributions or anything else that you see like on a 3- to 5-year horizon?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the cost curve side, there is certainly high- and low-cost assets in the integrated flake and tow components of the Fibers business. As I've said in the past, we are the lowest-cost producer. We're backward integrating coal. We have the larges
componenttext: Sure. So on the cost curve side, there is certainly high- and low-cost assets in the integrated flake and tow components of the Fibers business. As I've said in the past, we are the lowest-cost producer. We're backward integrating coal. We have the largest scale, and we're actually now down to our largest, most integrated asset as our only asset here in Tennessee at flake, which is matched to our tow capacity here in Tennessee with -- combined with our Korean tow capacity and China. So we're very happy about our cost position. Our competitors are based on either purchased methanol or anhydride in some cases, so some of these assets are certainly exposed to much higher cost position. They picked up some advantage with lower oil today versus where they were. As oil goes up, that cost position is going to become less competitive relative to where we are. There are a number of high-cost assets out there that can be shut down by competitors, if they ever choose to do so, to improve their cost position to serve their customers, and we're going to have to see what they choose to do. As the market stabilizes, as we put in stability through these multiyear contracts, it's -- it becomes more challenging to figure out how you're going to grow earnings growth, and hopefully, they'll look at those options.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the operating cash flows and some things you mentioned, Laurence, when I look at 2 or 3 areas, first of all, in pension, we talked about contributing about $50 million to $75 million of pension this year. That's still what we're anticipating. Over the
componenttext: On the operating cash flows and some things you mentioned, Laurence, when I look at 2 or 3 areas, first of all, in pension, we talked about contributing about $50 million to $75 million of pension this year. That's still what we're anticipating. Over the next couple of years, I'm looking at maybe roughly $75 million of pension contributions over the next couple of years. After that point, you kind of have to really look at what discount rates have done and how the returns have come in, whether that number needs to increase to $100 million or maybe come down to $50 million. But that kind of gives you a band of what pension contributions could be like over the next 3 to 5 years. On capital, when you got the kind of assets we have, I guess, every 3 to 5 years, there's going to be turnarounds. What we have -- we do and we have a great team that does it, we try to manage the capital -- maintenance spend and capital spend we have each year. Part of it's not only cash flow, part of it's just resources. So yes, we're going to have some capital spend over these years. But some of the unique items that we've had these last few years, like the -- some of the assets that we had to build in Texas as well as conversions to -- from natural -- coal to natural gas. There's a little bit ahead of us, but most of it's done. So I suspect our maintenance capital will be in that $300 million to $350 million range over that 5-year time period, and then we'll have growth capital on top of it to support all the attractive innovation programs that Mark talked about. So I think those are the main 2 things you're looking out there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: No. Right now, I'd say the currencies we're seeing today is kind of what we anticipate going into next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And some of your coatings customers are experiencing some headwinds now. Can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of downstream coatings demand and whether you're feeling the same pressures?
componenttext: Great. And some of your coatings customers are experiencing some headwinds now. Can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of downstream coatings demand and whether you're feeling the same pressures?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Since January, we've always assumed a very slow economic growth world, and we never assumed that the economy was going to improve. So this sort of 1% to 2% volume range is sort of where we've been and what we've assumed, and so there's no real change in o
componenttext: Since January, we've always assumed a very slow economic growth world, and we never assumed that the economy was going to improve. So this sort of 1% to 2% volume range is sort of where we've been and what we've assumed, and so there's no real change in our forecast. Based on some of the comments I've seen by a number of customers, it sounds like what they're talking about is they expected stronger growth and now they're sort of moderating back to this slower growth expectation. If that's the case, we're already there in our forecasting, and there wouldn't be any challenges for us. The risk though, of course, is if they've been planning and assuming higher growth, do they have some destocking issues that they have to address in the fourth quarter. We have no evidence from any of our customers that, that's happening yet, but that's something we'll have to keep an eye on.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go to our next question from John Roberts from UBS.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of the lower tax rate in the quarter was adjustments from prior period tax returns? And how much was just geographic mix in the current period?
componenttext: How much of the lower tax rate in the quarter was adjustments from prior period tax returns? And how much was just geographic mix in the current period?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the tax rate, let me just make one comment. In any particular tax year, you're going to have discrete items, such as the one you're asking about specifically. It was a $60 million benefit from better utilizations of foreign tax credits f
componenttext: So if you look at the tax rate, let me just make one comment. In any particular tax year, you're going to have discrete items, such as the one you're asking about specifically. It was a $60 million benefit from better utilizations of foreign tax credits from the Solutia acquisition that we recognized in the third quarter. That was related to amended returns that we were able to put in place. But I would add, these discrete items can vary each year for a variety of reasons, the results of audits, submitting [ph] returns, et cetera. Again, I'm going to say it twice because they deserve it. We have a great tax, finance and legal team that knows how to manage these as best we can in any given year. I also value -- it hasn't been asked yet, but I know we'd anticipate it. It's a little early for the effective tax rate for '17, but let me go and throw it out there. When I look at the things we put in place, there are some permanent improvements that we've seen with the actions that we've taken. So I think our effective tax rate for next year will improve, and I think it'll be more in the 23% to 24% range.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good. I didn't have to use up my second question. Are there non-Fiber applications for cellulosic resins that could use up some of the excess polymer capacity to help rebalance the cig tow market? Or should we think about the use of polymer for fib
componenttext: That's good. I didn't have to use up my second question. Are there non-Fiber applications for cellulosic resins that could use up some of the excess polymer capacity to help rebalance the cig tow market? Or should we think about the use of polymer for fiber as distinct from other applications?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent question, and I'm glad you asked it. There are other applications. So as we saw in 2014 that growth was going to start slowing down in tow demand associated with cigarettes, we started up a team to aggressively look at how to develop new market
componenttext: Excellent question, and I'm glad you asked it. There are other applications. So as we saw in 2014 that growth was going to start slowing down in tow demand associated with cigarettes, we started up a team to aggressively look at how to develop new market applications around cellulosics, and we're making tremendous progress on how to sort of reuse these assets in the new market applications. Something to keep in mind about Eastman is that we have a 90-year history of innovating when it comes to cellulosics. We started out with film, we then went into yarn, then we went into tow, then we went into plastics for things like tool handles and sunglass frames and then we took cellulosic technology into coating additives, then TVs and now into tires as another new emerging application. We know how to innovate in this space. We've done a lot more of this innovation than anyone else has ever done in creating new markets, just like we've done in polyesters, starting with polyester fiber to PET to a wide range of polyester applications. So we know how to do this. And so we're making great progress. We're not going to get into the specific products right now because we are having great success in moving this forward and we're still locking up IP. But these assets can make other products that go into other applications, and you'll hear a lot more about that next year. It's what we do and are very good at doing.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, it's been referenced that perhaps there could be portfolio options for the divestitures, not all that different from what you've done over the years. Any updated thoughts on that beyond the cracker?
componenttext: In the past, it's been referenced that perhaps there could be portfolio options for the divestitures, not all that different from what you've done over the years. Any updated thoughts on that beyond the cracker?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to -- no. I mean, our focus right now has been the excess ethylene and the commodity olefin product lines. We continue to look at the rest of the portfolio to see if there's opportunities that maybe there's a more natural owner. We do that in
componenttext: We continue to -- no. I mean, our focus right now has been the excess ethylene and the commodity olefin product lines. We continue to look at the rest of the portfolio to see if there's opportunities that maybe there's a more natural owner. We do that in due course with our board, and at this point, there's nothing that we're talking about specifically. But we'll continue to evaluate different things in our portfolio. We like the portfolio as a whole, so it's really stuff on the margin.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we've been on this journey of optimizing our portfolio for a long time, right? I mean, we've sold off $3.5 billion of revenue from underperforming businesses. We've done acquisitions, adding $4.2 billion of revenue, specialty businesses. And by th
componenttext: I mean, we've been on this journey of optimizing our portfolio for a long time, right? I mean, we've sold off $3.5 billion of revenue from underperforming businesses. We've done acquisitions, adding $4.2 billion of revenue, specialty businesses. And by the way, we paid 9x EBITDA for those specialty business with 7x EBITDA multiples to have synergies -- to provide attractive synergies as well as reasonable ROICs above cost of capital for our investors. So I feel great about the actions we've taken in improving our portfolio, and we're certainly committed to keeping that momentum going. But I don't think there's any big, large changes that we need to make, both on the acquisition side or on significant divestiture side. We're going to continue to look at these opportunities, like the ethylene, as ways to take out pockets of volatility, but our focus and our strategy is about innovation and growth. We're driving innovation and growth. We're managing costs aggressively. We're going to continue to create value in a capital-efficient way because we're doing mix upgrades of existing assets in how we drive this innovation. We're going to generate a lot of free cash flow and buy back stock and increase the dividend and improve our balance sheet. I think it's a compelling story as it is.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on capacity utilization levels. You might have mentioned this earlier, but I needed to hop off for a second. In Advanced Materials, you talked about how part of the margin improvement was being able to run at a higher utilizatio
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on capacity utilization levels. You might have mentioned this earlier, but I needed to hop off for a second. In Advanced Materials, you talked about how part of the margin improvement was being able to run at a higher utilization level. Is there -- as volume grows into next year, is that a benefit that we should continue to see? Or are you sort of now at a new tranche of profitability at this utilization level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to dramatically improve our profitability from where we are at this stage, but I do think we're going to continue driving double-digit earnings growth going forward as we grow volume, mix and manage cost. But even here, we've got
componenttext: I don't think we're going to dramatically improve our profitability from where we are at this stage, but I do think we're going to continue driving double-digit earnings growth going forward as we grow volume, mix and manage cost. But even here, we've got Tritan expansion going on. We'll have to bring on a new chunk of capacity next year to support this incredible growth we're having with Tritan with the existing products, and I should mention we also have new products that we're making off of the same chemistry to access even more addressable market than where we are today with Tritan. And so we add new capacity, they add some chunk --- chunks of cost you got to work your way through.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Vince, if I could just add. What that -- as you add those chunks of capacity, as you transition to that, you will have some startup costs next year, and that will be some challenges for this business. But again, they'll still deliver that double-digit
componenttext: And Vince, if I could just add. What that -- as you add those chunks of capacity, as you transition to that, you will have some startup costs next year, and that will be some challenges for this business. But again, they'll still deliver that double-digit earnings growth despite that, and you need that capacity then to grow past '18 and beyond.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For tire resins, it's a great opportunity. The tire resins historically have just been used as a processing aid, and now we have this whole new addressable market in the tread as a performance additive improving traction in the tire. We're seeing tremendo
componenttext: For tire resins, it's a great opportunity. The tire resins historically have just been used as a processing aid, and now we have this whole new addressable market in the tread as a performance additive improving traction in the tire. We're seeing tremendous adoption and interest across tire companies across the globe, and we really seem to be the preferred innovation partner because we have the broadest set of chemistry. So we're still trying to understand the full potential of this market. We're not going to complain about the 20% growth rate. Obviously, it's off of a relatively small number. But we see it as a significant market that could easily be $100 million, $200 million of additional revenue.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Great. And in the tow business, the 20% expected decline in profitability next year, how would you attribute it to volume versus price?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, we have a strategy of defending our share outside of China. So we're not expecting it to be a volume-driven story outside of China. It's going to be a price-driven story. In the China side of it, there's a lot of conflicting data about
componenttext: As I said earlier, we have a strategy of defending our share outside of China. So we're not expecting it to be a volume-driven story outside of China. It's going to be a price-driven story. In the China side of it, there's a lot of conflicting data about what's going on with demand and destocking in China, so it's a little hard to know what the imports are going to be next year. And so we're just going to have to see. Right now, we're assuming a modest decline.

componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, good partner, and we're looking forward to that capacity online. Yes, we do -- that will -- what that'll ultimately do, for those that aren't familiar with it, is allow us to -- where we've been purchased propylene, we'll now have addi
componenttext: Well, first of all, good partner, and we're looking forward to that capacity online. Yes, we do -- that will -- what that'll ultimately do, for those that aren't familiar with it, is allow us to -- where we've been purchased propylene, we'll now have additional propylene that's sourced through that propane, and we'll be more sourced with propane than we are today. We used to talk about that benefit was going to be roughly $30 million a year. But where the spreads are today, it's much lower than that, but we're still going to like that contract and that relationship long term.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then in Chemical Intermediates, obviously, there was quite a significant ramp in spot ethylene prices during the quarter, yet there was, you mentioned, some other competitive pressures. So was the benefit from the spot ethylene margins really
componenttext: Got it. And then in Chemical Intermediates, obviously, there was quite a significant ramp in spot ethylene prices during the quarter, yet there was, you mentioned, some other competitive pressures. So was the benefit from the spot ethylene margins really offset by competitive pressures? Or were you just not quite as able to capitalize on that spot price round?

componenttextpreview: No, I think we did a nice job of capturing the ethylene benefits. But you also have to remember our propane and ethane costs also went up considerably in the quarter. So there wasn't a huge expansion in spreads, but it certainly was better than last year
componenttext: No, I think we did a nice job of capturing the ethylene benefits. But you also have to remember our propane and ethane costs also went up considerably in the quarter. So there wasn't a huge expansion in spreads, but it certainly was better than last year and certainly carrying into the fourth quarter in a better state than last year.

componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions on normalized margins. You've held up margins quite well in both Fibers and AM. So on AM, do you think that you'd still be able to grow margins in the next couple of years as you continue to grow volume? And similarly, on Fibers, if you stabilize volume, would fiber margins kind of hold in this level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On AM, the margins are likely to be more stable around these higher levels than further increase. As we mentioned, there's the preproduction expenses, starting of new capacity and the focus on volume growth. So I think it will be stable. When it comes to
componenttext: On AM, the margins are likely to be more stable around these higher levels than further increase. As we mentioned, there's the preproduction expenses, starting of new capacity and the focus on volume growth. So I think it will be stable. When it comes to Fibers, the margins will come off from where we are today with the forecasted drop of earnings of around 20% into next year. It's important to keep in mind the altitude of these margins. This is an exceptionally profitable and attractive business, and even some moderating margins here is still incredibly attractive for any business. So we're going to manage through that and continue to find ways to stabilize it into '18.

Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Eastman Chemical Company Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. This call is being broadcast live on the Eastman's website, www.eastman.com. 
We'll now turn the call over to Mr. Greg Riddle of Eastman Chemical Company Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ron. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Board Chair and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations. Before we begin, I'll c
componenttext:
Thank you, Ron. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. On the call with me today are Mark Costa, Board Chair and CEO; Curt Espeland, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Louis Reavis, Manager, Investor Relations. 
Before we begin, I'll cover 2 items. First, during this presentation, you will hear certain forward-looking statements concerning our plans and expectations. Actual events or results could differ materially. Certain factors related to future expectations are or will be detailed in the company's third quarter 2016 financial results news release and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the Form 10-Q filed for second quarter 2016 and the Form 10-Q to be filed for third quarter 2016. 
Second, earnings per share and operating earnings referenced in this presentation exclude certain noncore costs, charges and gains. A reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures and other associated disclosures, including a description of the excluded items, are available in the third quarter 2016 financial results news release. You could find this on our website at www.eastman.com in the Investors section. Projection of future earnings also exclude any noncore, unusual or nonrecurring items. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. I'll begin my comments by reviewing our strategic highlights for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016. We continue to upgrade the quality of our product mix by growing high-margin specialty produc
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. I'll start on Slide 3. I'll begin my comments by reviewing our strategic highlights for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016. We continue to upgrade the quality of our product mix by growing high-margin specialty product lines, a key component of our winning strategy. And I have increasing confidence about the breadth and depth of our innovation portfolio, which is significantly more compelling today than it was 3 years ago. 
One of our recent innovation successes is within our tire resins platform in the Additives & Functional Products segment. Tire manufacturers face a significant challenge in improving fuel efficiency while maintaining traction safety. Eastman is quickly -- uniquely qualified to meet this challenge. We are the world leader in resin technology chemistry, and I am pleased to report that we have gained commercial approval with a major tire producer for 2 new proprietary products and are in the process of sampling a full range of resins with selected innovation partners. 
So far this year, the tire resins platform has delivered approximately 20% volume growth over 2015, with margins above the corporate average. This is a great example of revenue synergy from Solutia acquisition, combining a strong market-connected application development capability with our resin technology platform. 
Moving next to our capital projects to support our specialty growth. We are leveraging our unique innovation capabilities and investing for long-term growth where it counts. From Tritan to interlayers to Crystex, we're the world leader in both process technology and product offerings and are winning through our innovation platforms. We're walking the talk with our investments in growth in specialty products and seeing the results. 
We are, therefore, driving hard to complete these capital projects to support our growth. All 3 of these projects are on target to finish on or well below budget, which demonstrates our competitive advantage through best-in-class engineering, construction and operational capabilities. In a slow-growth world, we are creating our own growth and investing capital smartly. 
We also are proving we can drive innovation while managing costs aggressively. We remain well on track with our cost-reduction efforts to deliver $100 million to the bottom line in 2016 without sacrificing our investment in long-term growth initiatives. These efforts include implementation of hundreds of projects across our global footprint. 
One example is the successful initiative recently completed by our process control team. We were able to utilize a plant loader program associated with our larger -- largest cracker in Longview, Texas. The initiative increased feed efficiency, saving almost $2 million in costs. This is a great example of how our significant scale and integration in our 2 largest sites provide us a unique competitive advantage, where we have dedicated experts in a wide range of specialized operational disciplines. 
We also leverage these experts across the globe to optimize performance in the smaller manufacturing sites from our acquisitions to our sites we've had for a long time. In addition, we remain on track to execute our second cost-reduction initiative this quarter, which we expect will deliver an additional $100 million to the bottom line in 2017. 
Productivity is a core capability at Eastman. Over the past 5 years, we removed almost $700 million in costs to offset inflation and deliver results to the bottom line while maintaining our commitment to quality, reliability and safety. We are continuing to innovate throughout our enterprise, on product development and how we think about manufacturing and our approach to productivity across all our functions. All of these areas will contribute to our strong growth going forward. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Curt to discuss corporate and segment results.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with our third quarter results on Slide 4. Overall sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower selling prices and lower Fibers sales volumes more than offsetting higher sales volume in all othe
componenttext:
Good. Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with our third quarter results on Slide 4. Overall sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower selling prices and lower Fibers sales volumes more than offsetting higher sales volume in all other segments. 
Our operating earnings declined as an increase in Advanced Materials was more than offset by declines in the other segments. Despite the business -- challenging business environment, our operating margin was above 18%. Adjusted earnings per share was $1.86 for the quarter as actions we took led to both operating earnings and taxes coming in better than expected. 
Moving next to the segment results and starting with Advanced Materials on Slide 5, which delivered another quarter of impressive growth driven by our innovation platforms. Third quarter sales revenue increased due to double-digit volume growth of premium products. Eastman Tritan copolyester once again had a record volume quarter as we continue to lead in consumer durables and housewares. 
Saflex acoustic interlayers continued their strong growth this year as applications have expanded to more windows -- from the windows to the side windows and the sunroof as well as expanded to more models. And performance film volumes were strong this quarter due to an excellent new channel strategy in North America and China. The volume and mix improvement was partially offset by lower selling prices, primarily for core copolyesters attributed to lower raw material costs. 
Operating earnings were up 22% or $25 million, primarily driven by higher sales volume and improved product mix of premium products as well as lower unit costs due to higher capacity utilization. Operating margins for the quarter increased by approximately 350 basis points to over 22%. 
As we look ahead to the fourth quarter, we are expecting normal seasonal decline in volume. With that said, we expect Advanced Materials will deliver low double-digit earnings growth for the full year of 2016 and anticipate this business can deliver -- continue to deliver strong growth again in 2017. We are delivering compelling proof of our ability to drive growth through innovation even in a difficult macro environment. 
Now to Additives & Functional Products on Slide 6. Sales revenue declined primarily due to lower selling prices attributed to lower raw material costs, partially offset by higher sales volume. Operating earnings decreased primarily due to lower selling prices, more than offsetting lower raw material costs and higher sales volume. And the operating margin remained solid at over 21%. For full year 2016, we continue to expect higher volumes and expect prices to have mostly stabilized. 
One other item that I thought would be useful as you analyze this segment this year. We have been operating under a new organizational structure for a couple of quarters now, which, if you recall, was some major product moves between Additives & Functional Products and Chemical Intermediates. As we analyze how resources and costs are flowing, it's coming out a little different than expected in our historical recast. 
As you consider year-over-year comps, about $20 million of more costs are flowing through Additives & Functional Products in 2016 than what was reflected in the $660 million recasted view for them in 2015 while approximately $20 million less is flowing to Chemical Intermediates. Putting it all together, Additives & Functional Products remains on track with our previous expectations for full year earnings to be somewhat down, which would be a solid result in the current business climate. And as pricing stabilizes, we expect solid earnings growth next year through market volume growth and our innovation effort. 
Now to Fibers on Slide 7. Third quarter revenue, volume and earnings were in line with our expectations. Sales revenue decreased primarily due to lower sales volume and lower selling prices particularly for acetate tow. Lower acetate tow sales volume was primarily due to reduced sales into China. Operating earnings declined due to lower sales volume. The lower selling prices were offset by recent actions we took to reduce raw material costs and actions to reduce operating costs. As a result, operating margins held at approximately 32%. 
Our full year outlook has not changed as we continue to expect second half earnings to be similar to first half, which includes tow volumes being down approximately 10% for the year. I'll also mention that we continued contract negotiations for 2017 and anticipate earnings for the segment to be down roughly 20% next year. We remain confident in our long-term position and strongly believe that Fibers will continue to be a valuable business for Eastman going forward. 
I'll finish up the segment review with Chemical Intermediates on Slide 8. Sales revenue decreased due to lower selling prices. We attributed these lower selling prices to continued competitive pressures due to lower oil prices and weak demand in Asia Pacific. Operating earnings declined primarily due to lower selling prices, more than offsetting lower raw material and energy costs and lower hedge costs. During the quarter, we saw some modest improvement in the overall business environment impacting Chemical Intermediates and now expecting earnings in the back half of the year to be slightly higher than the first half, and we expect this improvement to continue into next year. 
Lastly, I'll give you a quick update on our process for divesting our excess ethylene capacity and potentially certain commodity olefin product lines. We continue our discussions with potential partners -- or parties and now anticipate this process will carry into next year, though I'll add that executing a transaction in this current environment remains challenging. 
On Slide 9, I'll transition to an overview of our cash flows or other financial highlights for the second quarter (sic) [ third quarter ]. We continue to do an excellent job of generating cash with third quarter operating cash flow of $450 million. We contributed $50 million to our U.S. pension plans in the quarter. Capital expenditures totaled $141 million. We continue to manage the pace of capital spending with the current economic environment while maintaining growth investments and continue to expect full year capital expenditures to be between $600 million and $625 million. 
Free cash flow for the quarter was a strong $309 million. And during the quarter, we reduced net debt by over $160 million, paid our second quarter dividend of $68 million and repurchased $75 million of our shares. Through 9 months of 2016, we have reduced debt by $400 million and returned almost $325 million to our stockholders. 
Our effective tax rate for the quarter was just over 21% as we are benefiting from foreign tax credits and other positive tax attributes. We expect our full year tax rate will be between 22% and 23%, which is better than previous expectations, reflecting the continued benefits of our improved -- improvement in business operations. We continue to look for every opportunity to reduce costs, including taxes, from both an earnings and cash flow standpoint. This quarter was another great example of our tax team finding such opportunities, including amending previously-filed tax returns.  And lastly, we remain on track to generate more than $900 million of free cash flow for this year, which is a very strong performance in the current environment. 
With that, I'll turn it back over to Mark.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Curt. On Page 10, we've talked a lot about the benefits of our portfolio transformation and how that contributes to more consistent earnings growth and strong free cash flow generation. You can see that our portfolio transformation has been a key
componenttext:
Thanks, Curt. On Page 10, we've talked a lot about the benefits of our portfolio transformation and how that contributes to more consistent earnings growth and strong free cash flow generation. You can see that our portfolio transformation has been a key element to delivering strong earnings for quite some time. 
Over the last 6 years, we have taken decisive actions to improve our portfolio through acquiring attractive specialty businesses and divesting underperforming businesses. And we acquired these specialty companies at reasonable valuations with very attractive synergies that we've delivered. Organically, we have grown our volume and, more importantly, upgraded our mix. This is both within our heritage businesses and within the acquired businesses through great efforts in our innovation programs and through our commercial excellence. 
As a result of these efforts, you can see a very different story from who we were before versus today. We have improved the earnings mix across segments significantly. In 2010, Fibers and Chemical Intermediates were roughly 60% of the corporate earnings. Today, that percentage is closer to 30%. For 2016, we expect that the combination of Advanced Materials and Additives & Functional Products will represent approximately 70% of our earnings. And even in this environment, our EPS CAGR will still be roughly 11% from 2010 to '16. 
We also dramatically improved our free cash flow, almost tripling it from 2010 to 2016. Both improvements in our core businesses and adding the strong free cash flow generation from our acquisitions have substantially upgraded the quality of our portfolio. And we are still investing capital to deliver long-term growth in our specialty businesses while we generate one of the strongest free cash flows in this industry. 
On Slide 11, I'll discuss our 2016 outlook. We're doing a great job of executing our strategy in a challenging global business environment. Strong growth of high-value, innovative products continue as we benefit from leading positions in our attractive niche markets. We're seeing the benefits of scale and integration translating to growth in earnings, and we continue to invest in innovation and product development so that we can sustain our momentum into the coming years. We're also seeing the benefit of acquisition synergies in both costs and revenue. 
At the same time, we're achieving our cost-reduction goals. I can't say enough about how -- our Eastman employees globally who made this possible. As I mentioned earlier, productivity is in the DNA of Eastman, and I remain very confident we will achieve our cost-reduction targets for 2017. In addition, we are using all lines of the income statement to support our performance this year, including lower tax rates. All of these actions are helping to offset the challenges from low oil, sluggish global GDP growth and the challenges we face in Fibers. 
Putting all this together, our outlook for adjusted full year 2016 earnings per share has improved to between $6.70 and $6.80, which I consider to be a solid result given our challenges. We also continue to expect strong free cash flow this year above $900 million. And we are creating value for our stakeholders with our balanced and disciplined allocation of this cash, increasing our dividend, increasing share repurchases and continued delevering. 
With this momentum in mind, I'll make a few comments about 2017. On the last call, I indicated we have confidence that we can get back on track for EPS growth in the 8% to 12% range in 2017, and we continue to be confident. As we look at it, we expect growth and innovation-driven mix improvement in Advanced Materials and Functional Products; cost-reduction actions contribute about $0.50 per share; the net of propane and currency hedges continue to roll off in 2017 to contribute about $0.30 per share; an increase in the level of share repurchases while maintaining a balanced approach with deleveraging; and continuing to use all of the lines of the income statement to contribute to EPS growth. These would more than offset the roughly $0.30 per share headwind from Fibers and the preproduction expenses from our new specialty plants. The combination of these factors will get us to EPS growth in the 8% to 12% range. 
I would also note that we don't need the world to get much better to achieve this growth. And if things get better, there is upside. We'll talk to more -- more to you about the outlook for 2017 in our fourth quarter call in January, but I believe it's important now for you to understand why we are confident about delivering strong earnings growth and strong free cash flow in 2017. 
This has been a tough year, and I'm proud of our employees around the world who have maintained focus and positioned us for growth going forward. I'm confident that 2017 will be a better year for Eastman. Most importantly, I believe that we are building one of the world's leading specialty companies to deliver long-term sustainable growth in a world where we -- where you need to create your own growth. 
With that, I'll turn it back over to Greg.

componenttext: Thanks. I will let Curt handle that question. I just want to add before he does that we're really excited about getting back to this path of earnings growth. We feel great about all the levers in front of us to get there and certainly expect it to improve our cash.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Mark highlighted earlier and if I could, Eastman has one of the best portfolios, I think, that can generate cash in the industry. And you're seeing that in our results, and quite obviously, you'll see that next year. We do expect higher free cash
componenttext: Yes. As Mark highlighted earlier and if I could, Eastman has one of the best portfolios, I think, that can generate cash in the industry. And you're seeing that in our results, and quite obviously, you'll see that next year. We do expect higher free cash flows next year as we see operating earnings grow, as well as we'll see a modest decline in our CapEx. A couple of factors to think about when you -- when I'm looking at 2017 cash flows is we'll be watching what kind of raw material environment we're facing. If we expect higher raws, as you know, that's going to give us some challenges in working capital that we'll try to offset. I also am expecting some higher cash taxes next year as we have now fully utilized the NOLs as part of the Solutia transaction as well as there's a phaseout of bonus depreciation for manufacturers like Eastman. So putting it all together though, we're going to generate over free -- free cash flow over $900 million. With the earnings outlook that Mark talked about, I wouldn't be surprised if we see free cash flow approaching $1 billion. The allocation, what you'll see is still a balance across the different buckets that we have. You know our disciplined and balanced approach to capital allocation. But what you'll see is some more balanced approach to deleveraging and share repurchases with that free cash flow. So if you think about deleveraging, it was the predominant use of cash flow these last couple of years. That will moderate to be more balanced. And so you'll see share repurchase probably in excess of $300 million.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And Mark, just on -- you've seen some price increase announcements in oxos and plasticizers. Can you comment on the cadence of those price increases and how they could contribute to 2017 earnings growth?
componenttext: Excellent. And Mark, just on -- you've seen some price increase announcements in oxos and plasticizers. Can you comment on the cadence of those price increases and how they could contribute to 2017 earnings growth?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. We are seeing a traction in getting price increases in September and into October as the propylene and ethylene markets have strengthened. That put pressure across the globe and played out as we expected in our second quarter call. We saw tha
componenttext: Sure, David. We are seeing a traction in getting price increases in September and into October as the propylene and ethylene markets have strengthened. That put pressure across the globe and played out as we expected in our second quarter call. We saw that our competitors, especially Asians, setting price on a lot of these products on a global basis, were starting to hit their cost positions. And as oil strengthened and their raw material costs, who are often -- I mean, purchase propylene and ethylene was going up, they would face pressure to increase prices, and that's what we're seeing. So it's very encouraging to actually see prices go up for once. It's been a long time. We do expect that momentum to continue as we go through the fourth quarter and carry into next year. But obviously, that will depend a bit on the raw material environment, so we'll have to see where oil and olefin prices go. But we're happy to see the change in direction and some traction right now.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question, Robert Koort from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk -- 2 items real quick, an update on how the Kuantan plants are progressing and when you might see some commissioning of those. And then secondly, can you speak a little bit about the volatility you've seen in Advanced Mat
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk -- 2 items real quick, an update on how the Kuantan plants are progressing and when you might see some commissioning of those. And then secondly, can you speak a little bit about the volatility you've seen in Advanced Materials? Obviously, you had a very nice showing again this quarter after a bit of a dip the prior. But what's sort of the path forward and the level of consistency or reduced volatility you might be able to deliver out of that business?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're making great progress on both our Crystex and our PVB plants in Kuantan and driving hard to get those up in the back half of next year. And as I said, they're on track and we're excited. The customers around our new Crystex product that we're p
componenttext: Yes. We're making great progress on both our Crystex and our PVB plants in Kuantan and driving hard to get those up in the back half of next year. And as I said, they're on track and we're excited. The customers around our new Crystex product that we're producing off of this new process technology are very excited, and we're feeling pressure to get that plant up as quickly as we can to serve this new interest in the better-performing product. So -- and the growth rates in there largely [ph] has just been fantastic, so we need to get that plant up to keep our growth. In regards to Advanced Materials, they're just having a phenomenal year like they had a phenomenal year last year, and it's really proof of our strategy we have been talking about for the last 5 years. We said we're going to drive growth through innovation, and that's what we're doing. In Tritan and heads-up display and acoustic interlayers and our performance films business, all delivering double-digit growth and driving not just the sort of overall volume growth but the mix upgrade with all those products growing at such high rates with above-segment and above-company average margins. So it's just a good story. It's really -- very little of it is a raw material tailwind in what's driving the results, which gives us confidence that it will sustain going forward. And obviously, third quarter was a quarter where everything just ran really well. We had good volume, good mix, the plants ran incredibly well. One of the challenges in these kind of businesses, where you're making such a physical product, is you have yield and quality issues, and we just had a really clean quarter in how we ran the plants.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, could you help us out a little bit in terms of looking at Additives & Functional Products? It's sort of sitting in this specialty area in your bar chart. So earnings are going to be slightly down. Can you kind of parse out, there's a lot of business
componenttext: Mark, could you help us out a little bit in terms of looking at Additives & Functional Products? It's sort of sitting in this specialty area in your bar chart. So earnings are going to be slightly down. Can you kind of parse out, there's a lot of business in there, what's growing and maybe just kind of highlight the areas that -- on the specialty business there that are showing earnings growth and maybe some of the headwinds, the hedges and stuff, that's kind of impacting that?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So first of all, this portfolio is a great set of portfolio -- of specialty businesses, tremendous additives that add a lot of functionality across our customers in coatings, tires, adhesives, and animal nutrition, crop, et cetera. It's just a great
componenttext: Sure. So first of all, this portfolio is a great set of portfolio -- of specialty businesses, tremendous additives that add a lot of functionality across our customers in coatings, tires, adhesives, and animal nutrition, crop, et cetera. It's just a great business of unique additives. So we view it as a business that will continue to grow. As you look at the pricing, which I think is the key question, and how it's come off, prices have really stabilized since the second quarter. So they -- we did a great job of holding on to raw material value in the beginning of last year, started giving some of it back in third quarter but really started giving it back in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of this year as we decided to share value with our customers. But those prices have stabilized, and we really didn't have much sequential decline in prices at all from second quarter into the third quarter of this year. And we expect the same sort of stability as we go into the fourth quarter. And you'll see that as -- even on a year-over-year basis in January as you see the trends in the fourth quarter. So that feels very stable to us and appropriate. As -- and we actually expect prices probably to start moving up in the coatings area, especially on the olefin-related products. The specialties are a little slower on prices on the way down. They're also slower on the way up. So Chemical Intermediates has already started to move on the pricing front, and we expect, as we go into next year, those prices on the specialty-related products will also start to move up with those -- with these current market conditions. So that all feels directionally correct to me. I think the important point is how you sustain these margins and continue to deliver growth over the long term. It's easy to hold on to prices when raws drop. But if you do that too aggressively and not share some of it with your customers, you really create a problem with those customers being engaged in working with you on any future innovation. And I think we've struck the right balance here, and we're seeing that in the proof of our innovation successes. We're just having tremendous success throughout the AFP portfolio with innovation. Our polyester coatings is doing tremendously well. We talked to you about that in the first quarter call, and we've gone from 3 to 10 customers aggressively working with us on how to commercialize that product and take it to market. We're seeing great success in the tire resins that I just told you about. We're seeing great success in the Aerafin olefin products that I told you about in the second quarter call that go with the adhesive resins. We continue to see great traction in our loader coal assets. And so across the portfolio, you're seeing a lot of innovation, a lot of traction. And as I said before, this is a little bit slower in getting started than Advanced Materials, but as you look at the next 3 years, you're going to see all these innovation programs driving growth and mix improvement here, just like what we're doing in Advanced Materials. So the love is [ph] -- we're proving, across the board, we can deliver growth and innovation. We can create our own growth. We're not waiting for the economy to get better. And that's the story you're going to see us deliver over the next 3 years.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect AFP to show good earnings growth next year as a combination of modest market volume growth. We're not assuming an improving economy next year just to be clear, but we do assume there is an economy growing somewhat. So we'll get some volume growt
componenttext: We expect AFP to show good earnings growth next year as a combination of modest market volume growth. We're not assuming an improving economy next year just to be clear, but we do assume there is an economy growing somewhat. So we'll get some volume growth. We'll get some mix improvement through the innovation. We'll certainly see some benefits of the hedge. But remember, 80% of the hedge benefit flows to Chemical Intermediates, so it's modest here. And of course, the broader cost management programs, a certain amount of that benefit is going to flow into this segment.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, Curt. Got you. Just kidding. I have to ask a question, Mark, with respect to Fibers, in the positioning in the portfolio. 2015, very difficult year. '16, very difficult year. '17, you just changed guidance from 10% to 20% down to now down 20%. As
componenttext: Got you, Curt. Got you. Just kidding. I have to ask a question, Mark, with respect to Fibers, in the positioning in the portfolio. 2015, very difficult year. '16, very difficult year. '17, you just changed guidance from 10% to 20% down to now down 20%. As I think about some of the shifting that's going on there, we used to kind of count on annual sort of contracts with your customers there, but now we're hearing of multiyear contracts. So if you guys are structuring multiyear contracts, are we setting the stage where '18 and '19 are also going to be more difficult years? Can you talk a little bit about the prospects for that business post another difficult year?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. We've obviously spent an extensive amount of time talking about what's going on in the Fibers business, from demand trends to competitive behavior, and I think I provided quite a long soliloquy on this one in the second quarter call. So I'll
componenttext: Sure, Frank. We've obviously spent an extensive amount of time talking about what's going on in the Fibers business, from demand trends to competitive behavior, and I think I provided quite a long soliloquy on this one in the second quarter call. So I'll try and be sort of brief on it now. Bottom line is you had a situation where the demand situation weakened across the globe, specifically the imports in China, and that's created pressure on pricing. And what we're seeing right now is that pricing pressure play out into the 2017 time frame. Our objective is doing what we can to sort of keep the business stable. That's been our objective from the beginning. We took capacity out in the U.K. as we added capacity in China, and we also exited some flake capacity as well. On the pricing front, we have attempted to be as stable as we can be on the pricing. Unfortunately, we got pushed pretty aggressively on some of our competitors trying to take share from us outside of China, and all we're trying to do is defend our share and keep it stable outside of China. We're not trying to recover lost imports in China by taking share outside of China. And we think the best way to do that is to get multiyear contracts on volume and price in place with many of our large customers, which will provide stability actually from '17 into '18 and '19 as we provide security of supply to our customers but also provide security of demand to us. So I think that those actions are actually going to put us in the right direction as far as the things that we can do to control the outcome in this industry and our performance, and we'll just have to see how the rest of it plays out.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, I'll talk about the taxes. Again, as you know, Jeff -- and you can see a lot of what's going on with our cash tax rate versus current as what goes through in our deferred tax line item in the cash flow statement. And so you see that has i
componenttext: All right. Well, I'll talk about the taxes. Again, as you know, Jeff -- and you can see a lot of what's going on with our cash tax rate versus current as what goes through in our deferred tax line item in the cash flow statement. And so you see that has improved this year, and again -- that's, again, a lot of great work that occurs with our tax, finance and legal teams, who are looking for ways to just -- as to really how do we help reduce costs and how do we help cash flows within this company. And so when I look at that going into next year, I do believe -- again, we won't have the benefits of those NOLs from Solutia that we've enjoyed. And in fact, if I didn't mention earlier, we've utilized all the NOLs since the acquisition in 2012, and so that was at an accelerated pace because of that great work. And again, the phaseout of bonus depreciation. So there's a pretty good opportunity for us to continue to look at our cash tax rate, but it will be more challenging as a goal for the next several years. On the Fibers...

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Fibers demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends, where the markets continue to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and
componenttext: On the Fibers demand, I'll take that one, Jeff. Outside of China, we don't expect any changes in trends, where the markets continue to decline sort of 1% to 2% a year, which has been true for a long time. Inside China, demand in China is a complicated and opaque question. Right now, we have seen some changes in production rate, cigarette production, where they've taken it down 6% to 7%, which is great because, I think, they're just destocking primarily with those actions. You have to remember that production rates are not equal to primary consumption rates. We do expect that they had trouble destocking cigarettes in '15 and '16 -- I'm sorry, '15 and '14. So I think that we're actually encouraged to see them taking actions to finally address that issue like they're already addressing at the tow inventory level as well. So in some ways, I think there's progress to put this behind us. And primary demand in China...

componenttextpreview: So roughly minus 10%?
componenttext: So roughly minus 10%?
