componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from P.J. Juvekar from Citi.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on Crystex. You seem to be doing a good job on innovation. But the OEM market -- the auto OEM market is slowing. The Class 8 truck market seem to be slowing as well. So can you talk about demand there? And is there any generic competition from
componenttext: A question on Crystex. You seem to be doing a good job on innovation. But the OEM market -- the auto OEM market is slowing. The Class 8 truck market seem to be slowing as well. So can you talk about demand there? And is there any generic competition from China coming in?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in auto demand, it sort of impacts us in multiple places. So in Advanced Materials, which is very OEM-driven, we are looking at that. What's been great about our success to date is we're creating a lot of our own earnings growth through mix upgrade and
componenttext: So in auto demand, it sort of impacts us in multiple places. So in Advanced Materials, which is very OEM-driven, we are looking at that. What's been great about our success to date is we're creating a lot of our own earnings growth through mix upgrade and double-digit growth in things like acoustics and heads-up display as well as a new channel strategy in performance films, where we're growing the whole size of the market and our share of it. So even in a slow automotive growth world, we can still deliver growth. It may not be as high as this year but still deliver growth. So I feel good about where we are there. And we see tremendous innovation opportunities continuing out there to add more functionality to the windows as we work with our customers in next generation of acoustics and heads-up display as well as other functionality. So it's just a very robust opportunity for growth. On the Additives & Functional Products side, when it comes to coatings and tires, we're more balanced through that. It's more of a balanced market from refinish or replacement tires than OEM. And so there, we're less exposed to sort of OEM trend rates as we are in Advanced Materials. So I think that, again, we'll have some solid growth there, and I'm not really worried about the OEM trend rates being a material issue.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly, I think, Curt, you mentioned that selling the ethylene business is being difficult in this environment. I would imagine that as we get into second half of '17 and '18 when the new ethylene capacity starts up, that it will get
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly, I think, Curt, you mentioned that selling the ethylene business is being difficult in this environment. I would imagine that as we get into second half of '17 and '18 when the new ethylene capacity starts up, that it will get even more difficult. So can you give us your thoughts about timing of the sale?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The timing of the sale? Sorry, you just were breaking up there.
componenttext: The timing of the sale? Sorry, you just were breaking up there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you're talking about the excess ethylene and the commodity olefins, we continue to have a number of parties actively engaged in the process. As I mentioned, it's been -- continue to be a challenging environment right now to ensure we get fair value
componenttext: So if you're talking about the excess ethylene and the commodity olefins, we continue to have a number of parties actively engaged in the process. As I mentioned, it's been -- continue to be a challenging environment right now to ensure we get fair value for those kind of assets. And quite honestly, it's been further compounded by having a competing asset coming into the marketplace. So we'll just be disciplined with valuation and patient on timing as needed. And so I think I mentioned, this is -- going into next year, I can't give you a good sense of next year other than I would suspect first half of the year feels about right, that we'll have better progress on the different options that we have. And again, we're not just sitting idle. We'll look and see if an outright sale is possible, but we'll continue to evaluate other options or structures and pursue them as appropriate as well.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the one thing you should take from us is we're committed to improving the quality of our portfolio and the stability of our earnings. We -- before it became a trend, we were already divesting a lot of underperforming volatile businesses and have d
componenttext: I mean, the one thing you should take from us is we're committed to improving the quality of our portfolio and the stability of our earnings. We -- before it became a trend, we were already divesting a lot of underperforming volatile businesses and have done a lot of portfolio transformation, as we noted earlier. And we'll continue to look at every way we can do it that's practical. But at the end of the day, we're going to focus on shareholder value creation and make sure what we do creates value.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kevin McCarthy from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, your Advanced Materials operating margins were up 350 basis points year-over-year. It looks like they were up actually a little bit more than that versus the first quarter. How sustainable is the current level?
componenttext: Mark, your Advanced Materials operating margins were up 350 basis points year-over-year. It looks like they were up actually a little bit more than that versus the first quarter. How sustainable is the current level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, we feel good about the margins we have in this business. As I said, we were running incredibly well through the third quarter and did this through volume and mix, which we generally view as a very sustainable way to grow earnings over the long term
componenttext: Kevin, we feel good about the margins we have in this business. As I said, we were running incredibly well through the third quarter and did this through volume and mix, which we generally view as a very sustainable way to grow earnings over the long term. It was a clean quarter. So there's always some quarters where you're going to have some quality issues and things like that, but I think the margins are sustainable. I would note that the fourth quarter always does have a seasonal decline in volumes, and so those margins are always going to be a little bit lower on a fourth quarter basis versus the third.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up. I think in your prepared remarks, you mentioned performance films had a new channel strategy. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.
componenttext: And as a follow-up. I think in your prepared remarks, you mentioned performance films had a new channel strategy. I just wonder if you could elaborate on that.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. One of the great things about this business is it's a consumer products business, where we have direct access to consumers and deliver a wide range of products and we have the best products in the industry. But when we picked up Solutia, their strat
componenttext: Sure. One of the great things about this business is it's a consumer products business, where we have direct access to consumers and deliver a wide range of products and we have the best products in the industry. But when we picked up Solutia, their strategy of how to go to market and how to even expand the market was not that sophisticated. And so we spent a lot of time rethinking our channel strategies and figuring out how to not just go through aftermarket retail shops but develop much more compelling programs through auto dealers in the U.S., which allows us to access an entirely new set of customers that don't show up in an aftermarket tin shop, and have been incredibly successful in expanding the market and also improving the quality of how we go to market. Same thing true in China. We were doing quite well aftermarket, not as successful in the auto dealerships and had significantly improved our channel strategy to go through the auto dealerships, which is a very important channel in China, and we're seeing great success. And it's not just going to those channels but how we take the products to market, how we're positioning our value proposition versus our competitors in a more compelling way. It's just been a great story of determined improvement of our go-to-market strategy over the last 3 years.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Laurence Alexander from Jefferies.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions, one on the Fibers market. Can you give a sense for how steep you think the underlying cost curve is? I'm thinking particularly where -- like where you see sort of the marginal -- the smallest, most marginal producers. And secondly, as yo
componenttext: Just 2 questions, one on the Fibers market. Can you give a sense for how steep you think the underlying cost curve is? I'm thinking particularly where -- like where you see sort of the marginal -- the smallest, most marginal producers. And secondly, as you look out over, I would say, the next 3 to 5 years, are there any large chunks that would -- of nonoperating expense that would affect the free cash flow bridge, either maintenance turnarounds or facilities where you need to do another CapEx cycle or pension contributions or anything else that you see like on a 3- to 5-year horizon?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the cost curve side, there is certainly high- and low-cost assets in the integrated flake and tow components of the Fibers business. As I've said in the past, we are the lowest-cost producer. We're backward integrating coal. We have the larges
componenttext: Sure. So on the cost curve side, there is certainly high- and low-cost assets in the integrated flake and tow components of the Fibers business. As I've said in the past, we are the lowest-cost producer. We're backward integrating coal. We have the largest scale, and we're actually now down to our largest, most integrated asset, is our only asset here in Tennessee, is flake, which is matched to our tow capacity here in Tennessee with -- combined with our Korean tow capacity and China. So we're very happy about our cost position. Our competitors are based on either purchased methanol or anhydride in some cases, so some of these assets are certainly exposed to much higher cost position. They picked up some advantage with lower oil today versus where they were. As oil goes up, that cost position is going to become less competitive relative to where we are. There are a number of high-cost assets out there that can be shut down by competitors, if they ever choose to do so, to improve their cost position to serve their customers, and we're going to have to see what they choose to do. As the market stabilizes, as we put in stability through these multiyear contracts, it's -- it becomes more challenging to figure out how you're going to grow earnings growth, and hopefully, they'll look at those options.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the operating cash flows and some things you mentioned, Laurence, when I look at 2 or 3 areas, first of all, in pension, we talked about contributing about $50 million to $75 million of pension this year. That's still what we're anticipating. Over the
componenttext: On the operating cash flows and some things you mentioned, Laurence, when I look at 2 or 3 areas, first of all, in pension, we talked about contributing about $50 million to $75 million of pension this year. That's still what we're anticipating. Over the next couple of years, I'm looking at maybe roughly $75 million of pension contributions over the next couple of years. After that point, you kind of have to really look at what discount rates have done and how the returns have come in, to whether that number needs to increase to $100 million or maybe come down to $50 million. But that kind of gives you a band of what pension contributions could be like over the next 3 years to 5 years. On capital, when you got the kind of assets we have, yes, every 3 years to 5 years, there's going to be turnarounds. What we have -- we do and we have a great team that does it, we try to manage to capital -- maintenance spend to capital spend we have each year. Part of it's not only cash flow, part of it's just resources. So yes, we're going to have some capital spend over these years. But some of the unique items that we've had these last few years, like the -- some of the assets that we had to build in Texas as well as conversions to -- from natural -- coal to natural gas. There's a little bit ahead of us yet, but most of it's done. So I suspect our maintenance capital will be in that $300 million to $350 million range over that 5-year time period, and then we'll have growth capital on top of it to support all the attractive innovation programs that Mark talked about. So I think those are the main 2 things you were looking at there.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: No. Right now, I'd say the currencies we're seeing today is kind of what we anticipate going into next year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And some of your coatings customers are experiencing some headwinds now. Can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of downstream coatings demand and whether you're feeling the same pressures?
componenttext: Great. And some of your coatings customers are experiencing some headwinds now. Can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of downstream coatings demand and whether you're feeling the same pressures?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Since January, we've always assumed a very slow economic growth world, and we never assumed that the economy was going to improve. So this sort of 1% to 2% volume range is sort of where we've been and what we've assumed, and so there's no real change in o
componenttext: Since January, we've always assumed a very slow economic growth world, and we never assumed that the economy was going to improve. So this sort of 1% to 2% volume range is sort of where we've been and what we've assumed, and so there's no real change in our forecast. Based on some of the comments I've seen by a number of customers, it sounds like what they're talking about is they expected stronger growth and now they're sort of moderating back to this slower growth expectation. If that's the case, we're already there in our forecasting, and there wouldn't be any challenges for us. The risk though, of course, is if they've been planning and assuming higher growth, do they have some destocking issues that they have to address in the fourth quarter. We have no evidence from any of our customers that, that's happening yet, but that's something we'll have to keep an eye on.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to our next question from John Roberts from UBS.
componenttext: And we'll go to our next question from John Roberts from UBS.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: How much of the lower tax rate in the quarter was adjustments from prior period tax returns? And how much was just geographic mix in the current period?
componenttext: How much of the lower tax rate in the quarter was adjustments from prior period tax returns? And how much was just geographic mix in the current period?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if you look at the tax rate, let me just make one comment. In any particular tax year, you're going to have discrete items, such as the one you're asking about specifically. It was a $60 million benefit from better utilizations of foreign tax credits f
componenttext: So if you look at the tax rate, let me just make one comment. In any particular tax year, you're going to have discrete items, such as the one you're asking about specifically. It was a $60 million benefit from better utilizations of foreign tax credits from the Solutia acquisition that we recognized in the third quarter. That was related to amended returns that we were able to put in place. But I would add, these discrete items can vary each year for a variety of reasons, the results of audits, amending returns, et cetera. Again, I'm going to say this twice because they deserve it. We have a great tax, finance and legal team that knows how to manage these as best we can in any given year. I also value [ph] -- it hasn't been asked yet, but I know we'd anticipate it. It's a little early for an effective tax rate for '17, but let me go and throw it out there. When I look at the things we put in place, there are some permanent improvements that we've seen with the actions that we've taken. So I think our effective tax rate for next year will improve, and I think it'll be more in the 23% to 24% range.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good. I didn't have to use up my second question. Are there non-Fiber applications for cellulosic resins that could use up some of the excess polymer capacity to help rebalance the cig tow market? Or should we think about the use of polymer for fib
componenttext: That's good. I didn't have to use up my second question. Are there non-Fiber applications for cellulosic resins that could use up some of the excess polymer capacity to help rebalance the cig tow market? Or should we think about the use of polymer for fiber as distinct from other applications?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent question, and I'm glad you asked it. There are other applications. So as we saw in 2014 that the world was going to start slowing down in tow demand associated with cigarettes, we started up a team to aggressively look at how to develop new mark
componenttext: Excellent question, and I'm glad you asked it. There are other applications. So as we saw in 2014 that the world was going to start slowing down in tow demand associated with cigarettes, we started up a team to aggressively look at how to develop new market applications around cellulosics, and we're making tremendous progress on how to sort of reuse these assets into new market applications. Something to keep in mind about Eastman is that we have a 90-year history of innovating when it comes to cellulosics. We started out with film, we then went into yarn, then we went into tow, then we went into plastics for things like tool handles and sunglass frames and then we took cellulosic technology into coating additives, then TVs and now into tires as another new emerging application. We know how to innovate in this space. We've done a lot more of this innovation than anyone else has ever done in creating new markets, just like we've done in polyesters, starting with polyester fiber to PET to a wide range of polyester applications. So we know how to do this. And so we're making great progress. We're not going to get into the specific products right now because we are having great success in moving this forward and we're still locking up IP. But these assets can make other products that go into other applications, and you'll hear a lot more about that next year. It's what we do and are very good at doing.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to our next question from Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll go to our next question from Vincent Andrews, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the past, it's been referenced that perhaps there could be portfolio options for the divestitures, not all that different from what you've done over the years. Any updated thoughts on that -- beyond the cracker?
componenttext: In the past, it's been referenced that perhaps there could be portfolio options for the divestitures, not all that different from what you've done over the years. Any updated thoughts on that -- beyond the cracker?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We continue to -- no. I mean, our focus right now has been the excess ethylene and the commodity olefin product lines. We continue to look at the rest of the portfolio to see if there's opportunities that maybe there's a more natural owner. We do that in
componenttext: We continue to -- no. I mean, our focus right now has been the excess ethylene and the commodity olefin product lines. We continue to look at the rest of the portfolio to see if there's opportunities that maybe there's a more natural owner. We do that in due course with our board, and at this point, there's nothing that we're talking about specifically. But we'll continue to evaluate different things in our portfolio. We like the portfolio as a whole, so it's really stuff on the margin.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we've been on this journey of optimizing our portfolio for a long time, right? I mean, we've sold off $3.5 billion of revenue from underperforming businesses. We've done acquisitions, adding $4.2 billion of revenue, specialty businesses. And by th
componenttext: I mean, we've been on this journey of optimizing our portfolio for a long time, right? I mean, we've sold off $3.5 billion of revenue from underperforming businesses. We've done acquisitions, adding $4.2 billion of revenue, specialty businesses. And by the way, we paid 9x EBITDA for those specialty businesses with 7x EBITDA multiples plus synergies -- to provide attractive synergies as well as reasonable ROICs above cost of capital for our investors. So I feel great about the actions we've taken in improving our portfolio, and we're certainly committed to keeping that momentum going. But I don't think there's any big, large changes that we need to make, both on the acquisition side or on significant divestiture side. We're going to continue to look at these opportunities, like the ethylene, as ways to take out pockets of volatility, but our focus and our strategy is about innovation and growth. We're driving innovation and growth. We're managing costs aggressively. We're going to continue to create value in a capital-efficient way because we're doing mix upgrades of existing assets in how we drive this innovation. We're going to generate a lot of free cash flow and buy back stock and increase the dividend and improve our balance sheet. I think it's a compelling story as it is.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on capacity utilization levels. You might have mentioned this earlier, but I needed to hop off for a second. In Advanced Materials, you talked about how part of the margin improvement was being able to run at a higher utilizatio
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on capacity utilization levels. You might have mentioned this earlier, but I needed to hop off for a second. In Advanced Materials, you talked about how part of the margin improvement was being able to run at a higher utilization level. Is there -- as volume grows into next year, is that a benefit that we should continue to see? Or are you sort of now at a new tranche of profitability at this utilization level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to dramatically improve our profitability from where we are at this stage, but I do think we're going to continue driving double-digit earnings growth going forward as we grow volume, mix and manage cost. But even here, we've got
componenttext: I don't think we're going to dramatically improve our profitability from where we are at this stage, but I do think we're going to continue driving double-digit earnings growth going forward as we grow volume, mix and manage cost. But even here, we've got Tritan expansion going on. We'll have to bring on a new chunk of capacity into next year to support this incredible growth we're having with Tritan with the existing products, and I should mention we also have new products that we're making off of the same chemistry to access even more addressable market than where we are today with Tritan. And so you add new capacity, it adds some chunk --- chunks of cost you got to work your way through.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Vince, if I could just add. What that -- as you add those chunks of capacity, as you transition to that, you will have some startup costs next year, and that will be some challenges for this business. But again, they'll still deliver that double-digit
componenttext: And Vince, if I could just add. What that -- as you add those chunks of capacity, as you transition to that, you will have some startup costs next year, and that will be some challenges for this business. But again, they'll still deliver that double-digit earnings growth despite that, and you need that capacity then to grow past '18 and beyond.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Aleksey Yefremov from Nomura Securities.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Aleksey Yefremov from Nomura Securities.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us an estimate of sales opportunity for the new tire product that you talked about today?
componenttext: Could you give us an estimate of sales opportunity for the new tire product that you talked about today?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For tire resins, it's a great opportunity. The tire resins historically have just been used as a processing aid, and now we have this whole new addressable market in the tread as a performance additive improving traction in the tire. We're seeing tremendo
componenttext: For tire resins, it's a great opportunity. The tire resins historically have just been used as a processing aid, and now we have this whole new addressable market in the tread as a performance additive improving traction in the tire. We're seeing tremendous adoption and interest across tire companies across the globe, and we really seem to be the preferred innovation partner because we have the broadest set of chemistry. So we're still trying to understand the full potential of this market. We're not going to complain about the 20% growth rate. Obviously, it's off of a relatively small number. But we see it as a significant market that could easily be $100 million, $200 million of additional revenue.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And in the tow business, the 20% expected decline in profitability next year, how would you attribute it to volume versus price?
componenttext: Great. And in the tow business, the 20% expected decline in profitability next year, how would you attribute it to volume versus price?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, we have a strategy of defending our share outside of China. So we're not expecting it to be a volume-driven story outside of China. It's going to be a price-driven story. In the China side of it, there's a lot of conflicting data about
componenttext: As I said earlier, we have a strategy of defending our share outside of China. So we're not expecting it to be a volume-driven story outside of China. It's going to be a price-driven story. In the China side of it, there's a lot of conflicting data about what's going on with demand and destocking in China, so it's a little hard to know what the imports are going to be next year. And so we're just going to have to see. Right now, we're assuming a modest decline.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move to our next question from Nils Wallin from CLSA.
componenttext: And we'll move to our next question from Nils Wallin from CLSA.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First one is we haven't heard you guys talk about the -- your deal with Enterprise and their PDH unit. Is there going to be any sort of benefit next year as that comes online in terms of your propylene purchases?
componenttext: First one is we haven't heard you guys talk about the -- your deal with Enterprise and their PDH unit. Is there going to be any sort of benefit next year as that comes online in terms of your propylene purchases?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, good partner, and we're looking forward to that capacity online. Yes, we do -- that will -- what that'll ultimately do, for those that aren't familiar with it, is allow us to -- where we've been purchased propylene, we'll now have addi
componenttext: Well, first of all, good partner, and we're looking forward to that capacity online. Yes, we do -- that will -- what that'll ultimately do, for those that aren't familiar with it, is allow us to -- where we've been purchased propylene, we'll now have additional propylene that's sourced through that propane, and we'll be more sourced with propane than we are today. We used to talk about that benefit was going to be roughly $30 million a year. But where the spreads are today, it's much lower than that, but we're still going to like that contract and that relationship long term.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then in Chemical Intermediates, obviously, there was quite a significant ramp in spot ethylene prices during the quarter, yet there was, you mentioned, some other competitive pressures. So was the benefit from the spot ethylene margins going u
componenttext: Got it. And then in Chemical Intermediates, obviously, there was quite a significant ramp in spot ethylene prices during the quarter, yet there was, you mentioned, some other competitive pressures. So was the benefit from the spot ethylene margins going up offset by competitive pressures? Or were you just not quite as able to capitalize on that spot price round?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think we did a nice job of capturing the ethylene benefits. But you also have to remember our propane and ethane costs also went up considerably in the quarter. So there wasn't a huge expansion in spreads, but it certainly was better than last year
componenttext: No, I think we did a nice job of capturing the ethylene benefits. But you also have to remember our propane and ethane costs also went up considerably in the quarter. So there wasn't a huge expansion in spreads, but it certainly was better than last year and certainly carrying into the fourth quarter in a better state than last year.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Arun Viswanathan from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Arun Viswanathan from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions on normalized margins. You've held up margins quite well in both Fibers and AM. So on AM, do you think that you'd still be able to grow margins in the next couple of years as you continue to grow volume? And similarly, on
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions on normalized margins. You've held up margins quite well in both Fibers and AM. So on AM, do you think that you'd still be able to grow margins in the next couple of years as you continue to grow volume? And similarly, on Fibers, if you stabilize volume, would fiber margins kind of hold in at this level?

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On AM, the margins are likely to be more stable around these higher levels than further increase. As we mentioned, there's the preproduction expenses, starting of new capacity and the focus on volume growth. So I think it will be stable. When it comes to
componenttext: On AM, the margins are likely to be more stable around these higher levels than further increase. As we mentioned, there's the preproduction expenses, starting of new capacity and the focus on volume growth. So I think it will be stable. When it comes to Fibers, the margins will come off from where we are today with the forecasted drop of earnings of around 20% into next year. It's important to keep in mind the altitude of these margins. This is an exceptionally profitable and attractive business, and even some moderating margins here is still incredibly attractive for any business. So we're going to manage through that and continue to find ways to stabilize it into '18.

headline: Eastman Chemical Co., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Thanks again for joining us this morning. A web replay and a replay in downloadable MP3 format will be available on our website later this morning. Have a great day.

componenttext: Thank you, everyone.
